headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations,  and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations,  and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Vice President, Controller. 
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results.
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken, and good morning. Thanks to PACCAR's 23,000 employees around the world, 2015 was an outstanding year for the company with many records established. PACCAR achieved record revenues of $19.1 billion and record net income of $1.6 billion, and af
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken, and good morning. Thanks to PACCAR's 23,000 employees around the world, 2015 was an outstanding year for the company with many records established. PACCAR achieved record revenues of $19.1 billion and record net income of $1.6 billion, and after-tax return on revenues of 8.4%. Net income increased 18% versus the prior year. 2015 was PACCAR's 77th consecutive year of earning on net income. These excellent results reflect the strongest North American heavy truck market since 2006 and the highest European heavy truck market since 2008. 
In addition, PACCAR Parts earned record pretax income and PACCAR Financial Services achieved another strong profit year. PACCAR celebrated several important milestones in our 110th anniversary year. These included the delivery of DAF's 1 millionth truck, the production of the 100,000 engine in our Mississippi engine factory and 35th anniversary celebrations at Peterbilt's Dent in Texas factory and in PACCAR Leasing. During the year, PACCAR continued investing in premium quality products and services in our core markets, and expanding our presence in emerging markets to provide the foundation for future growth. 
PACCAR's fourth quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and quarterly net income was $347 million, a strong 8.8% after-tax return on revenues. During the quarter, European truck deliveries increased, partially offsetting reduced North American truck deliveries. The strong contribution of all companies segments enables PACCAR to attain the highest operating margins in our industry. PACCAR declared cash dividends up $2.30 per share last year, a 25% increase compared to 2014 and the highest total dividend in company history. 
The regular quarterly dividend was raised by 9% during the year. PACCAR's total dividends in 2015 provided a yield of over 4%, which is in the top 100 companies in the S&P 500. During 2015, PACCAR repurchased 3.8 million shares of its stock for $202 million. PACCAR delivered 35,400 trucks during the fourth quarter in line with expectations. Vehicle deliveries, and truck and other margins in the first quarter this year are projected to be comparable to the fourth quarter. Peterbilt and Kenworth achieved a good market share of 27.4% in the U.S. and Canada heavy duty truck market in 2015. Class 8 truck industry retail sales totaled 278,000 units for the year. 
Peterbilt and Kenworth also achieved a record 17.4% share of the U.S. and Canadian medium duty truck market last year, resulting in a record 27,300 medium duty truck deliveries for PACCAR. 2016 will be another good year for the U.S. and Canadian Class 8 industry truck market with retail sales estimated to be in the range of 230,000 to 260,000 units. Additional good news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth dealer inventories are in great shape entering this year. 
DAF increase its market share to 14.6% in the European above 16-tonne truck market last year compared to 13.8% in 2014. The market was a strong 269,000 units in 2015. Looking at this year, we anticipate that the European above 16-tonne market has the potential to expand further and be in a range of 260,000 to 290,000 vehicles. Economic growth in Europe is expected to increase this year to 1.7% with more than 2% growth anticipated in the U.K., DAF's largest market. 
PACCAR Parts generated record pretax profit of $556 million and strong revenues of $3.1 billion in 2015. The excellent results were driven by strong freight tonnage, high fleet utilization and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts. During the year, PACCAR Parts set records for parts deliveries to fleets, online part sales and TRP part sales for all makes of trucks and trailers. For the fourth quarter, PACCAR Parts achieved revenues of $750 million and pretax income of $126 million. 
Our expectation for 2016 is that parts and revenues -- is that parts revenues, excluding the effects of currency movements could increased 3% to 5%. PACCAR Financial Services revenues were $293 million in the fourth quarter and pretax income was $90 million. The good results benefited from continuing strong portfolio performance. PACCAR leasing ended the year with a record 39,000 units its full service lease portfolio. For the full year, PACCAR Financial Services earned pretax income of $363 million. 
At this point, I'm going to have Michael Barkley address the effects of currency movements on our segment operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the truck segment, the quarter-over-quarter comparison has us -- the impact of currency was $200 million on revenue and for the full year, the impact was $940 million on revenue. The profit impact was minimal given that we had a large amount of materi
componenttext: For the truck segment, the quarter-over-quarter comparison has us -- the impact of currency was $200 million on revenue and for the full year, the impact was $940 million on revenue. The profit impact was minimal given that we had a large amount of material coming for our engines in to our Columbus engine factory from the Eurozone. For parts. The quarterly impact on revenue was $38 million and for the full year was $193 million. The impact on profit was $4 million and for the quarter -- $34 million for the full year. For financial services, the impact on revenue was $17 million and the impact for the full year was $79 million. And the impact on profit for financial services was $5 million. For the quarter and for the full year, it was $22 million.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. As we look at next year, PACCAR's projected research and development spending of $240,000 to $270 million and capital expenditures of $325 million to $375 million will expand Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF product offerings, enhance the P
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. As we look at next year, PACCAR's projected research and development spending of $240,000 to $270 million and capital expenditures of $325 million to $375 million will expand Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF product offerings, enhance the PACCAR engine range and increase the capacity and operating efficiency of our factories and distribution centers. 
As the company begins its 111th year, we are in an excellent position to lead the industry with the highest-quality products and services. Thank you, and I'd be pleased to answer your questions.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Tim Thein with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Tim Thein with Citi.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the first one. Maybe you could extend -- I think you had mentioned the margin 1Q being comparable to 4Q. Can you, based on the way things looked today, can you kind of extend that to your expectations for the year?
componenttext: Just on the first one. Maybe you could extend -- I think you had mentioned the margin 1Q being comparable to 4Q. Can you, based on the way things looked today, can you kind of extend that to your expectations for the year?

componenttextpreview: I think that as we think about margins for the year, I think that we see the full year being fairly comparable to 2015.
componenttext: I think that as we think about margins for the year, I think that we see the full year being fairly comparable to 2015.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then just on the market share trend in Europe. Obviously, how the individual countries play out can influence that quite a bit. Just in terms of some of your key markets, what are you thinking in terms of  and how they -- how you're plan
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just on the market share trend in Europe. Obviously, how the individual countries play out can influence that quite a bit. Just in terms of some of your key markets, what are you thinking in terms of  and how they -- how you're planning for that expectations just over all share. I know it's not easy to forecast it at this time of year. But I guess, just based on the gain, you can continue to gain further share for DAF and across Western Europe?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, DAF has a really long history of continuing to grow their share progressively over the long-term and that would continue to be our market, with the investments that we made and the great new year, all 6 products that they have in the marketplace, th
componenttext: Well, DAF has a really long history of continuing to grow their share progressively over the long-term and that would continue to be our market, with the investments that we made and the great new year, all 6 products that they have in the marketplace, the continuing enhancements that we make to the PACCAR engines. We've got a great product lineup. We have great service capability with PACCAR Parts and PACCAR Financial. So our anticipation is that we'll continue to increment that market share on our way through to our medium-term target of 20%.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Potter with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Potter with Piper Jaffray.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment a bit on inventory I guess, broadly in the channel. You mentioned during your prepared remarks that you think Peterbilt and Kenworth have -- are in good shape when it comes to retail inventory. I was just wondering if
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a bit on inventory I guess, broadly in the channel. You mentioned during your prepared remarks that you think Peterbilt and Kenworth have -- are in good shape when it comes to retail inventory. I was just wondering if you guys think that PACCAR was maybe more nimble than some of your competitors when it comes to responding to the recent downturn in orders, because obviously, a lot of folks have been talking about the buildup of inventory out there in the channel. So if you guys have, I guess low inventory that would imply that most of the inventory concerns are being felt by other truck companies. Is that accurate?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't really comment on the nimbleness of our competitors. But I know that we monitor our business very closely and manage it to balance the delivery of trucks with the demand that's in the market. I would say that based on what we know, we have 45, 50
componenttext: I can't really comment on the nimbleness of our competitors. But I know that we monitor our business very closely and manage it to balance the delivery of trucks with the demand that's in the market. I would say that based on what we know, we have 45, 50 days worth of inventory in the channel. I think the industry's closer to a 90-day measure. So I'd say we -- as I say, we're in great shape in terms of where we're at starting the 2016 year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. That's good to her. I was wondering I guess, also if you could make a couple of comments here on pricing. Obviously, if you look at just pure truck revenue and divide it by the number of units sold, it looks like there was a pretty materi
componenttext: Okay. Very good. That's good to her. I was wondering I guess, also if you could make a couple of comments here on pricing. Obviously, if you look at just pure truck revenue and divide it by the number of units sold, it looks like there was a pretty material degradation in sequential terms. But obviously, you've got some ForEx in there, you got presumably some mix maybe toward medium duty. Was just wondering if you could maybe help us interpret that sequential decline and how much is, I guess, "real pricing"?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, the margin performance for the quarter and the year were excellent. We expect that, as we'd mentioned margins in the first quarter to be comparable to what we saw in the fourth quarter. Almost all of the per unit degradation is exchange ra
componenttext: Yes, obviously, the margin performance for the quarter and the year were excellent. We expect that, as we'd mentioned margins in the first quarter to be comparable to what we saw in the fourth quarter. Almost all of the per unit degradation is exchange rate -- exchange related. So that's just the effects of translating currencies around the world into the U.S. dollar.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering what you're seeing in terms of used truck pricing and how that's influencing your forecast of demand for 2016 [ph] on new sales at this point? I think last quarter, it sounded like it wasn't much of an issue, but I'm wondering if anything has re
componenttext: Wondering what you're seeing in terms of used truck pricing and how that's influencing your forecast of demand for 2016 [ph] on new sales at this point? I think last quarter, it sounded like it wasn't much of an issue, but I'm wondering if anything has really changed there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is there are more used trucks coming into the market, and that's dampening used truck prices a bit. But the great news is that the Kenworth and Peterbilt products continue to earn a premium relative to the competition. And so we'
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is there are more used trucks coming into the market, and that's dampening used truck prices a bit. But the great news is that the Kenworth and Peterbilt products continue to earn a premium relative to the competition. And so we're very involved with selling used trucks last year. As a company, we sold about 9,000 trucks globally and we'll do that again this year. So we'll use that as a tool to be able to support new truck business and our finance operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think the margins have favored North America over Europe based on volume and the Euro 6 program over the last year. So you anticipate that 2016, the margin is going to be in, in balance again between the 2 regions at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And I think the margins have favored North America over Europe based on volume and the Euro 6 program over the last year. So you anticipate that 2016, the margin is going to be in, in balance again between the 2 regions at this point?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would think the margin, as we said, we expect it to be comparable to last year. And I think that would -- on a market basis, I think that would be true as well.
componenttext: I would think the margin, as we said, we expect it to be comparable to last year. And I think that would -- on a market basis, I think that would be true as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So still in other words, favoring North America over Europe sounds like then?
componenttext: So still in other words, favoring North America over Europe sounds like then?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase with Morgan Stanley.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ron, my first question is around your 1Q production outlook. I know you guys had flattish Q-on-Q, but what are the thoughts on U.S. and Canada versus Europe? You also expect like a flattish outcome for both of the regions?
componenttext: So Ron, my first question is around your 1Q production outlook. I know you guys had flattish Q-on-Q, but what are the thoughts on U.S. and Canada versus Europe? You also expect like a flattish outcome for both of the regions?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that North America is going to be up in the 10% to 15% range and Europe will be down in that kind of range just because of work days and production, beta production levels in each of the markets.
componenttext: Yes. I think that North America is going to be up in the 10% to 15% range and Europe will be down in that kind of range just because of work days and production, beta production levels in each of the markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. My second question is just, what have you guys seen or heard from U.S. customers with respect to the MX-11 launch so far?
componenttext: That's really helpful. My second question is just, what have you guys seen or heard from U.S. customers with respect to the MX-11 launch so far?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just -- we were just getting those into the field. The customers who have had the test trucks that have been running in the market, we have hundreds of thousands of test miles on those trucks and the feedback from those customers has just been
componenttext: Well, it's just -- we were just getting those into the field. The customers who have had the test trucks that have been running in the market, we have hundreds of thousands of test miles on those trucks and the feedback from those customers has just been -- has been excellent. So the MX-11 has been in the European market now for 2 years with great responses, now 25% of the production in our European operation. So we're excited to offer that and we think that will be a nice enhancement to meet customer needs both in the vocational and regional whole applications.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, I wonder if you can talk about your bookings in Europe in the quarter? Did your lead times widen out? It sounds like you're taking the build rate higher, if I'm not mistaken in the first quarter, given the number of working days. Is that right? Can y
componenttext: Ron, I wonder if you can talk about your bookings in Europe in the quarter? Did your lead times widen out? It sounds like you're taking the build rate higher, if I'm not mistaken in the first quarter, given the number of working days. Is that right? Can you just flush out what you're seeing in that market, please?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you rephrase your question, Jerry?
componenttext: Can you rephrase your question, Jerry?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So can you talk about whether your lead times extended in the fourth quarter? It looks like in Europe, it looks like your build rates are moving higher. So I would guess your book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was greater than 1. But I'd appreciate
componenttext: Sure. So can you talk about whether your lead times extended in the fourth quarter? It looks like in Europe, it looks like your build rates are moving higher. So I would guess your book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was greater than 1. But I'd appreciate any color there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Order intake during the course of last year really outpaced the build rate in the first parts of the year. So we were ramping up build rate and build rates as we start 2016 are very comparable to where we ended up last year, fewer workdays and just a
componenttext: Yes. Order intake during the course of last year really outpaced the build rate in the first parts of the year. So we were ramping up build rate and build rates as we start 2016 are very comparable to where we ended up last year, fewer workdays and just a slight reduction in the average daily count for the first quarter. So it's -- lead times are in excellent shape really in all of our markets as we began 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, obviously, we'll get the details when the K comes out. But I wonder if you can just help us bridge the year-over-year gross margin performance fourth quarter '15 versus fourth quarter '14, and in terms of the contribution of pricing, net o
componenttext: Okay. And then, obviously, we'll get the details when the K comes out. But I wonder if you can just help us bridge the year-over-year gross margin performance fourth quarter '15 versus fourth quarter '14, and in terms of the contribution of pricing, net of material cost, any pieces you can help us with would be helpful.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of moving pieces in there, Jerry with pricing, cost movement, customer mix, model mix, et cetera. So it's -- that's -- we really don't have that level of granularity here. So.
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of moving pieces in there, Jerry with pricing, cost movement, customer mix, model mix, et cetera. So it's -- that's -- we really don't have that level of granularity here. So.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the 2016 outlook, for the full year, you mentioned you're looking for a comparable gross margins even though shipments, I think are expected to be down based on your outlook for North American and European truck markets. Can you
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the 2016 outlook, for the full year, you mentioned you're looking for a comparable gross margins even though shipments, I think are expected to be down based on your outlook for North American and European truck markets. Can you talk about what's a favorable at the gross margin line that's providing that tailwind despite lower volumes?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our teams just do a great job of rigorously manning -- managing the cost structure. We obviously, worked very closely with our suppliers to make sure that we're getting our fair share of commodity cost movements. We have great products. The Kenworth
componenttext: Well, our teams just do a great job of rigorously manning -- managing the cost structure. We obviously, worked very closely with our suppliers to make sure that we're getting our fair share of commodity cost movements. We have great products. The Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF products are the highest quality and demand a premium price in the market. So as we look at this year, we feel that 2016 will be comparable to our 2015 levels.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about your parts business a little bit? It came in weaker on revenues and significantly weaker on EBIT margins than I was forecasting, and I don't know if I was just setting too high an expectation. Can you just talk about parts in Q4 and what
componenttext: Can we talk about your parts business a little bit? It came in weaker on revenues and significantly weaker on EBIT margins than I was forecasting, and I don't know if I was just setting too high an expectation. Can you just talk about parts in Q4 and what went on there? Did I miss something from a seasonality perspective?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think as we look at -- Michael talked about the exchange rate effects. And so when you compare the fourth quarter results with the fourth quarter of the prior year, they're essentially the same as last year. It's a very strong fourth quarter last ye
componenttext: No. I think as we look at -- Michael talked about the exchange rate effects. And so when you compare the fourth quarter results with the fourth quarter of the prior year, they're essentially the same as last year. It's a very strong fourth quarter last year. There is fewer -- there were fewer new trucks being delivered as well as I think that a little bit of rebalancing of inventories in the market. But as we commented, we think parts will continue to grow as we enter into 2016. Our parts team has done a great job with some of the many programs that they've put in place and we continue to see obviously, growth in the engine parts business as we go forward. So we think there's continued -- to see positive momentum as we go to 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful on the color. On your outlook for North America then 12 -- U.S. and Canada, then 12%, most of the industries forecasting significantly -- a significantly greater decline than back to kind of replacement levels of somewhere around 20 [
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful on the color. On your outlook for North America then 12 -- U.S. and Canada, then 12%, most of the industries forecasting significantly -- a significantly greater decline than back to kind of replacement levels of somewhere around 20 [ph]. What are you seeing out there? What are your customers telling you? What are your teams telling you? Where do you think the strength is coming from versus where others are forecasting?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, the on highway business is supported by strong freight tonnage metrics. There -- they've been pretty flat, but at a very high level. I think the last numbers that came out were like the second highest level on record. So freight activitie
componenttext: Well, obviously, the on highway business is supported by strong freight tonnage metrics. There -- they've been pretty flat, but at a very high level. I think the last numbers that came out were like the second highest level on record. So freight activities look good. The estimation for growth for next year for North America is 2% to 3% growth. So consumer demand is strong and so we see a lot of positives that are going to support a good market. If you look at the 230,000 to 360,000 trucks, it could be the second or third best in the last decade. So it's a good market for next year. So we're optimistic about how things will develop as we talk to customers, as we commented last, last quarter. Customers are ordering -- that have ordered are ordering levels comparable to what they ordered in 2015. I'd say a little bit of difference is that their expectations to last year -- the expectations for delivery were they needed them as soon as they could get them. And now they're thinking a little bit -- spreading those deliveries out further across the year. So we're seeing positive things overall.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add that Kenworth and Peterbilt are very strong in their locational segment and the construction activity continues to be strong. Forecasted to grow once again for residential housing in 2016. And so the vocational segment for us is performing
componenttext: And I would add that Kenworth and Peterbilt are very strong in their locational segment and the construction activity continues to be strong. Forecasted to grow once again for residential housing in 2016. And so the vocational segment for us is performing very well, especially with the new products that we're introducing into both Kenworth and Peterbilt.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And does that give you confidence then guiding to flattish or comparable margins year-over-year despite a decline in revenues?
componenttext: And does that give you confidence then guiding to flattish or comparable margins year-over-year despite a decline in revenues?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look at the expectations for the year cost and...
componenttext: Yes. As we look at the expectations for the year cost and...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our parts mix will grow a little bit and the parts margins are obviously, good. We'll continue to operate at a very high level in the parts business and that should be a net positive for margins as well.
componenttext: Our parts mix will grow a little bit and the parts margins are obviously, good. We'll continue to operate at a very high level in the parts business and that should be a net positive for margins as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Crédit Suisse.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, I mean it sounds like you guys are obviously, more constructive relative to your peers. But if you look at the industry numbers, cancellation rates have picked up over the past several months. Have you seen any of that? Or have
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, I mean it sounds like you guys are obviously, more constructive relative to your peers. But if you look at the industry numbers, cancellation rates have picked up over the past several months. Have you seen any of that? Or have you been immune to that? And then I guess a broader just cycle question, do you view this as sort of a -- the -- obviously, the level of decline you're expecting this year is less than the industry. But do you view this as sort of a 1-year midcycle pause? Or would you look at this as more of a normal downturn?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- that cancellation activity in our operations are very normal. There's nothing unusual that is happening in that arena. And in terms of sort of where we're at in the cycle. I think that's to be determined. The economic fundamentals are positive and we
componenttext: I -- that cancellation activity in our operations are very normal. There's nothing unusual that is happening in that arena. And in terms of sort of where we're at in the cycle. I think that's to be determined. The economic fundamentals are positive and we see that we're going to track what the demand is. And we think the demand's going to be a good market for 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Casey with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Casey with Wells Fargo.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question on the parts business revenue in the quarter, Ron. You mentioned inventory rebalancing in the channel. Was that broad based or was it concentrated in some of the regions?
componenttext: First question on the parts business revenue in the quarter, Ron. You mentioned inventory rebalancing in the channel. Was that broad based or was it concentrated in some of the regions?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that was general across the body -- body.
componenttext: No, I think that was general across the body -- body.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the margin question, somebody asked earlier, if you compare the margin in the quarter with the run rate of the first 3 quarters, which was very strong, the margin in the quarter went down roughly a couple of 100 basis points. Is that all
componenttext: Okay. And then on the margin question, somebody asked earlier, if you compare the margin in the quarter with the run rate of the first 3 quarters, which was very strong, the margin in the quarter went down roughly a couple of 100 basis points. Is that all seasonality? Or was there an impact from this rebalancing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's obviously, some operating leverage effects in there, and that probably reflects more of the mix of parts that were being distributed during the quarter.
componenttext: I think there's obviously, some operating leverage effects in there, and that probably reflects more of the mix of parts that were being distributed during the quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in truck, I was just hoping a little bit more clarity to one of Jerry's question. Could you talk about what you saw in European truck in terms of the order activity in Q4? Was it as strong a growth as you saw in the first few quarters? Or i
componenttext: Okay. And then in truck, I was just hoping a little bit more clarity to one of Jerry's question. Could you talk about what you saw in European truck in terms of the order activity in Q4? Was it as strong a growth as you saw in the first few quarters? Or is it kind of moderating in line with your outlook there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's steady. And I'd say in line with our outlook. Yes, I think that's a good way to say it.
componenttext: I think it's steady. And I'd say in line with our outlook. Yes, I think that's a good way to say it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the -- in the U.S. and Canada, you had some order volatility toward the end of the year. November, weak; December, better. Did you see that December better kind of continuing into January? Or are we into a little bit of a seasonal there?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the -- in the U.S. and Canada, you had some order volatility toward the end of the year. November, weak; December, better. Did you see that December better kind of continuing into January? Or are we into a little bit of a seasonal there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think most of the ups and downs are just timing of when some of the larger fleet orders appear in the order board. So I think as I said, large fleets are planning buys and their buys are generally pretty consistent with what we saw for deliveries
componenttext: Well, I think most of the ups and downs are just timing of when some of the larger fleet orders appear in the order board. So I think as I said, large fleets are planning buys and their buys are generally pretty consistent with what we saw for deliveries in 2015.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with Bank of Montréal.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We keep dancing around this question, I just wondered if you can spend a couple of minutes giving us a little more of comprehensive list of -- underneath the volume numbers, which you obviously, give us for the industry. Can you just give us a couple of t
componenttext: We keep dancing around this question, I just wondered if you can spend a couple of minutes giving us a little more of comprehensive list of -- underneath the volume numbers, which you obviously, give us for the industry. Can you just give us a couple of the bigger factors. You talked about mix and parts being better. But some of the bigger factors that are going to drive profitability, pricing, under absorption, any luck manufacturing, efficiency improvements, people reductions, mix between U.S. and Europe. Just a couple of the bigger ones to help us get a feel for what some of the levers are you have inside to control the margins.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you just go down the list, I think pricing reflects good markets. And so we have great products to offer the market. So we feel good that our products demand a fair price in the marketplace. Costs, I think there's probably a little bit of
componenttext: Well, I think if you just go down the list, I think pricing reflects good markets. And so we have great products to offer the market. So we feel good that our products demand a fair price in the marketplace. Costs, I think there's probably a little bit of downward momentum on prices with commodity cost reductions. So that's a bit of a benefit. But everybody's getting that same benefit in the industry. Our factories and businesses around the world are a great job of managing the cost structure and our purchasing groups around the world, a great job of procuring and working closely with our suppliers. We have a great supply base that provides us timely deliveries, quality parts. So we work closely with them to make sure that we can support our business and our factories can operate efficiently. And so all of the factors as we talked about R&D for next year, we'll see it. We're projecting a little bit of an uptick, that R&D spending will occur pretty ratably during the course of the year. We manage our SG&A closely. We're thinking SG&A for next year will be comparable to our 2015 levels and that those amounts will be pretty comparable quarter-to-quarter. So as we look at next year, we feel good about the prospects and being able to continue to manage in a very prudent, cost-effective way.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then on the -- have you shared at all kind of a medium or longer-term view on medium duty market share? I know you've had a big new product push for the last couple of years and it seems to be working.
componenttext: That's great. And then on the -- have you shared at all kind of a medium or longer-term view on medium duty market share? I know you've had a big new product push for the last couple of years and it seems to be working.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a great medium duty product and more and more of our dealers are becoming engaged in the medium duty business. And I think we're seeing the benefits of that over time in North America. We have got great products in Europe. As I mentioned, with the
componenttext: We have a great medium duty product and more and more of our dealers are becoming engaged in the medium duty business. And I think we're seeing the benefits of that over time in North America. We have got great products in Europe. As I mentioned, with the increase in share, we did get to a record level of medium duty recoveries last year. And we'll continue to invest in our product, to continue to make enhancements and look forward to continuing to have opportunity to grow that business going forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So there's no number on where you could be, 5 or 10 years from now?
componenttext: All right. So there's no number on where you could be, 5 or 10 years from now?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- we obviously, can continue to push the number [indiscernible]. We're 27% share of the heavy-duty market, 17% of the medium duty market in North America. So there's a lot of upside for us.
componenttext: No, I don't -- we obviously, can continue to push the number [indiscernible]. We're 27% share of the heavy-duty market, 17% of the medium duty market in North America. So there's a lot of upside for us.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Robinson with Susquehanna financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Robinson with Susquehanna financial.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you guys have managed your inventories well in U.S. and Canada. But just looking at retail sales and builds at your peers, one of them has grown substantially. The industry is up substantially. I was just wondering whether you think you can hold pr
componenttext: I know you guys have managed your inventories well in U.S. and Canada. But just looking at retail sales and builds at your peers, one of them has grown substantially. The industry is up substantially. I was just wondering whether you think you can hold pricing given the dynamics in the U.S. and Canada.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing price is pretty stable in the U.S. and Canadian market as we progressed to the first parts of the year. So we expect that, that will continue.
componenttext: We're seeing price is pretty stable in the U.S. and Canadian market as we progressed to the first parts of the year. So we expect that, that will continue.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just a clarification on the parts outlook, can you just go through that by region?
componenttext: That's great. And then just a clarification on the parts outlook, can you just go through that by region?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's our expedition really in both regions. Some level of growth in the 3% to 5% range growth for both North America and Europe. Obviously, we're starting to grow our business in Brazil. And so that's our overall perspective.
componenttext: I think that's our expedition really in both regions. Some level of growth in the 3% to 5% range growth for both North America and Europe. Obviously, we're starting to grow our business in Brazil. And so that's our overall perspective.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when we think about your parts margin outlook going into 2016, should we expect the mix that impacted 4Q to continue to be a headwind? Or is that something that largely corrects itself with inventory rebalancing and we sort of go back to the lev
componenttext: Okay. And when we think about your parts margin outlook going into 2016, should we expect the mix that impacted 4Q to continue to be a headwind? Or is that something that largely corrects itself with inventory rebalancing and we sort of go back to the levels of the first 9 months of 2016?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our margin expectations for next year will be comparable to 2015.
componenttext: Well, I think our margin expectations for next year will be comparable to 2015.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you getting a benefit for the MX-13 for your parts business yet, in the U.S.?
componenttext: Okay. And are you getting a benefit for the MX-13 for your parts business yet, in the U.S.?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Absolutely. We've got 105,000 engines that we've produced out of our Columbus factory. And we're seeing that engine business, it's still early days from a parts perspective, but that will continue to be a positive factor in our parts business for ye
componenttext: Sure. Absolutely. We've got 105,000 engines that we've produced out of our Columbus factory. And we're seeing that engine business, it's still early days from a parts perspective, but that will continue to be a positive factor in our parts business for years to come.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with ISI.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I missed it, production for the full-year of '16, North America and Europe, I know you gave us the first quarter, sequentially. But what's the full-year assumption?
componenttext: Maybe I missed it, production for the full-year of '16, North America and Europe, I know you gave us the first quarter, sequentially. But what's the full-year assumption?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have -- provide that level of detail. But you can look at the market size estimates and I think get a pretty good number.
componenttext: We don't have -- provide that level of detail. But you can look at the market size estimates and I think get a pretty good number.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your production versus those industry forecast, you'd say are very much in line?
componenttext: So your production versus those industry forecast, you'd say are very much in line?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, I know we're asking the same question again. But over the last 30 years, you had 8 years of revenue declines and 7 of them, gross margins go down. So is there something about the currency benefit, North America buying from Europe. But obviously,
componenttext: So again, I know we're asking the same question again. But over the last 30 years, you had 8 years of revenue declines and 7 of them, gross margins go down. So is there something about the currency benefit, North America buying from Europe. But obviously, North America is down more than Europe is in '16. So that one fully explain it. Can you help us more on price cost? This is obviously, as history would tell you, free to be forecasting flat gross margins is abnormal. So with a little more specificity, can you help us understand where is the difference between your history that down volume equals flat gross margin? And I know the parts is helpful, but at 17% of the business, it's not that large. So again, it's an important issue for all of us, so we appreciate the detail.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's all the factors that we talked about. I mean, its the cost management aspects, the favorable potential movement from commodity cost movements. So it's just all the elements of our total margin picture play into that. And there's no one individu
componenttext: Sure. It's all the factors that we talked about. I mean, its the cost management aspects, the favorable potential movement from commodity cost movements. So it's just all the elements of our total margin picture play into that. And there's no one individual item that I can point to, that's the difference.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A counter argument of parts being bigger is today, you're more vertically integrated in North America. So thus, following decline will be more painful than prior down cycles. I mean, I know it's not a big number, but there's something about heavy expendit
componenttext: A counter argument of parts being bigger is today, you're more vertically integrated in North America. So thus, following decline will be more painful than prior down cycles. I mean, I know it's not a big number, but there's something about heavy expenditures, building out Brazil, now with the market that weak, there's some easy retrenchment or recouping of levels of losses in Brazil. We're just trying to flush out why are you comfortable guiding flat gross margins.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have anything else to add, David. Thank you.
componenttext: Do you have anything else to add, David. Thank you.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Frohnapple with Longbow Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up to Joles question, you talked about medium duty market share. Can you just provide any granularity in what you're seeing in the underlying medium duty market in North American and your oulook for that market this year?
componenttext: As a follow-up to Joles question, you talked about medium duty market share. Can you just provide any granularity in what you're seeing in the underlying medium duty market in North American and your oulook for that market this year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would think that the medium duty market I think last year was 80,000 units or so. And I think we're thinking in the 65,000, 75,000 range for 2016.
componenttext: I would think that the medium duty market I think last year was 80,000 units or so. And I think we're thinking in the 65,000, 75,000 range for 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just what would be driving that decline that you guys are looking for?
componenttext: Okay. And just what would be driving that decline that you guys are looking for?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, the medium duty business at PACCAR is being influenced significantly by the level of construction activity. I mean, we put a lot of medium duty trucks into the construction market and that's been strong and as a result, our deliveries into that mark
componenttext: Neil, the medium duty business at PACCAR is being influenced significantly by the level of construction activity. I mean, we put a lot of medium duty trucks into the construction market and that's been strong and as a result, our deliveries into that market have been strong and we would expect that to continue at good strong levels in 2016. We've also introduced some new product, the Cabover products at Kenworth and Peterbilt are both becoming more and more of our dealers are stocking and selling those trucks and that's a net contribution to our medium duty production as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up to used truck pricing in North America. What are you seeing with regard to used truck inventory levels in the channel? Currently are they a bit high? And would you expect them to normalize at some point in this year?
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up to used truck pricing in North America. What are you seeing with regard to used truck inventory levels in the channel? Currently are they a bit high? And would you expect them to normalize at some point in this year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you struck inventory levels for PACCAR are very normal. Yes, we're -- have a pretty level of used trucks and we expect that to sort of stay as we look at lease returns, et cetera, as we progress through the year. We should be able to keep th
componenttext: Well, I think you struck inventory levels for PACCAR are very normal. Yes, we're -- have a pretty level of used trucks and we expect that to sort of stay as we look at lease returns, et cetera, as we progress through the year. We should be able to keep that at very normal levels throughout the year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the Europe delivery volumes last quarter and what you're looking for in the first quarter. It seems like it would be at a higher rate for the market than where the 15% share is or so. So could you talk about whether there's an inventory build effo
componenttext: Just on the Europe delivery volumes last quarter and what you're looking for in the first quarter. It seems like it would be at a higher rate for the market than where the 15% share is or so. So could you talk about whether there's an inventory build effort right now into the year. Or are there opportunities where you think there's an increase in market share in 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as I have -- we talked about earlier on market share, we have a long tradition of building that share and our teams have done a great job of getting the products in place -- great products in place with a really industry-leading fuel efficiency. An
componenttext: Again, as I have -- we talked about earlier on market share, we have a long tradition of building that share and our teams have done a great job of getting the products in place -- great products in place with a really industry-leading fuel efficiency. And so we continue to target growing our share in the various markets. And there's inventory levels throughout the channel dealer inventories in Europe are in great shape. And so there's no real inventory buildup or reduction. It's pretty steady.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last one I guess on the share repurchase, it looks like a little bit faster pace into the end of the year than where you had been previously. Any reason that, that was maybe abnormal? Or is that kind of a level that you anticipated and you
componenttext: Okay. And just last one I guess on the share repurchase, it looks like a little bit faster pace into the end of the year than where you had been previously. Any reason that, that was maybe abnormal? Or is that kind of a level that you anticipated and you would only need another authorization to keep going at that level?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, as we said in our press release, I think that the shares are are attractive option at the current pricing level. And so we expect we'll continue to do some share repurchases during the course of 2016 as we do in many years.
componenttext: Yes, obviously, as we said in our press release, I think that the shares are are attractive option at the current pricing level. And so we expect we'll continue to do some share repurchases during the course of 2016 as we do in many years.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Uhlman with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Uhlman with Cleveland Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could dig in to the finance business. Your aspirations for 2016, how you expect that business to unfold. And then within there, the leasing business. Maybe we can talk about some of the key operating trends that you follow? What have
componenttext: I was wondering if we could dig in to the finance business. Your aspirations for 2016, how you expect that business to unfold. And then within there, the leasing business. Maybe we can talk about some of the key operating trends that you follow? What have you been seeing in the business and how you're thinking about for 2016?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that as we look at our portfolio and our asset base, I think the earning asset -- average earning assets that we'll have for 2016 would be fairly comparable to our 2015 levels, which were really at record levels. And the leasing business has
componenttext: Yes, I think that as we look at our portfolio and our asset base, I think the earning asset -- average earning assets that we'll have for 2016 would be fairly comparable to our 2015 levels, which were really at record levels. And the leasing business has done very well over a long period of time, celebrating their 35th anniversary in 2015. They continue to work very closely with our dealers and our customers to continue to grow that business at the end of the year with a record level of units in the fleet. And we continue to look for opportunities to expand our business in Europe. And during 2015, we launched our PacLease business in Australia. So we continue to look for ways to have leasing make a very valuable contribution to the overall company results.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Could you talk to -- it's not a big expense for you. But could you talk your pension expense expectations for 2016.
componenttext: Okay. Could you talk to -- it's not a big expense for you. But could you talk your pension expense expectations for 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there'll be very comparable to -- it's a pretty steady level. Obviously, it gets impacted by the level of employment, discount rates et cetera. So I think we'll see may be some benefit from a slightly higher discount rate that will benefit expense
componenttext: I think there'll be very comparable to -- it's a pretty steady level. Obviously, it gets impacted by the level of employment, discount rates et cetera. So I think we'll see may be some benefit from a slightly higher discount rate that will benefit expense a little bit in 2016 for North America.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Samir Sameer Rathod with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Samir Sameer Rathod with Macquarie.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There seems to be a lot of press recently an autonomous vehicles from large tech companies and it seems like their moving revelation forwards in various states. And if you look at it objectively, the technology is getting better. The miles driven autonomo
componenttext: There seems to be a lot of press recently an autonomous vehicles from large tech companies and it seems like their moving revelation forwards in various states. And if you look at it objectively, the technology is getting better. The miles driven autonomous has grown exponentially. How does PACCAR think about this? What steps are you guys taking today for a potential market in the future on the truck side? And generally, how do you see this as evolving?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So all of our truck divisions and our engineering teams around the world are involved in evaluating all the technologies that can benefit our customers, including the technologies that will support autonomous driving. We've demonstrated autonomous vehicle
componenttext: So all of our truck divisions and our engineering teams around the world are involved in evaluating all the technologies that can benefit our customers, including the technologies that will support autonomous driving. We've demonstrated autonomous vehicles at various exhibitions. In North America, our team in Europe is also demonstrated their autonomous capabilities with platooning activities, working with government and educational institution. So a lot of work in that area, working closely with suppliers who have the technologies that can support that activity. So it's an ongoing activity. I think we're several years away from seeing that in the truck business. But we're right in the forefront of all the developments that are going on in that arena.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions have been asked on the margins and the gross margins in your core markets. I'd like to go in a different direction and talk about some of the emerging and expanding markets. That was a big highlight of an Analyst Meeting that you had ju
componenttext: A lot of questions have been asked on the margins and the gross margins in your core markets. I'd like to go in a different direction and talk about some of the emerging and expanding markets. That was a big highlight of an Analyst Meeting that you had just a little bit ago and you were talking about your plans in Russia and your plans in Brazil. These markets are obviously, very weak right now. Wouldn't you think that this a very good time strategically moving in and make investments in these markets. I guess 2 questions. Number one, how are you doing in the various emerging markets? And what are your forecasts for those areas? And of the CapEx that you're spending, how much of that is dedicated to emerging market investment right now?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, Brazil, we've made a significant investment in our new plant operations, the products that we've launched and are launching. In the market, we're excited about the prospects for Brazil and the rest of South America as we go forward. Our t
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, Brazil, we've made a significant investment in our new plant operations, the products that we've launched and are launching. In the market, we're excited about the prospects for Brazil and the rest of South America as we go forward. Our teams are doing a great job. We have a great dealer representation that is representing the DAF product in the Brazilian market. We had the opportunity to increase our production and increase our penetration. We had excellent showing at the [indiscernible] truck show in November at Sao Paolo. So our team enters 2016 with a lot of positive momentum in a challenging market. In Russia, the DAF organization there has done a good job over the last years of increasing the number of locations representing the DAF product. And when the economy improves in Russia, we'll be able to grow our deliveries in that particular region. If you look at Asia, still an area of opportunity for our company. We continue to evaluate ways that we can participate greater. We have great presence in India and China with our purchasing activities, our technical office in Pune, India that supports our information technology and engineering activities. So we're very cognizant of what's going on in those markets and continue to look for opportunities to play a bigger part. As we look forward, we just invested in Brazil with the launch of the CF, DAF CF products so expanding the product offerings. we've -- we're now assembling the MX engine in our DAF Brazil factory. So we'll continue to make investments and expanding the product offerings and improving the productivity and efficiency and the capacity of our operations in these markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just following up on that. You did about 16,000 units of what I would call noncore markets last year. This number is small. But you gave a forecast for North America, you gave a forecast for Europe. How should we think about this noncore markets
componenttext: Okay. And just following up on that. You did about 16,000 units of what I would call noncore markets last year. This number is small. But you gave a forecast for North America, you gave a forecast for Europe. How should we think about this noncore markets number?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relatively flat 2016 compared to 2015, certainly, that would be the case in South America, somewhere in the range of 70,000 to 80,000 units heavy-duty in the whole region.
componenttext: Relatively flat 2016 compared to 2015, certainly, that would be the case in South America, somewhere in the range of 70,000 to 80,000 units heavy-duty in the whole region.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would. I would think -- agree, that's a good estimate for next year.
componenttext: Yes, I would. I would think -- agree, that's a good estimate for next year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on the MX-11. Can you give us your thoughts on what kind of [indiscernible] you expect now that it's launched for 2016? And perhaps more broadly, what you expect to see PACCAR engines penetration rate in the overall Class 8 market in 2016?
componenttext: I'm curious on the MX-11. Can you give us your thoughts on what kind of [indiscernible] you expect now that it's launched for 2016? And perhaps more broadly, what you expect to see PACCAR engines penetration rate in the overall Class 8 market in 2016?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the MX-11, we think that will be very well-received -- it has been very well-received in Europe. We think that as customers get more exposed to it and accustomed to its capability that it will become a greater portion of our engine build North Ameri
componenttext: Well, the MX-11, we think that will be very well-received -- it has been very well-received in Europe. We think that as customers get more exposed to it and accustomed to its capability that it will become a greater portion of our engine build North America. We continue to ratchet up our MX engine penetration in Kenworth and Peterbilt products, averaging about 40% in the year, 42% in the fourth quarter. The MX-11 will help move that further forward and we see in the near term, next year or 2 getting that's up closer to the 50% range. And as we look at the capability of our engines in -- currently and in the coming years, it'll meet roughly 80%, 85% of what customers need to do their work. And we continue to get more and more of our customers starting to take some MX's to really test them in their fleet. And typically, after customers have had that chance to have that test, and they see the great performance of those engines, the great fuel efficiency, more and more those are converting their business to the MX engine. So it will continue to progress over the next years.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and if anyone has an objection, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings,
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and if anyone has an objection, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President a
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Vice President, Controller. 
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results.
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken, and good morning. Thanks to PACCAR's 23,000 employees around the world. 2015 was an outstanding year for the company with many records established. PACCAR achieved record revenues of $19.1 billion and record net income of $1.6 billion, and af
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken, and good morning. Thanks to PACCAR's 23,000 employees around the world. 2015 was an outstanding year for the company with many records established. PACCAR achieved record revenues of $19.1 billion and record net income of $1.6 billion, and after-tax return on revenues of 8.4%. Net income increased 18% versus the prior year. 2015 was PACCAR's 77th consecutive year of earning on net income. These excellent results reflect the strongest North American heavy truck market since 2006 and the highest European heavy truck market since 2008. 
In addition, PACCAR Parts earned record pretax income and PACCAR Financial Services achieved another strong profit year. PACCAR celebrated several important milestones in our 110th anniversary year. These included the delivery of DAF's 1 millionth truck, the production of the 100,000 engine in our Mississippi Engine factory and 35th anniversary celebrations at Peterbilt's Denton Texas factory and at PACCAR Leasing. During the year, PACCAR continued investing in premium quality products and services in our core markets, and expanding our presence in emerging markets to provide the foundation for future growth. 
PACCAR's fourth quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and quarterly net income was $347 million, a strong 8.8% after-tax return on revenues. During the quarter, European truck deliveries increased, partially offsetting reduced North American truck deliveries. The strong contribution of all company segments enables PACCAR to attain the highest operating margins in our industry. PACCAR declared cash dividends of $2.30 per share last year, a 25% increase compared to 2014 and the highest total dividend in company history.
The regular quarterly dividend was raised by 9% during the year. PACCAR's total dividends in 2015 provided a yield of over 4%, which is in the top 100 companies in the S&P 500. During 2015, PACCAR repurchased 3.8 million shares of its stock for $202 million. PACCAR delivered 35,400 trucks during the fourth quarter in line with expectations. Vehicle deliveries, and truck and other margins in the first quarter this year are projected to be comparable to the fourth quarter. Peterbilt and Kenworth achieved a good market share of 27.4% in the U.S. and Canada heavy duty truck market in 2015. Class 8 truck industry retail sales totaled 278,000 units for the year. 
Peterbilt and Kenworth also achieved a record 17.4% share of the U.S. and Canadian medium duty truck market last year, resulting in a record 27,300 medium duty truck deliveries for PACCAR. 2016 will be another good year for the U.S. and Canadian Class 8 industry truck market with retail sales estimated to be in a range of 230,000 to 260,000 units. Additional good news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth dealer inventories are in great shape entering this year.
DAF increased its market share to 14.6% in the European above 16-tonne truck market last year compared to 13.8% in 2014. The market was a strong 269,000 units in 2015. 
Looking at this year, we anticipate that the European above 16-tonne truck market has the potential to expand further and be in a range of 260,000 to 290,000 vehicles. Economic growth in Europe is expected to increase this year to 1.7% with more than 2% growth anticipated in the U.K., DAF's largest market. 
PACCAR Parts generated record pretax profit of $556 million and strong revenues of $3.1 billion in 2015. The excellent results were driven by strong freight tonnage, high fleet utilization and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts. During the year, PACCAR Parts set records for parts deliveries to fleets, online part sales and TRP part sales for all makes of trucks and trailers. For the fourth quarter, PACCAR Parts achieved revenues of $750 million and pretax income of $126 million. 
Our expectation for 2016 is that parts and revenues -- is that parts revenues, excluding the effects of currency movements could increase 3% to 5%. 
PACCAR Financial Services revenues were $293 million in the fourth quarter and pretax income was $90 million. The good results benefited from continuing strong portfolio performance. PACCAR leasing ended the year with a record 39,000 units in its full service lease portfolio. For the full year, PACCAR Financial Services earned pretax income of $363 million.
At this point, I'm going to have Michael Barkley address the effects of currency movements on our segment operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the truck segment, the quarter-over-quarter comparison has us -- the impact of currency was $200 million on revenue and for the full year, the impact was $940 million on revenue. The profit impact was minimal given that we have a large amount of mater
componenttext:
For the truck segment, the quarter-over-quarter comparison has us -- the impact of currency was $200 million on revenue and for the full year, the impact was $940 million on revenue. The profit impact was minimal given that we have a large amount of material coming for our engines into our Columbus Engine factory from the Eurozone. 
For parts. The quarterly impact on revenue was $38 million and for the full year was $193 million. Impact on profit was $4 million and for the quarter and -- $34 million for the full year. For Financial Services, the impact on revenue was $17 million and the impact for the full year was $79 million. And the impact on profit for Financial Services was $5 million. For the quarter and for the full year, it was $22 million.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. As we look at next year, PACCAR's projected research and development spending of $240 million to $270 million and capital expenditures of $325 million to $375 million will expand Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF product offerings, enhance t
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. As we look at next year, PACCAR's projected research and development spending of $240 million to $270 million and capital expenditures of $325 million to $375 million will expand Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF product offerings, enhance the PACCAR engine range and increase the capacity and operating efficiency of our factories and distribution centers. 
As the company begins its 111th year, we are in an excellent position to lead the industry with the highest quality products and services. 
Thank you, and I'd be pleased to answer your questions.
