componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment a bit on inventory, I guess, broadly in the channel. You mentioned there in your prepared remarks that you think Peterbilt and Kenworth have -- are in good shape when it comes to retail inventory. I was just wondering if you guys think that PACCAR was maybe more nimble than some of your competitors when it comes to responding to the recent downturn in orders, because obviously, a lot of folks have been talking about the buildup of inventory out there in the channel. So if you guys have, I guess low inventory, that would imply that most of the inventory concerns are being felt by other truck companies. Is that accurate?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't really comment on the nimbleness of our competitors. But I know that we monitor our business very closely and manage it to balance the delivery of trucks with the demand that's in the market. I would say that based on what we know, we have 45
componenttext: Yes, I can't really comment on the nimbleness of our competitors. But I know that we monitor our business very closely and manage it to balance the delivery of trucks with the demand that's in the market. I would say that based on what we know, we have 45, 50 days worth of inventory in the channel. And I think the industry is closer to a 90-day measure. So I'd say we -- as I say, we're in great shape in terms of where we're at starting the 2016 year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. That's good to hear. I was wondering, I guess, also if you could maybe make a couple of comments here on pricing. Obviously, if you look at just pure truck revenue and divide it by the number of units sold, it looks like there was a prett
componenttext: Okay. Very good. That's good to hear. I was wondering, I guess, also if you could maybe make a couple of comments here on pricing. Obviously, if you look at just pure truck revenue and divide it by the number of units sold, it looks like there was a pretty material degradation in sequential terms. But obviously, you've got some ForEx in there, you've got presumably some mix maybe toward medium-duty. I was just wondering if you could maybe help us interpret that sequential decline and how much is, I guess, "real pricing?"

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, the margin performance for the quarter and the year were excellent. We expect that, as we mentioned, margins in the first quarter to be comparable to what we saw in the fourth quarter. Almost all of the per unit degradation is exchange rel
componenttext: Yes, obviously, the margin performance for the quarter and the year were excellent. We expect that, as we mentioned, margins in the first quarter to be comparable to what we saw in the fourth quarter. Almost all of the per unit degradation is exchange related. So that's just the effects of translating currencies around the world into the U.S. dollar.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering what you're seeing in terms of used truck pricing and how that's influencing your forecast of demand for 2016 on new sales at this point? I think last quarter, it didn't sound like it was much of an issue, but wondering if anything has really ch
componenttext: Wondering what you're seeing in terms of used truck pricing and how that's influencing your forecast of demand for 2016 on new sales at this point? I think last quarter, it didn't sound like it was much of an issue, but wondering if anything has really changed there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're seeing is there are more used trucks coming into the market, and that's dampening used truck prices a bit. But the great news is that the Kenworth and Peterbilt products continue to earn a premium relative to the competition. And so we'
componenttext: I think what we're seeing is there are more used trucks coming into the market, and that's dampening used truck prices a bit. But the great news is that the Kenworth and Peterbilt products continue to earn a premium relative to the competition. And so we're very involved with selling used trucks. Last year as a company, we sold about 9,000 trucks globally, and we'll do that again this year. So we'll use that as a tool to be able to support new truck business and our finance operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think the margins have favored North America over Europe, based on volumes and the Euro 6 program over the last year or so. Do you anticipate that in 2016, the margin is going to be in balance again between the 2 regions at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And I think the margins have favored North America over Europe, based on volumes and the Euro 6 program over the last year or so. Do you anticipate that in 2016, the margin is going to be in balance again between the 2 regions at this point?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would think the margin, as we said, we expect it to be comparable to last year. And I think that would -- on a market basis, I think that would be true as well.
componenttext: I would think the margin, as we said, we expect it to be comparable to last year. And I think that would -- on a market basis, I think that would be true as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So still, in other words, favoring North America over Europe, it sounds like then?
componenttext: So still, in other words, favoring North America over Europe, it sounds like then?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase with Morgan Stanley.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ron, my first question is around your 1Q production outlook. I know you guys had flattish Q-on-Q, but what are the thoughts on U.S. and Canada versus Europe? Do you also expect like a flattish outcome for both of the regions?
componenttext: So Ron, my first question is around your 1Q production outlook. I know you guys had flattish Q-on-Q, but what are the thoughts on U.S. and Canada versus Europe? Do you also expect like a flattish outcome for both of the regions?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that North America is going to be up in the 10% to 15% range, and Europe will be down in that kind of range just because of work days and production, beta production levels in each of the markets.
componenttext: I think that North America is going to be up in the 10% to 15% range, and Europe will be down in that kind of range just because of work days and production, beta production levels in each of the markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. My second question is just, what are you guys seeing or heard from U.S. customers with respect to the MX-11 launch so far?
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. My second question is just, what are you guys seeing or heard from U.S. customers with respect to the MX-11 launch so far?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just -- we're just getting those into the field. The customers who have had the test trucks that have been running in the market, we have hundreds of thousands of test miles on those trucks, and the feedback from those customers has just been -
componenttext: Well, it's just -- we're just getting those into the field. The customers who have had the test trucks that have been running in the market, we have hundreds of thousands of test miles on those trucks, and the feedback from those customers has just been -- has been excellent. So the MX-11 has been in the European market now for 2 years with great response, it's now 25% of the production in our European operation. So we're excited to offer that and think that will be a nice enhancement to meet customer needs, both in the vocational and regional haul applications.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, I wonder if you can talk about your bookings in Europe in the quarter. Did your lead times widen out? It sounds like you're taking the build rate higher, if I'm not mistaken, in the first quarter, given the number of working days. Is that right? Can
componenttext: Ron, I wonder if you can talk about your bookings in Europe in the quarter. Did your lead times widen out? It sounds like you're taking the build rate higher, if I'm not mistaken, in the first quarter, given the number of working days. Is that right? Can you just flesh out for us what you're seeing in that market, please?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you rephrase your question, Jerry?
componenttext: Can you rephrase your question, Jerry?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So can you talk about whether your lead times extended in the fourth quarter? It looks like -- in Europe, it looks like your build rates are moving higher. So I would guess your book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was greater than 1. But I'd apprecia
componenttext: Sure. So can you talk about whether your lead times extended in the fourth quarter? It looks like -- in Europe, it looks like your build rates are moving higher. So I would guess your book-to-bill in the fourth quarter was greater than 1. But I'd appreciate any color there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Order intake during the course of last year really outpaced the build rate in the first parts of the year, and so we were ramping up build rate, and build rates as we start 2016 are comparable to where we ended up last year, fewer workdays and just a
componenttext: Yes. Order intake during the course of last year really outpaced the build rate in the first parts of the year, and so we were ramping up build rate, and build rates as we start 2016 are comparable to where we ended up last year, fewer workdays and just a slight reduction in the average daily count for the first quarter. So it's -- lead times are in excellent shape really in all of our markets as we begin 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, obviously, we'll get the details when the K comes out. But I'm wondering if you could just help us bridge the year-over-year gross margin performance for fourth quarter '15 versus fourth quarter '14 in terms of the contribution of pricing,
componenttext: Okay. And then, obviously, we'll get the details when the K comes out. But I'm wondering if you could just help us bridge the year-over-year gross margin performance for fourth quarter '15 versus fourth quarter '14 in terms of the contribution of pricing, net of material costs. Any pieces that you could help us with would be helpful.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that -- there's a lot of moving pieces in there, Jerry with pricing, cost movement, customer mix, model mix, et cetera. So it's -- that's -- we really don't have that level of granularity here, so.
componenttext: Yes, that -- there's a lot of moving pieces in there, Jerry with pricing, cost movement, customer mix, model mix, et cetera. So it's -- that's -- we really don't have that level of granularity here, so.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the 2016 outlook, for the full year, you mentioned you're looking for a comparable gross margins even though shipments, I think, are expected to be down based on your outlook for North American and European truck markets. Can yo
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the 2016 outlook, for the full year, you mentioned you're looking for a comparable gross margins even though shipments, I think, are expected to be down based on your outlook for North American and European truck markets. Can you talk about what's favorable at the gross margin line that's providing that tailwind despite lower volumes?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our teams, they just do a great job of rigorously managing the cost structure. We obviously work very closely with our suppliers to make sure that we're getting our fair share of commodity cost movements. We have great products. The Kenworth, Peterb
componenttext: Well, our teams, they just do a great job of rigorously managing the cost structure. We obviously work very closely with our suppliers to make sure that we're getting our fair share of commodity cost movements. We have great products. The Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF products are the highest quality and demand a premium price in the market. So as we look at this year, we feel that 2016 will be comparable to our 2015 levels.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about your parts business a little bit? It came in weaker on revenues and significantly weaker on EBIT margins than I was forecasting, and I don't know if I was just setting too high an expectation. Can you just talk about parts in Q4 and what
componenttext: Can we talk about your parts business a little bit? It came in weaker on revenues and significantly weaker on EBIT margins than I was forecasting, and I don't know if I was just setting too high an expectation. Can you just talk about parts in Q4 and what went on there? Did I miss something from a seasonality perspective?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think as we look at the -- Michael talked about the exchange rate effects. And so when you compare the fourth quarter results with the fourth quarter of the prior year, they're essentially the same as last year. It was a very strong fourth quarter l
componenttext: No. I think as we look at the -- Michael talked about the exchange rate effects. And so when you compare the fourth quarter results with the fourth quarter of the prior year, they're essentially the same as last year. It was a very strong fourth quarter last year. There are fewer -- there were fewer new trucks being delivered as well as I think the -- a little bit of rebalancing of inventories in the market. But as we commented, we think parts will continue to grow. As we enter into 2016, our parts team has done a great job with some of the many programs that they've put in place, and we continue to see obviously, growth in the engine parts business as we go forward. So we think there's a continued -- to see positive momentum as we go to 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful on the color. On your outlook for North America down 12% -- U.S. and Canada, down 12%. Most of the industry is forecasting significantly -- a significantly greater decline down back to kind of replacement levels of somewhere around do
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful on the color. On your outlook for North America down 12% -- U.S. and Canada, down 12%. Most of the industry is forecasting significantly -- a significantly greater decline down back to kind of replacement levels of somewhere around down 20%. What are you seeing out there? What are your customers telling you? What are your teams telling you? Where do you think the strength is coming from versus where others are forecasting?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, the on-highway business is supported by strong freight tonnage metrics. There -- they've been pretty flat, but at a very high level. I think the last numbers that came out were like the second highest level on record. So freight activitie
componenttext: Well, obviously, the on-highway business is supported by strong freight tonnage metrics. There -- they've been pretty flat, but at a very high level. I think the last numbers that came out were like the second highest level on record. So freight activities look good. The estimation for growth for next year for North America is 2% to 3% growth. So consumer demand is strong, and so we see a lot of positives that are going to support a good market. If you look at the 230,000 to 260,000 trucks, it could be the second or third best in the last decade. So it's a good market for next year. So we're optimistic about how things will develop. As we've talked to customers, as I think we commented last quarter, customers are ordering -- that have ordered are ordering levels comparable to what they ordered in 2015. I'd say a little bit of the difference is just that their expectations the last year -- the expectations for delivery were they needed them as soon as they could get them. And now they're thinking a little bit -- spreading those deliveries out a little further across the year. So we're seeing positive things overall.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add that Kenworth and Peterbilt are very strong in the vocational segment and construction activity continues to be strong. Forecasted to grow once again for residential housing in 2016. And so the vocational segment for us is performing very
componenttext: And I would add that Kenworth and Peterbilt are very strong in the vocational segment and construction activity continues to be strong. Forecasted to grow once again for residential housing in 2016. And so the vocational segment for us is performing very well, especially with the new products that we're introducing into both Kenworth and Peterbilt.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is that what gives you confidence then in guiding to flattish or comparable margins year-over-year despite a decline in revenue?
componenttext: And is that what gives you confidence then in guiding to flattish or comparable margins year-over-year despite a decline in revenue?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look at the expectations for the year in costs and...
componenttext: Yes. As we look at the expectations for the year in costs and...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our parts mix will grow a little bit and the parts margins are obviously good. We'll continue to operate at a very high level in the parts business, and that should be a net positive for margins as well.
componenttext: Our parts mix will grow a little bit and the parts margins are obviously good. We'll continue to operate at a very high level in the parts business, and that should be a net positive for margins as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Credit Suisse.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, I mean it sounds like you guys are obviously more constructive relative to your peers. But if you look at the industry numbers, cancelation rates have picked up over the past several months. Have you seen any of that? Or have y
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, I mean it sounds like you guys are obviously more constructive relative to your peers. But if you look at the industry numbers, cancelation rates have picked up over the past several months. Have you seen any of that? Or have you been immune to that? And then I guess a broader just cycle question, do you view this as sort of a -- the -- obviously, the level of decline you're expecting this year is less than the industry. But do you view this as sort of a one-year midcycle pause? Or would you look at this more as a normal downturn?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think cancelation activity in our operations are very normal. There's nothing unusual that is happening in that arena. And in terms of sort of where we're at in the cycle, I think that's to be determined. The economic fundamentals are positive, and we s
componenttext: I think cancelation activity in our operations are very normal. There's nothing unusual that is happening in that arena. And in terms of sort of where we're at in the cycle, I think that's to be determined. The economic fundamentals are positive, and we see that we're going to track what the demand is. And we think the demand's going to be a good market for 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Casey with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Casey with Wells Fargo.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question on the parts business revenue in the quarter. Ron, you mentioned inventory rebalancing in the channel. Was that broad based or was it concentrated in some of the regions?
componenttext: First question on the parts business revenue in the quarter. Ron, you mentioned inventory rebalancing in the channel. Was that broad based or was it concentrated in some of the regions?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that was general across the body -- data body.
componenttext: No, I think that was general across the body -- data body.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the margin question somebody asked earlier, if you compare the margin in the quarter with the run rate of the first 3 quarters, which was very strong, the margin in the quarter went down roughly a couple of 100 basis points. Is that all
componenttext: Okay. And then on the margin question somebody asked earlier, if you compare the margin in the quarter with the run rate of the first 3 quarters, which was very strong, the margin in the quarter went down roughly a couple of 100 basis points. Is that all seasonality? Or was there an impact from this rebalancing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's obviously some operating leverage effects in there, and it probably effects -- reflects more of the mix of parts that were being distributed during the quarter.
componenttext: I think there's obviously some operating leverage effects in there, and it probably effects -- reflects more of the mix of parts that were being distributed during the quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in truck, I just was hoping a little bit more clarity to one of Jerry's question. Could you talk about what you saw in European truck in terms of the order activity in Q4? Was it as strong a growth as you saw in the first few quarters? Or i
componenttext: Okay. And then in truck, I just was hoping a little bit more clarity to one of Jerry's question. Could you talk about what you saw in European truck in terms of the order activity in Q4? Was it as strong a growth as you saw in the first few quarters? Or is it kind of moderating in line with your outlook there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's steady. And I'd say in line with our outlook. Yes, I think that's a good way to say it.
componenttext: I think it's steady. And I'd say in line with our outlook. Yes, I think that's a good way to say it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the -- in the U.S. and Canada, you had some order volatility toward the end of the year. November, weak; December, better. Did you see that December better kind of continuing into January? Or are we into a little bit of the seasonal dold
componenttext: Okay. And then on the -- in the U.S. and Canada, you had some order volatility toward the end of the year. November, weak; December, better. Did you see that December better kind of continuing into January? Or are we into a little bit of the seasonal doldrums there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think most of the ups and downs are just timing of when some of the larger fleet orders appear in the order board. So I think as I said, large fleets are planning buys and their buys are generally pretty consistent with what we saw for deliveries
componenttext: Well, I think most of the ups and downs are just timing of when some of the larger fleet orders appear in the order board. So I think as I said, large fleets are planning buys and their buys are generally pretty consistent with what we saw for deliveries in 2015.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with Bank of Montréal.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We keep dancing around this question, I just wondered if you could spend a couple of minutes giving us a little more of a comprehensive list of -- underneath the volume numbers, which you obviously give us for the industry, can you just give us a couple o
componenttext: We keep dancing around this question, I just wondered if you could spend a couple of minutes giving us a little more of a comprehensive list of -- underneath the volume numbers, which you obviously give us for the industry, can you just give us a couple of the bigger factors? You've talked about mix in parts being better. But some of the bigger factors that are going to drive profitability, pricing, underabsorption, any like manufacturing, efficiency improvements, people reductions, mix between U.S. and Europe. Just a couple of the bigger ones to help us get a feel for what some of the levers are you have inside to control the margins.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you just go down the list, I think pricing reflects good markets. And so we have great products to offer the market. So we feel good that our products demand a fair price in the marketplace. Costs, I think there's probably a little bit of
componenttext: Well, I think if you just go down the list, I think pricing reflects good markets. And so we have great products to offer the market. So we feel good that our products demand a fair price in the marketplace. Costs, I think there's probably a little bit of downward momentum on prices, with the commodity cost reductions. So that's a bit of a benefit. But everybody is getting that same benefit in the industry. Our factories and businesses around the world do a great job of managing their cost structure, and our purchasing groups around the world do a great job of procuring and working closely with our suppliers. We have a great supply base that provides us timely deliveries, quality parts. And so we work closely with them to make sure that we can support our business and our factories can operate efficiently. And so all of the factors, as we've talked about, R&D for next year, we'll see a -- we're projecting a little bit of an uptick, that R&D spending will occur pretty ratably during the course of the year. We manage our SG&A closely. We're thinking SG&A for next year will be comparable to our 2015 levels, and that those amounts will be pretty comparable quarter-to-quarter. So as we look at next year, we feel good about the prospects and being able to continue to manage in a very prudent, cost-effective way.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then on -- have you shared at all kind of a medium or longer-term view on medium-duty market share? I know you've had a big new product push for the last couple of years, and it seems to be working.
componenttext: That's great. And then on -- have you shared at all kind of a medium or longer-term view on medium-duty market share? I know you've had a big new product push for the last couple of years, and it seems to be working.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a great medium-duty products, and more and more of our dealers are becoming engaged in the medium-duty business. And I think we're seeing the benefits of that over time in North America. We have great products in Europe. As I mentioned, with the i
componenttext: We have a great medium-duty products, and more and more of our dealers are becoming engaged in the medium-duty business. And I think we're seeing the benefits of that over time in North America. We have great products in Europe. As I mentioned, with the increase in share, we did get to a record level of medium-duty deliveries last year. And we'll continue to invest in our product to continue to make enhancements and look forward to continuing to have opportunity to grow that business going forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So there's no number on where you could be 5 or 10 years from now?
componenttext: All right. So there's no number on where you could be 5 or 10 years from now?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- we obviously could continue to push the number north. We're 27% share of the heavy-duty market, and 17% of the medium-duty market in North America. So there's lots of upside for us.
componenttext: No, I don't -- we obviously could continue to push the number north. We're 27% share of the heavy-duty market, and 17% of the medium-duty market in North America. So there's lots of upside for us.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Robinson with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Robinson with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you guys have managed your inventories well in U.S. and Canada. But just looking at retail sales and builds at your peers, one of them has grown substantially. The industry is up substantially. I was just wondering whether you think you can hold pr
componenttext: I know you guys have managed your inventories well in U.S. and Canada. But just looking at retail sales and builds at your peers, one of them has grown substantially. The industry is up substantially. I was just wondering whether you think you can hold pricing given the dynamics in the U.S. and Canada.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing prices pretty stable in the U.S. and Canadian market as we progressed through the first parts of the year. So we expect that, that will continue.
componenttext: We're seeing prices pretty stable in the U.S. and Canadian market as we progressed through the first parts of the year. So we expect that, that will continue.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just a clarification on the parts outlook, could you just go through that by region?
componenttext: That's great. And then just a clarification on the parts outlook, could you just go through that by region?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's our expectation really in both regions, some level of growth in the 3% to 5% range for both North America and Europe. And obviously we're starting to grow our business in Brazil, and so that's our overall perspective.
componenttext: I think that's our expectation really in both regions, some level of growth in the 3% to 5% range for both North America and Europe. And obviously we're starting to grow our business in Brazil, and so that's our overall perspective.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we think about your parts margin outlook going into 2016, should we expect the mix that impacted 4Q to continue to be a headwind? Or is that something that largely corrects itself with inventory rebalancing and we sort of go back to th
componenttext: Okay. And then when we think about your parts margin outlook going into 2016, should we expect the mix that impacted 4Q to continue to be a headwind? Or is that something that largely corrects itself with inventory rebalancing and we sort of go back to the levels of the first 9 months of 2015?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our margin expectations for next year will be comparable to 2015.
componenttext: Well, I think our margin expectations for next year will be comparable to 2015.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And are you getting a benefit from the MX-13 in your parts business yet, in the U.S.?

componenttext: Sure. Absolutely. We've got 105,000 engines that we've produced out of our Columbus factory. And that -- we're seeing that engine business, it's still early days from a parts perspective, but that will continue to be a positive factor in our parts business for years to come.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, I know we're asking the same question again. But over the last 30 years, you have 8 years of revenue declines, and 7 of them, gross margins go down. So is there something about the currency benefit, North America buying from Europe. But obviousl
componenttext: So again, I know we're asking the same question again. But over the last 30 years, you have 8 years of revenue declines, and 7 of them, gross margins go down. So is there something about the currency benefit, North America buying from Europe. But obviously, North America is down more than Europe is in '16. So that wouldn't fully explain it. Can you help us more on price costs? This is obviously, history would tell you, for you to be forecasting flat gross margins is abnormal. So with a little more specificity, can you help us understand where is the difference between your history that down volumes equals flat gross margins? And I know the parts is helpful, but at 17% of the business, it's not that large. So again, just, it's an important issue for all of us, so we appreciate the detail.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's all of the factors that we talked about. I mean, it's the cost management aspects, the favorable potential movement from commodity cost movements. So it's just all the elements of our total margin picture play into that. And there's no one indi
componenttext: Sure. It's all of the factors that we talked about. I mean, it's the cost management aspects, the favorable potential movement from commodity cost movements. So it's just all the elements of our total margin picture play into that. And there's no one individual item that I can point to and say that's the difference.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A counterargument to parts being bigger is today, you're more vertically integrated in North America. So thus, volume decline would be more painful than prior down cycles. I mean, I know it's not a big number, but is there something about heavy expenditur
componenttext: A counterargument to parts being bigger is today, you're more vertically integrated in North America. So thus, volume decline would be more painful than prior down cycles. I mean, I know it's not a big number, but is there something about heavy expenditures, building out Brazil, now with the market that weak, there's some easy retrenchment or recouping of levels of losses in Brazil? I'm just trying to flush out why you're that comfortable guiding flat gross margins.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's just -- I don't have anything else to add, David. Thank you.
componenttext: That's just -- I don't have anything else to add, David. Thank you.

componenttext: No, I appreciate it. It's just a key issue for everybody.

componenttext: Neil, the medium-duty business at PACCAR is being influenced significantly by the level of construction activity. I mean, we put a lot of medium-duty trucks into the construction market, and so that's been strong and as a result, our deliveries into that market have been strong, and we would expect that to continue at good strong levels in 2016. We've also introduced some new product, the Cabover products in -- at Kenworth and Peterbilt are both beginning to develop good traction. More and more of our dealers are stocking and selling those trucks and that's a net contribution to our medium-duty production as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think used truck inventory levels for PACCAR are very normal. Yes, we're -- we have a pretty level of used trucks and we expect that to sort of stay as we look at lease returns, et cetera. As we progress through the year, we should be able to keep that at very normal levels throughout the year.

componenttext: Again, as we talked about earlier, on market share, we have a long tradition of building that share, and our teams have done a great job of getting the products in place -- great products in place with really industry-leading fuel efficiency. And so we continue to target growing our share of the various markets. And there's inventory levels throughout the channel, dealer inventories in Europe are in great shape. And so there's no real inventory buildup or reduction. It's pretty steady.

componenttext: I was wondering if we could dig into the finance business. Your aspirations for 2016, how you expect that business to unfold. And then within there, the leasing business. Maybe you could talk about some of the key operating trends that you follow. What have you been seeing in the business and how are you thinking about it for 2016?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we look at our portfolio and our asset base, I think the earning asset -- average earning assets that we'll have for 2016 would be fairly comparable to our 2015 levels, which were really at record levels. And the leasing business has done
componenttext: Yes, I think as we look at our portfolio and our asset base, I think the earning asset -- average earning assets that we'll have for 2016 would be fairly comparable to our 2015 levels, which were really at record levels. And the leasing business has done very well over a long period of time, celebrating their 35th anniversary in 2015. They continue to work very closely with our dealers and our customers to continue to grow that business. They ended the year with a record level of units in the fleet. And we continue to look for opportunities to expand our business in Europe. And during 2015, we launched our PacLease business in Australia. So we continue to look for ways to have leasing make a valuable contribution to the overall company results.

componenttext: I think they'll be very comparable to -- it's a pretty steady level. It -- obviously, it gets impacted by the level of employment, discount rates, et cetera. So I think we'll see maybe some benefit from a slightly higher discount rate that will benefit pension expense a little bit in 2016 for North America.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There seems to be a lot of press recently on autonomous vehicles from large tech companies, and it seems like they're moving regulation forward in various states. And if you look at it objectively, the technology is getting better. The miles driven autono
componenttext: There seems to be a lot of press recently on autonomous vehicles from large tech companies, and it seems like they're moving regulation forward in various states. And if you look at it objectively, the technology is getting better. The miles driven autonomously is growing exponentially. How does PACCAR think about this? What steps are you guys taking today for a potential market in the future on the truck side? And generally, how do you see this evolving?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So all of our truck divisions and our engineering teams around the world are involved in evaluating all the technologies that can benefit our customers, including the technologies that will support autonomous driving. We've demonstrated autonomous vehicle
componenttext: So all of our truck divisions and our engineering teams around the world are involved in evaluating all the technologies that can benefit our customers, including the technologies that will support autonomous driving. We've demonstrated autonomous vehicles at various exhibitions in North America. Our team in Europe has also demonstrated their autonomous capabilities with platooning activities, working with government and educational institutions. So a lot of work in that area, working closely with suppliers, who have the technologies that can support that activity. So it's an ongoing activity. I think we're several years away from seeing that in the truck business. But we're right on the forefront of all the developments that are going on in that arena.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions have been asked on the margins and the gross margins in your core markets. I'd like to go in a different direction and talk about some of the emerging and expanding markets. That was a big highlight of an Analyst Meeting you had just a
componenttext: A lot of questions have been asked on the margins and the gross margins in your core markets. I'd like to go in a different direction and talk about some of the emerging and expanding markets. That was a big highlight of an Analyst Meeting you had just a little bit ago, and you were talking about your plans in Russia and your plans in Brazil. These markets are obviously very weak right now. Wouldn't you think that this a very good time strategically to be moving in and making investments in these markets? So, I guess 2 questions. Number one, how are you doing in the various emerging markets? And what are your forecasts for those areas? And then of the CapEx that you're spending, how much of that is dedicated to emerging market investment right now?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, Brazil, we've made a significant investment in our new plant operations, the products that we've launched and are launching in the market. We're excited about the prospects for Brazil and the rest of South America as we go forward. Our te
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, Brazil, we've made a significant investment in our new plant operations, the products that we've launched and are launching in the market. We're excited about the prospects for Brazil and the rest of South America as we go forward. Our teams are doing a great job. We have a great dealer representation that is representing the DAF product in the Brazilian market. We had the opportunity to increase our production and increase our penetration. We had an excellent showing at the Fenatran Truck Show in November in Sao Paolo. So our team enters 2016 with a lot of positive momentum in a challenging market. In Russia, the DAF organization there has done a good job over the last years of increasing the number of locations representing the DAF product. And when the economy improves in Russia, we'll be able to grow our deliveries in that particular region. And if you look at Asia, still an area of opportunity for our company. We continue to evaluate ways that we can participate greater. We have great presence in India and China with our purchasing activities, our technical office in Pune, India that supports our information technology and engineering activities. So we're very cognizant of what's going on in those markets and continue to look for opportunities to play a bigger part. As we look forward, we just invested in Brazil with the launch of the CF, DAF CF product, so expanding the product offerings. We've -- we're now assembling the MX engine in our DAF Brazil factory. So we'll continue to make investments in expanding the product offerings and improving the productivity and efficiency and the capacity of our operations in these markets.

componenttext: Okay. And just following up on that. You did about 16,000 units of what I would call noncore markets last year. This number is small, but you gave a forecast for North America, you gave a forecast for Europe. How should we think about this noncore markets number?

componenttext: Relatively flat 2016 compared to 2015. Certainly, that would be the case in South America, somewhere in the range of 70,000 to 80,000 units, heavy duty, in the whole region.

componenttext: Yes, I would think -- agreed. I think that's a good estimate for next year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious just on the MX-11. Can you give us your thoughts as to what kind of penetration do you expect now that it's launched for 2016? And perhaps more broadly, what you expect to see PACCAR engines' penetration rate in the overall Class 8 market in 2
componenttext: I'm curious just on the MX-11. Can you give us your thoughts as to what kind of penetration do you expect now that it's launched for 2016? And perhaps more broadly, what you expect to see PACCAR engines' penetration rate in the overall Class 8 market in 2016?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the MX-11, we think that will be very well received -- it's been very well received in Europe. We think that as customers get more exposed to it and accustomed to its capability that it will become a greater portion of our engine build in North Amer
componenttext: Well, the MX-11, we think that will be very well received -- it's been very well received in Europe. We think that as customers get more exposed to it and accustomed to its capability that it will become a greater portion of our engine build in North America. We've continued to ratchet up our MX engine penetration in Kenworth and Peterbilt products, averaging around 40% for the year, 42% in the fourth quarter. The MX-11 will help move that further forward. We see in the near term, next year or 2, getting that up closer to the 50% range. And as we look at the capability of our engines in -- currently and in the coming years that it'll meet roughly 80%, 85% of what customers need to do their work. And we continue to get more and more of our customers starting to take some MXs to really test them in their fleet. And typically, after customers have had that chance to have that test, and they see the great performance of those engines, the great fuel efficiency, more and more of those are converting their business to the MX engine. So it will continue to progress over the next years.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hasting
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name as Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning our Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name as Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning our Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and controller. As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media that are on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect the expected results. 
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 m
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 million, an 8.1% after-tax return on revenues. Adjusted net income excludes the $943 million non-recurring charge for their European Commission investigation of all European truck manufacturers. Including the non-recurring charge PACCAR reported a net loss of $595 million in the first quarter. PACCAR achieved excellent Truck, Parts and Other gross margins of 14.9%, helped by the strong European truck market. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. PACCAR delivered 35,300 trucks during the first quarter, in line with our expectations. Deliveries in Europe were over 30% higher than last year's first quarter. Looking ahead, we expect a slight increase in deliveries in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. Second quarter gross margins are projected to be comparable to the strong first quarter margins, reflecting the benefits of DAF, Peterbilt and Kenworth's new truck models, the benefits of steady build rates, good truck markets and continued material cost savings. PACCAR's forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market is a range of 260,000 to 290,000 units, reflecting strong demand and a steady economic outlook. Europe's GDP growth expectations for this year are 2% in the U.K., which is DAF's largest market and 1.5% on the continent. Freight transport activity on German highways in the first quarter was up 4% over the same period last year. Year-to-date, DAF has achieved a record 16.6% share of the heavy-duty market. The economic picture in the U.S. remains positive, with GDP forecast to grow 2.1% this year. The housing and automotive industries create a large amount of freight. Housing starts are projected to grow 11% this year to over $1.2 million and the automotive industry is expected to deliver 17.5 million vehicles, which would be a record. Other positive signals are that the ISM manufacturing index has returned to expansion and manufacturing inventories in the economy appear to be stabilizing. 
We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in the range of 220,000 to 250,000 units this year, the third best in the last decade. The economy's steady growth is supportive of healthy freight levels. The 88 tonnage continued at record levels. Peterbilt and Kenworth's combined retail sales market share of the U.S. Canadian market is 26% year-to-date. Our share of net orders so far this year is strong at 37% as customers appreciate the benefits of Kenworth and Peterbilt's reliable and fuel-efficient trucks and industry-leading resale values. 
PACCAR's Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $720 million compared to $753 million in the same quarter of last year. PACCAR Parts quarterly pretax income was $135 million, an excellent return on revenue of 18.7%. These results were driven by good fleet utilization. The growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. PACCAR Financial Services first quarter pretax income was $80 million compared to $89 million a year ago. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. 
PACCAR's strong balance sheet and positive cash flow have enabled the company to invest $3.3 billion in new products and facilities in the last 5 years. PACCAR's capital spending of $325 million to $375 million this year is targeted at enhanced aftermarket support, manufacturing facilities and new product development. Research and development expenses are estimated to be in the range of $240 million to $260 million. 
PACCAR continues to enhance its leadership position in the global truck market by developing the highest quality products and services in the industry. Thank you. And I'd be pleased to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook.
componenttext: Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of questions. The gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and that relative to what The Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of that was material cost? How muc
componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions. The gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and that relative to what The Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of that was material cost? How much of that was benefits from increasing production? And then I also think last quarter, you alluded to being able to achieve flat gross margins year-on-year. Can you talk about your comfort level with that today versus where we sat last quarter with material costs potentially being a headwind in the back half of the year and with the pricing environment?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, so first quarter, we had excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the ma
componenttext: Sure, so first quarter, we had excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the material cost movement that are purchasing and material teams are providing with our suppliers working closely with them to provide good value for our customers. The products are performing great in the field, so we've seen a good performance in our warranty cost during the quarter. So all the elements, just a good quarter of execution provided the results that we've seen. As we look forward for the full year, margins, I think will still be in that 14.5% to 15% range for the full year at these build rates. So we'll continue to operate at the kind of levels that we saw in the first quarter, I believe.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, can you just also, I'll get back in queue, last quarter, you talked about your inventory levels being at a much healthier rate relative to your peers. Can you just provide an update on that?
componenttext: I'm sorry, can you just also, I'll get back in queue, last quarter, you talked about your inventory levels being at a much healthier rate relative to your peers. Can you just provide an update on that?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the same situation exists. Our inventories are below 60 days in the field, so in great, great position. So what we produce will find its way to the customers' hands.
componenttext: I think the same situation exists. Our inventories are below 60 days in the field, so in great, great position. So what we produce will find its way to the customers' hands.

componenttext: I'd say, pricing is steady in the marketplace and that's what we experienced in the first quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, very good. Then was wondering also if you could comment a little bit on your outlook for areas other than North America and Europe. So Brazil, obviously, but also the rest of South America, Mexico, Australia and the other regions you saw material in
componenttext: Okay, very good. Then was wondering also if you could comment a little bit on your outlook for areas other than North America and Europe. So Brazil, obviously, but also the rest of South America, Mexico, Australia and the other regions you saw material in the trucks into.

componenttextpreview: You first talked about Australia and Mexico. I'd say, the markets there are good, steady and our plans all there also operate very efficiently during the quarter and markets are pretty reasonable. Brazil, the country, is challenging, but we continue to mo
componenttext: You first talked about Australia and Mexico. I'd say, the markets there are good, steady and our plans all there also operate very efficiently during the quarter and markets are pretty reasonable. Brazil, the country, is challenging, but we continue to move forward with our business. Build rates are steady and the team is doing an excellent job of continuing to establish and deepen the footprint of DAF in the marketplace, and we continue to see pretty good activity with respect to the Andean countries in South America with both the Kenworth and DAF brands.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttextpreview: This is Mike on for Ann. I just wanted to get a little bit of color on Financial Services margins, a little bit weaker than expected and if there was any particular reason why that may happen or may continue?
componenttext: This is Mike on for Ann. I just wanted to get a little bit of color on Financial Services margins, a little bit weaker than expected and if there was any particular reason why that may happen or may continue?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and then it dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Fin
componenttext: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and then it dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Financial Services business, we had nice used truck gains. This first quarter this year, those truck games didn't repeat. So it's primarily used trucks, a little bit impact of currency movement but they're primarily the effects of used truck pricing.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of David Leiker of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of David Leiker of Robert W. Baird.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe for David. I was wondering if you could give your European order growth in the quarter, and when I just look at what individual countries are doing, it would seem like DAF in the quarter was over 30% growth is doing quite a bit better than jus
componenttext: This is Joe for David. I was wondering if you could give your European order growth in the quarter, and when I just look at what individual countries are doing, it would seem like DAF in the quarter was over 30% growth is doing quite a bit better than just what the U.K. and Netherlands markets might be doing. So are you gaining market share of countries that might not have been typically DAF countries in the past?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 products that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is now performing excellently and the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the product
componenttext: Yes, I think in most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 products that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is now performing excellently and the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the product is the best it's ever been. And so as time goes on, more and more customers are recognizing that. And when you look at some of the southern markets that have been pretty depressed for quite a few years, those are recovering, and DAF has a strong presence in Central Europe in countries like Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, and many of those is #1 or 2 in those markets. So I think just the combination of all those elements coming together, and DAF achieved 16.6% share for the first quarter which is a record level for them. And so it's really across the continent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and similar conversation that pertain to the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retailers are closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations, maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned re
componenttext: Okay, and similar conversation that pertain to the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retailers are closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations, maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned relative to the other OEMs or is it similar to that new product is driving the gains?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine, penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptance of
componenttext: I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine, penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptance of the PACCAR engine in the product. And so just the continued appreciation of the product, the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the current products is excellent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher of UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on the cost savings. I know you mentioned continuing material cost savings expected in Q2. I guess, given the rise we have seen in commodity prices, how is that baked into your expectations of the 14.5% to 16% [ph] margins for the
componenttext: I just want to follow up on the cost savings. I know you mentioned continuing material cost savings expected in Q2. I guess, given the rise we have seen in commodity prices, how is that baked into your expectations of the 14.5% to 16% [ph] margins for the full year and I guess particularly in the second half.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks and material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that migh
componenttext: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks and material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that might play into our costs and pricing.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think you can get pricing benefits on top of the higher costs as the smoothing sort of works itself through over the course of the year?
componenttext: Do you think you can get pricing benefits on top of the higher costs as the smoothing sort of works itself through over the course of the year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: They typically do. It may not be exactly the same time but typically those things find their way into the marketplace.
componenttext: They typically do. It may not be exactly the same time but typically those things find their way into the marketplace.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, just on the FINCO earnings, I wanted to clarify what it was within the interest and other much of the higher cost, I believe that was the biggest pricing is are talking about earlier. Do you think the 10% year-on-year decline in profit this going to
componenttext: Okay, just on the FINCO earnings, I wanted to clarify what it was within the interest and other much of the higher cost, I believe that was the biggest pricing is are talking about earlier. Do you think the 10% year-on-year decline in profit this going to be better or worse or the same as what the full year could be?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of it will depend on how the used truck market develops in the coming quarters. And so we'll see how that develops. In terms of the interest in other, just part of that is just the larger portfolio. The asset, the average earning assets in the first
componenttext: A lot of it will depend on how the used truck market develops in the coming quarters. And so we'll see how that develops. In terms of the interest in other, just part of that is just the larger portfolio. The asset, the average earning assets in the first quarter this year are higher and so that just reflects. We have higher assets and higher debt levels that go with that and that just reflects the higher cost to go with it.

You guys have spoken about once the market gets good enough, you might be at a point where you get to make a margin on the new emissions components. Are we at that point yet? componenttext: I wish that were the case, Jerry, but pricing is pretty steady in terms of this year versus what we saw last year during the course of the year. Market is good, so pricing environment has been, as I said, pretty steady without much up or down movement.

componenttext: From a customer standpoint, the actual retail sales and the dealer level were up a bit during the quarter. What we saw was that the dealers rebalancing their inventories to sort of adjust to individual local market conditions. So we expect that we'll see in the second quarter beyond an improvement in parts sales for the rest of the year.

componenttext: Okay, and lastly, you've done a nice job bringing down warranty costs on your Euro 6 engines. I'm wondering if you could just update us on how that's tracking, the warranty accruals continue to decline sequentially based on the experience level or are we at the run rate based on actual warranty that you're seeing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The DAF trucks, the PACCAR engines, the Kenworth, Peterbilt trucks around the world are performing very well, best reliability I think in the industry. And we've seen that reflected in our warranty provisions quarter-over-quarter. So the first quarter was
componenttext: The DAF trucks, the PACCAR engines, the Kenworth, Peterbilt trucks around the world are performing very well, best reliability I think in the industry. And we've seen that reflected in our warranty provisions quarter-over-quarter. So the first quarter was at a good run rate that we think is appropriate for our product.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting sort of 50% make versus buy in North America. For a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wondering any rea
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting sort of 50% make versus buy in North America. For a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wondering any reason why you would stop at 50%, and if you were to go beyond 50%, would you need to go all the way to 100% to justify the capital investment? Or could we see that target just slowly be dragged higher?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of
componenttext: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of land and its expandable just as what we had planned it to be. So we're earning a strong return off of the investment that we have made and will continue to make additional investments as of engine penetration grows in North America. The 50% is sort of a short midterm target. The longer-term target, as we look at our customers and the applications they have, we feel the engine can meet up to 80%, 85% of customer needs. So that's sort of the target at this point, longer term. And so we'll continue to invest increment capacity as we needed and we'll be making some of those investments in the next couple of years to support the growing acceptance of the engines doing great.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, what about your vertical integration effort and other product categories, and I think in your one of your more recent investor days, you have talked about things like axles also you can make internally. Are you doing more of that? Is that a driver o
componenttext: Okay, what about your vertical integration effort and other product categories, and I think in your one of your more recent investor days, you have talked about things like axles also you can make internally. Are you doing more of that? Is that a driver of success in the gross margin?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and that's what you get when you order a DAF truck, our PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle technology
componenttext: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and that's what you get when you order a DAF truck, our PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle technology and capabilities. We have great working relationships with Dana and Meritor, who are providing really customized applications that integrate well with the rest of the PACCAR powertrain to be able to offer our customers the unique capability for the fully integrated powertrain to operate their vehicles.

componenttext: We don't have any visibility to the industry as a whole, but I would tell you DAF's inventory is in great shape. Very similar to what we see with Peterbilt and Kenworth in North America in the 45 to 60 day range, which is really optimal to meet customer demand and not have excess inventories on the ground.

componenttextpreview: So for the parts business, we're getting pretty close now where foreign exchange rates have been pretty comparable. A little bit of effect on our revenue, I think, it was $10 million in the parts business in the first quarter. And I'll let Michael sort of
componenttext: So for the parts business, we're getting pretty close now where foreign exchange rates have been pretty comparable. A little bit of effect on our revenue, I think, it was $10 million in the parts business in the first quarter. And I'll let Michael sort of comment on overall effects for the company.

componenttext: For the truck parts and other, net sales and revenue impact was $68 million and the impact on Financial Services revenues was $9 million. And the impact on profitability was negligible.

componenttext: Okay, and just -- sorry, on the parts outlook for the year, is the sort of low to mid-single digits, still the right way to think about it or how you were thinking about it?

componenttext: I think we'll see a return to growth as we progress through the year. I think parts sales globally can be up towards the 3% range for the year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question relative to the order share and we don't typically see these kinds of swings translate into retail sales. But given that kind of order of magnitude, do you think that, that creates any more volatility over the course of the year? Or based
componenttext: Just a question relative to the order share and we don't typically see these kinds of swings translate into retail sales. But given that kind of order of magnitude, do you think that, that creates any more volatility over the course of the year? Or based on the timing of when those orders are scheduled to ship, would you not see any kind of disruption?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think the orders creating any additional volatility. They just bolster the backlog. And I think the cost of our -- we build the truck when we have an order. We don't build for inventory. We prudently manage our build schedule and so the fact t
componenttext: No, I don't think the orders creating any additional volatility. They just bolster the backlog. And I think the cost of our -- we build the truck when we have an order. We don't build for inventory. We prudently manage our build schedule and so the fact to that we have 37% of the orders just reflects we've got customers really appreciating the vehicle and the band ordering for what they need for the coming couple of months.

componenttext: Okay, and do you have kind of a targeted share, when you think your share would be in the U.S. or Canada for 2016 on retail?

componenttextpreview: Yes, so last year, we were 27.5%. So I think we'll be slightly above that for the full year in terms of retail sales.
componenttext: Yes, so last year, we were 27.5%. So I think we'll be slightly above that for the full year in terms of retail sales.

componenttext: And then the record share at DAF, you had mentioned that there was a good breadth of strength in share across the continent, I'm wondering if you believe that this, directionally, that this level of retail characteristic can persist for the rest of the year.

componenttext: Well, you see the margin benefits, whenever we get finished, we're utilizing the facility. But as you go through the cycles, you identify opportunities to continue to make your facilities and your processes more capable, and this is just sort of the continuing effort that we go through and have gone through for 110 years of the company of continuing the best during all phases of the business cycle to be able to be prepared, one, to get the efficiencies, but also to get that incremental capacity. The penetration of the 2.1-meter products both at Peterbilt and Kenworth has been outstanding and we continue to invest in the robotic capacity in those facility. And this is just part of that overall process that we go through throughout our history of making good prudent investments that prepare us, not only for today, but also for tomorrow.

componenttextpreview: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers, as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has
componenttext: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers, as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has become the engine of choice of those bus and coach customers for their applications. So 2 years of experience in Europe and launched it in January this year in North America, and the launch has gone very well. I was recently on a trip visiting, with some of our customers, and there's a lot of interest by a lot of different types of customers particularly those that are sensitive to weight because it's 400 pounds lighter than our other offering. So it's a very attractive option. And so the launch has gone good. The customers who have put that into their product early days is performing as expected. And we will continue to ramp that up as we progress through the course of this year.
