headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hasting
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and Controller. As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general, economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results. 
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 m
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 million, an 8.1% after-tax return on revenues. 
Adjusted net income excludes a $943 million non-recurring charge for the European Commission investigation of all European truck manufacturers. Including the non-recurring charge, PACCAR reported a net loss of $595 million in the first quarter. PACCAR achieved excellent Truck, Parts and Other gross margins of 14.9%, helped by the strong European truck market. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. 
PACCAR delivered 35,300 trucks during the first quarter, in line with our expectations. Deliveries in Europe were over 30% higher than last year's first quarter. Looking ahead, we expect a slight increase in deliveries in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. Second quarter gross margins are projected to be comparable to the strong first quarter margins, reflecting the benefits of DAF, Peterbilt and Kenworth's new truck models, the benefits of steady build rates, good truck markets and continued material cost savings. 
PACCAR's forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market is a range of 260,000 to 290,000 units, reflecting strong demand and a steady economic outlook. Europe's GDP growth expectations for this year are 2% in the U.K., which is DAF's largest market and 1.5% on the continent. Freight transport activity on German highways in the first quarter was up 4% over the same period last year. Year-to-date, DAF has achieved a record 16.6% share of the heavy-duty market. The economic picture in the U.S. remains positive, with GDP forecast to grow 2.1% this year. The housing and automotive industries create a large amount of freight. Housing starts are projected to grow 11% this year to over $1.2 million, and the automotive industry is expected to deliver 17.5 million vehicles, which would be a record. Other positive signals are that the ISM manufacturing index has returned to expansion and manufacturing inventories in the economy appear to be stabilizing. 
We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in a range of 220,000 to 250,000 units this year, the third best in the last decade. The economy's steady growth is supportive of healthy freight levels. The 88 tonnage index continued at record levels. Peterbilt and Kenworth's combined retail sales market share of the U.S. Canadian market is 26% year-to-date. Our share of net orders so far this year is strong at 37% as customers appreciate the benefits of Kenworth and Peterbilt's reliable and fuel-efficient trucks and industry-leading resale values. 
PACCAR's Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $720 million compared to $753 million in the same quarter of last year. PACCAR Parts quarterly pretax income was $135 million, an excellent return on revenue of 18.7%. These results were driven by good fleet utilization. The growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. PACCAR Financial Services first quarter pretax income was $80 million compared to $89 million a year ago. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. 
PACCAR's strong balance sheet and positive cash flow have enabled the company to invest $3.3 billion in new products and facilities in the last 5 years. PACCAR's capital spending of $325 million to $375 million this year is targeted at enhanced aftermarket support, manufacturing facilities and new product development. Research and development expenses are estimated to be in a range of $240 million to $260 million. 
PACCAR continues to enhance its leadership position in the global truck market by developing the highest quality products and services in the industry. Thank you. And I'd be pleased to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook.
componenttext: Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of questions. The margins -- the gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and then this -- in that relative to what the Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of
componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions. The margins -- the gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and then this -- in that relative to what the Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of that was material cost? How much of that was benefits from increasing production? And then I also think last quarter, you alluded to being able to achieve flat gross margins year-on-year. Can you talk about your comfort level with that today versus where we sat last quarter with material costs potentially being a headwind in the back half of the year and with the pricing environment?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first quarter, we had excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the ma
componenttext: Sure. So first quarter, we had excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the material cost movement that our purchasing and materials teams are providing with our suppliers, working closely with them to provide good value for our customers. The products are performing great in the field, so we've seen a good performance in our warranty cost during the quarter. So all the elements, just a good quarter of execution provided the results that we've seen. As we look forward for the full year margins, I think we'll still be in that 14.5% to 15% range for the full year at these build rates. So we'll continue to operate at the kind of levels that we saw in the first quarter, I believe.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: And I'm sorry, can you just also, and I'll get back. And can you comment, I mean last quarter, you talked about your inventory levels being at a much healthier rate relative to your peers. Can you just provide an update on that?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: I think the same situation exists. Our inventories are below 60 days in the field, so in great, great position. So what we produce will find its way to the customers' hands.

componenttext: Yes, you first talked about Australia and Mexico. I'd say, the markets there are good, steady and our plants all there also operated very efficiently during the quarter and markets are pretty reasonable. Brazil, the country is challenging, but we continue to move forward with our business. Build rates are steady and the team is doing an excellent job of continuing to establish and deepen the footprint of DAF in the marketplace, and we continue to see pretty good activity with respect to the Andean countries in South America with both the Kenworth and DAF brands.

componenttext: This is Mike Conlon for Ann. I just wanted to get a little bit of color on Financial Services margins, a little bit weaker than expected and if there was any particular reason why that, that may happen or may continue?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and then it dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Fin
componenttext: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and then it dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Financial Services business, we had nice used truck gains. This -- first quarter this year, those used truck gains didn't repeat. So it's primarily used trucks, a little bit impact of currency movement, but primarily the effects of used truck pricing.

componenttext: This is Joe Vruwink for David. I was wondering if you could give your European order growth in the quarter, and when I just look at what individual countries are doing, it would seem like DAF in the quarter with over 30% growth is doing quite a bit better than just what the U.K. and Netherlands markets might be doing. So are you gaining market share of countries that might not have been typically DAF countries in the past?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 product that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is performing excellently, and the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the product is t
componenttext: Yes, I think in most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 product that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is performing excellently, and the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the product is the best it's ever been. And so as time goes on more and more customers are recognizing that. And when you look at some of the southern markets that have been pretty depressed for quite a few years, those are recovering, and DAF has a strong presence in Central Europe in countries like Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, and many of those is #1 or 2 in those markets. So I think just the combination of all those elements coming together DAF achieved 16.6% share for the first quarter, which is a record level for them. And so it's really across the continent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and similar conversation, but here in the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retailers are closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned relati
componenttext: Okay, and similar conversation, but here in the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retailers are closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned relative to the other OEMs or is it similar and that new product is driving the gains?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptance of
componenttext: I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptance of the PACCAR engine in the product. And so just the continued appreciation of the product, the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the current products is excellent.

componenttextpreview: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks and material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that migh
componenttext: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks and material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that might play into our costs and pricing.

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the FINCO earnings, I wanted to clarify what it was within the interest and other that drove a higher cost. componenttext: A lot of it will depend on how the used truck market develops in the coming quarters. And so we'll see how that develops. In terms of the interest in other, just part of that is just a larger portfolio. The asset -- the average earning assets in the first quarter this year are higher and so that just reflects. We have higher assets and higher debt levels to go with that and that just reflects the higher cost to go with it.

componenttext: Okay, and lastly, you've done a nice job bringing down warranty costs on Euro 6 engines. componenttext: Yes, the DAF trucks, the PACCAR engines, the Kenworth, Peterbilt trucks around the world are performing very well, best reliability I think in the industry. And we've seen that reflected in our warranty provisions quarter-over-quarter. So the first quarter was at a good run rate that we think is appropriate for our product.

componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting at sort of 50% make versus buy in North America for a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wondering
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting at sort of 50% make versus buy in North America for a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wondering any reason why you would stop at 50%, and if you were to go beyond 50%, would you need to go all the way to 100% to justify the capital investment? Or could we see that target just slowly be dragged higher?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of
componenttext: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of land and its expandable just as we had planned it to be. So we're earning a strong return off of the investment that we have made and will continue to make additional investments as the engine penetration grows in North America. The 50% is sort of a short midterm target. The longer-term target, as we look at our customers and the applications they have, we feel the engine can meet up to 80%, 85% of customer needs. So that's sort of the target at this point, longer term. And so we'll continue to invest, increment capacity as we needed, and we'll be making some of those investments in the next couple of years to support the growing acceptance of the engines doing great.

componenttext: Okay. And then what about your vertical integration effort in other product categories? headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and we -- that's what you get when you order a DAF truck, our PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle tech
componenttext: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and we -- that's what you get when you order a DAF truck, our PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle technology and capabilities. We have great working relationships with Dana and Meritor, who are providing really customized applications that integrate well with the rest of the PACCAR powertrain to be able to offer our customers the unique capability of a fully integrated powertrain to operate their vehicles.

componenttext: No, I don't think the orders create any additional volatility. They just bolster the backlog. And I think because of our -- we build the truck when we have an order. componenttext: Well, you see the margin benefits, whenever we get finished and we're utilizing the facility. But as you go through the cycles, you identify opportunities to continue to make your facilities and your processes more capable, and this is just sort of the continuing effort that we go through and have gone through for 110 years of the company of continuing to invest during all phases of the business cycle to be able to be prepared, one, to get the efficiencies, but also to get that incremental capacity. The penetration of the 2.1-meter products both at Peterbilt and Kenworth has been outstanding and we continue to invest in the robotic capacity in those facility. And this is just part of that overall process that we go through throughout our history of making good prudent investments that prepare us, not only for today, but also for tomorrow.

componenttextpreview: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has b
componenttext: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has become the engine of choice of those bus and coach customers for their applications. So 2 years of experience in Europe and launched it in January this year in North America, and the launch has gone very well. I was recently on a trip visiting with some of our customers, and there's a lot of interest by a lot of different types of customers, particularly those that are sensitive to weight because it's 400 pounds lighter than our other offering. So it's a very attractive option. And so the launch has gone good. The customers who have put that into their product early days is performing as expected. And we will continue to ramp that up as we progress through the course of this year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hasting
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and Controller. As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general, economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results. 
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 m
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the first quarter of 2016. PACCAR's first quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.3 billion, and first quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $348 million, an 8.1% after-tax return on revenues. 
Adjusted net income excludes a $943 million non-recurring charge for the European Commission investigation of all European truck manufacturers. Including the non-recurring charge, PACCAR reported a net loss of $595 million in the first quarter. PACCAR achieved excellent Truck, Parts and Other gross margins of 14.9%, helped by the strong European truck market. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. 
PACCAR delivered 35,300 trucks during the first quarter, in line with our expectations. Deliveries in Europe were over 30% higher than last year's first quarter. Looking ahead, we expect a slight increase in deliveries in the second quarter compared to the first quarter. Second quarter gross margins are projected to be comparable to the strong first quarter margins, reflecting the benefits of DAF, Peterbilt and Kenworth's new truck models, the benefits of steady build rates, good truck markets and continued material cost savings. 
PACCAR's forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market is a range of 260,000 to 290,000 units, reflecting strong demand and a steady economic outlook. Europe's GDP growth expectations for this year are 2% in the U.K., which is DAF's largest market and 1.5% on the continent. Freight transport activity on German highways in the first quarter was up 4% over the same period last year. Year-to-date, DAF has achieved a record 16.6% share of the heavy-duty market. The economic picture in the U.S. remains positive, with GDP forecast to grow 2.1% this year. The housing and automotive industries create a large amount of freight. Housing starts are projected to grow 11% this year to over $1.2 million, and the automotive industry is expected to deliver 17.5 million vehicles, which would be a record. Other positive signals are that the ISM Manufacturing Index has returned to expansion and manufacturing inventories in the economy appear to be stabilizing. 
We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in a range of 220,000 to 250,000 units this year, the third best in the last decade. The economy's steady growth is supportive of healthy freight levels. The ATA tonnage index continues at record levels. Peterbilt and Kenworth's combined retail sales market share of the U.S. Canadian market is 26% year-to-date. Our share of net orders so far this year is strong at 37% as customers appreciate the benefits of Kenworth and Peterbilt's reliable and fuel-efficient trucks and industry-leading resale values. 
PACCAR's Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $720 million compared to $753 million in the same quarter of last year. PACCAR Parts quarterly pretax income was $135 million, an excellent return on revenue of 18.7%. These results were driven by good fleet utilization, the growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. PACCAR Financial Services' first quarter pretax income was $80 million compared to $89 million a year ago. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. 
PACCAR's strong balance sheet and positive cash flow have enabled the company to invest $3.3 billion in new products and facilities in the last 5 years. PACCAR's capital spending of $325 million to $375 million this year is targeted at enhanced aftermarket support, manufacturing facilities and new product development. Research and development expenses are estimated to be in a range of $240 million to $260 million. 
PACCAR continues to enhance its leadership position in the global truck market by developing the highest quality products and services in the industry. Thank you. And I'd be pleased to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of questions. The margins -- the gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and then this -- in that relative to what the Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of
componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions. The margins -- the gross margins in the first quarter were higher, I think, than you expected and then this -- in that relative to what the Street expected. So can you just talk to, because the Q isn't out yet, how much of that was material cost? How much of that was benefits from increasing production? And then I also think last quarter, you alluded to being able to achieve flat gross margins year-on-year. Can you talk about your comfort level with that today versus where we sat last quarter with material costs potentially being a headwind in the back half of the year and with the pricing environment?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first quarter, we had an excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the
componenttext: Sure. So first quarter, we had an excellent quarter from an execution standpoint. Our plants had steady build rates, as I mentioned, and so able to operate the plants very efficiently during the quarter, continue to see favorable benefits from some of the material cost movement that our purchasing and materials teams are providing with our suppliers, working closely with them to provide good value for our customers. The products are performing great in the field, so we've seen a good performance in our warranty cost during the quarter. So all the elements, just a good quarter of execution provided the results that we've seen. As we look forward for the full year margins, I think we'll still be in that 14.5% to 15% range for the full year at these build rates. So we'll continue to operate at the kind of levels that we saw in the first quarter, I believe.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: And I'm sorry, can you just also -- and I'll get back queue -- comment, I mean last quarter, you talked about your inventory levels being at a much healthier rate relative to your peers. Can you just provide an update on that?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: I think the same situation exists. Our inventories are below 60 days in the field, so in great, great position. So what we produce will find its way to the customers' hands.

componenttext: Yes, first talk about Australia and Mexico. Build rates are steady and the team is doing an excellent job of continuing to establish and deepen the footprint of DAF in the marketplace, and we continue to see pretty good activity with respect to the Andean countries in South America with both the Kenworth and DAF brands.

componenttext: This is Mike Conlon on for Ann. I just wanted to get a little bit of color on the Financial Services margins, it was a little bit weaker than expected and if there was any particular reason why that may happen or may continue?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and that has dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Fi
componenttext: Well, one of the things that we saw late last year, first quarter this year, there's several of our competitors have a pretty sizable oversupply of used truck inventories and that has dampened the overall market prices. And so whereas last year, in our Financial Services business, we had nice used truck gains, this -- first quarter this year, those used truck gains didn't repeat. So it's primarily used trucks, a little bit of impact of currency movement, but primarily the effects of used truck pricing.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Robert W. Baird.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe Vruwink for David. I was wondering if you could give your European order growth in the quarter, and when I just look at what individual countries are doing, it would seem like DAF in the quarter with over 30% growth is doing quite a bit better
componenttext: This is Joe Vruwink for David. I was wondering if you could give your European order growth in the quarter, and when I just look at what individual countries are doing, it would seem like DAF in the quarter with over 30% growth is doing quite a bit better than just what the U.K. and Netherlands markets might be doing. So are you gaining market share of countries that might have not been typically DAF countries in the past?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in most -- almost -- most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 product that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is performing excellently, and the fuel efficiency, the reliability o
componenttext: Yes, I think in most -- almost -- most countries, DAF gained share year-over-year on the quarter perspective. The Euro 6 product that DAF has had in the market now for a couple of years is performing excellently, and the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the product is the best it's ever been. And so as time goes on, more and more customers are recognizing that. And when you look at some of the southern markets that have been pretty depressed for quite a few years, those are recovering. And DAF has a strong presence in Central Europe in countries like Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, and many of those as #1 or 2 in those markets. So I think just the combination of all those elements coming together DAF achieved 16.6% share for the first quarter, which is a record level for them. And so it's really across the continent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and similar conversation, but here in the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retail is closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations [ph] maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned relat
componenttext: Okay, and similar conversation, but here in the U.S., to get 37% share of incoming orders, I think your Class 8 retail is closer to 25% right now. So is that particular locations [ph] maybe or regions of the country where you're just more positioned relative to the other OEMs or is it similar and that new product is driving the gains?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptanc
componenttext: Yes, I think new product is a big thing. The Peterbilt 579, 567 models and the Kenworth T680 and T880 models are very well-received by the customers. The engine, PACCAR engine penetration increased to 46% in the quarter. So there's more and more acceptance of the PACCAR engine in the product. And so just the continued appreciation of the product, the fuel efficiency, the reliability of the current products is excellent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on the cost savings. I mean, I know you mentioned continuing material cost savings expected in Q2. Just given the rise we have seen in commodity prices, how is that baked into your expectations of the 14.5% to 15% margins for the
componenttext: I just want to follow up on the cost savings. I mean, I know you mentioned continuing material cost savings expected in Q2. Just given the rise we have seen in commodity prices, how is that baked into your expectations of the 14.5% to 15% margins for the full year, and I guess, particularly in the second half?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks in material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that might
componenttext: We have long-term agreements with most of our suppliers, which tend to smooth out both the upticks and downticks in material cost movements from a commodity standpoint. So it will be pretty muted in terms of any uptick that we might see and how that might play into our costs and pricing.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think you can get pricing benefits on top of the higher costs as the smoothing sort of works itself through over the course of the year?
componenttext: Do you think you can get pricing benefits on top of the higher costs as the smoothing sort of works itself through over the course of the year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You typically do. I mean it may not be exactly at the same time, but typically those things find their way to the marketplace.
componenttext: You typically do. I mean it may not be exactly at the same time, but typically those things find their way to the marketplace.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the FINCO earnings, I wanted to clarify what it was within the interest and other that drove the higher cost. I'm not sure if that was the used pricing that you were talking about earlier. And do you think the 10% year-over-year dec
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the FINCO earnings, I wanted to clarify what it was within the interest and other that drove the higher cost. I'm not sure if that was the used pricing that you were talking about earlier. And do you think the 10% year-over-year decline in profit is going to be better or worse or the same as what the full year could be?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of it will depend on how the used truck market develops in the coming quarters. And so we'll see how that develops. In terms of the interest and other, just -- part of that is just a larger portfolio. The asset -- the average earning assets in the f
componenttext: A lot of it will depend on how the used truck market develops in the coming quarters. And so we'll see how that develops. In terms of the interest and other, just -- part of that is just a larger portfolio. The asset -- the average earning assets in the first quarter this year are higher and so that just reflects. We have higher assets and higher debt levels that go with that and that just reflects the higher costs that go with it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, I'm wondering if you could talk about the pricing environment in Europe, specifically you folks have spoken about once the market gets good enough, you might be at a point where you get to make a margin on the new emissions components. Are we at that
componenttext: Ron, I'm wondering if you could talk about the pricing environment in Europe, specifically you folks have spoken about once the market gets good enough, you might be at a point where you get to make a margin on the new emissions components. Are we at that point yet? Can you just give us an update within the context of the steady pricing environment that you outlined across the business?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wish that were the case, Jerry, but it's -- the pricing is pretty steady in terms of this year versus what we saw last year during the course of the year. Market is good, so pricing environment has been, again as I said, pretty steady without much up or
componenttext: I wish that were the case, Jerry, but it's -- the pricing is pretty steady in terms of this year versus what we saw last year during the course of the year. Market is good, so pricing environment has been, again as I said, pretty steady without much up or down movement.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then can you talk about what you're seeing out of your customers in terms of parts consumption in North America? It looks like your North America Parts business may have been down more than the overall Parts business. Is that an issue of timing
componenttext: Okay, and then can you talk about what you're seeing out of your customers in terms of parts consumption in North America? It looks like your North America Parts business may have been down more than the overall Parts business. Is that an issue of timing or what drove that? I think we're hearing from construction industries that it was a pretty seasonally positive quarter for business. So I'm wondering if you could just fill in the gaps on what you're seeing out of your customers there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so from a customer standpoint, the actual retail sales at the dealer level were up a bit during the quarter. What we saw was the dealers rebalancing their inventories to sort of adjust to individual local market conditions. So we expect that we'll se
componenttext: Yes, so from a customer standpoint, the actual retail sales at the dealer level were up a bit during the quarter. What we saw was the dealers rebalancing their inventories to sort of adjust to individual local market conditions. So we expect that we'll see in the second quarter and beyond that -- an improvement in parts sales for the rest of the year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and lastly, you've done a nice job bringing down warranty costs on Euro 6 engines. I'm wondering if you could just update us on how that's tracking, did the warranty accruals continue to decline sequentially based on the experience level or are we a
componenttext: Okay, and lastly, you've done a nice job bringing down warranty costs on Euro 6 engines. I'm wondering if you could just update us on how that's tracking, did the warranty accruals continue to decline sequentially based on the experience level or are we at the run rate based on the actual warranty instances that you're seeing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the DAF trucks, the PACCAR engines, the Kenworth, Peterbilt trucks around the world are performing very well, best reliability I think in the industry. And we've seen that reflected in our warranty provisions quarter-over-quarter. So the first quarte
componenttext: Yes, the DAF trucks, the PACCAR engines, the Kenworth, Peterbilt trucks around the world are performing very well, best reliability I think in the industry. And we've seen that reflected in our warranty provisions quarter-over-quarter. So the first quarter was at a good run rate that we think is appropriate for our product.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Ross Gilardi with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Ross Gilardi with Bank of America.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting at sort of a 50% make versus buy in North America for a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wonderin
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about your internal engine effort. Obviously, PACCAR has been targeting at sort of a 50% make versus buy in North America for a long time, and you've been inching closer to that target. I'm just wondering, any reason why you would stop at 50%, and if you were to go beyond 50%, would you need to go all the way to 100% to justify the capital investment? Or could we see that target just slowly be dragged higher?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of
componenttext: Wonderful thing about our facility in Columbus, Mississippi, we built it at 400,000 square feet. We're continuing to add additional equipment into the facility to achieve what's possible within that footprint. But we have a lot of -- we have 400 acres of land and its expandable just as we had planned it to be. So we're earning a strong return off of the investment that we have made and will continue to make additional investments as the engine penetration grows in North America. The 50% is sort of a short midterm target. The longer-term target, as we look at our customers and the applications they have, we feel the engine can meet up to 80%, 85% of customer needs. So that's sort of the target at this point, longer term. And so we'll continue to invest increment capacity as we need it, and we'll be making some of those investments in the next couple of years to support the growing acceptance of the engines. Doing great.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then what about your vertical integration effort in other product categories? I mean I think at your -- one of your more recent investor days, you had talked about things like axles also that you can make internally. And are you doing more of th
componenttext: Okay. And then what about your vertical integration effort in other product categories? I mean I think at your -- one of your more recent investor days, you had talked about things like axles also that you can make internally. And are you doing more of that? And is that a driver of success in the gross margin?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and we -- that's what you get when you order a DAF truck are PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle techn
componenttext: Well DAF has been making axles for the 20 years that PACCAR has owned them, and we -- that's what you get when you order a DAF truck are PACCAR axles. We are working -- in North America, we're looking at opportunities to take advantage of DAF's axle technology and capabilities. We have great working relationships with Dana and Meritor, who are providing really customized applications that integrate well with the rest of the PACCAR powertrain to be able to offer our customers the unique capability of a fully integrated powertrain to operate their vehicles.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color on the Europe market. We've been hearing some discussion about some rising dealer inventories in Europe. I'm wondering if you've seen anything there with just across the industry or with DAF specifically?
componenttext: I appreciate the color on the Europe market. We've been hearing some discussion about some rising dealer inventories in Europe. I'm wondering if you've seen anything there with just across the industry or with DAF specifically?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have any visibility to the industry as a whole, but I would tell you DAF's inventory is in great shape. Very similar to what we see with Peterbilt and Kenworth in North America in the 45 to 60 day range, which is really optimal to meet customer d
componenttext: We don't have any visibility to the industry as a whole, but I would tell you DAF's inventory is in great shape. Very similar to what we see with Peterbilt and Kenworth in North America in the 45 to 60 day range, which is really optimal to meet customer demand and not have excess inventories on the ground.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then if I could just go back to the parts business for a minute, I know in prior quarters, FX has been a headwind there. I mean are you still expecting -- and was it a headwind here in the quarter, and are you still expecting kind of a low to mi
componenttext: Okay, and then if I could just go back to the parts business for a minute, I know in prior quarters, FX has been a headwind there. I mean are you still expecting -- and was it a headwind here in the quarter, and are you still expecting kind of a low to mid-single-digit growth for the parts business this year? And then, I guess, just separately, could you give us what FX impact was for the company for revenue and operating income all together?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for the parts business, we're getting pretty close now where foreign exchange rates have been pretty comparable. We had a little bit of effect on revenue. I think, it was $10 million in the parts business in the first quarter. And I'll let Michael to c
componenttext: So for the parts business, we're getting pretty close now where foreign exchange rates have been pretty comparable. We had a little bit of effect on revenue. I think, it was $10 million in the parts business in the first quarter. And I'll let Michael to comment on overall effects for the company.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the Truck, Parts and Other, net sales and revenue, impact was $68 million and the impact on Financial Services revenues was $9 million. And the impact on profitability was negligible.
componenttext: For the Truck, Parts and Other, net sales and revenue, impact was $68 million and the impact on Financial Services revenues was $9 million. And the impact on profitability was negligible.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just -- sorry, on the parts outlook for the year, is sort of low to mid-single digits still the right way to think about it or how you're thinking about it?
componenttext: Okay, and then just -- sorry, on the parts outlook for the year, is sort of low to mid-single digits still the right way to think about it or how you're thinking about it?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we'll see a return to growth as we progress through the year. I think parts sales globally could be up towards the 3% range for the year.
componenttext: Yes, I think we'll see a return to growth as we progress through the year. I think parts sales globally could be up towards the 3% range for the year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question relative to the order share -- and we don't typically see those kinds of swings then translate into retail sales. But given that kind of order of magnitude, do you think that, that creates any more volatility over the course of the year? O
componenttext: Just a question relative to the order share -- and we don't typically see those kinds of swings then translate into retail sales. But given that kind of order of magnitude, do you think that, that creates any more volatility over the course of the year? Or based on the timing of when those orders are scheduled to ship, would you not see any kind of disruption?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think the orders create any additional volatility. They just bolster the backlog. And I think because of our -- we build the truck when we have an order. We don't build for inventory. We prudently manage our build schedule and so the fact that
componenttext: No, I don't think the orders create any additional volatility. They just bolster the backlog. And I think because of our -- we build the truck when we have an order. We don't build for inventory. We prudently manage our build schedule and so the fact that we had 37% of the orders just reflects that we've got customers really appreciating the vehicle and ordering for what they need for the coming couple of months.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and do you have kind of a targeted share where you think your share will be in U.S. and Canada for 2016 on retail?
componenttext: Okay, and do you have kind of a targeted share where you think your share will be in U.S. and Canada for 2016 on retail?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so last year we were 27.5%. So I think we'll be slightly above that for the full year in terms of retail sales.
componenttext: Yes, so last year we were 27.5%. So I think we'll be slightly above that for the full year in terms of retail sales.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Uhlman with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Uhlman with Cleveland Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, a clarification, I might have missed it, but did you mention the magnitude of the used truck pricing that you're seeing right now, and if not, could you tell us kind of what that trend has been looking like recently? And when you would exp
componenttext: I guess, first, a clarification, I might have missed it, but did you mention the magnitude of the used truck pricing that you're seeing right now, and if not, could you tell us kind of what that trend has been looking like recently? And when you would expect to see a stabilization in used truck prices?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're starting to see a stabilization during the quarter from the, say, fourth quarter into the first quarter. It was probably a 5% to 10% impact for the market as a whole. The good news is that the Peterbilt, Kenworth and DAF products continue to
componenttext: I think we're starting to see a stabilization during the quarter from the, say, fourth quarter into the first quarter. It was probably a 5% to 10% impact for the market as a whole. The good news is that the Peterbilt, Kenworth and DAF products continue to maintain their premium relative to the competition in the 10% to 20% range.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then back to the share of orders that you got in North America, congrats on pulling those in. Could you tell us what the first quarter of last year's share was or what the year-over-year order growth was for you?
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then back to the share of orders that you got in North America, congrats on pulling those in. Could you tell us what the first quarter of last year's share was or what the year-over-year order growth was for you?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we have that number readily at hand. So we'll have to come back to you on that.
componenttext: I don't think we have that number readily at hand. So we'll have to come back to you on that.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the record share at DAF, you had mentioned that there was a good breadth of strength in the share across the continent, I'm wondering if you believe that this, directionally, that this level of retail share can persist for the rest of the y
componenttext: Okay. And then the record share at DAF, you had mentioned that there was a good breadth of strength in the share across the continent, I'm wondering if you believe that this, directionally, that this level of retail share can persist for the rest of the year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: DAF, in 2012, '13, was in the 6 -- 15%, 15.5%, 16% range. So, yes, I believe this is probably more consistent. We had some interruptions if you will with the Euro 5, Euro 6 transition. And I think this is more indicative of where DAF -- DAF's position in
componenttext: DAF, in 2012, '13, was in the 6 -- 15%, 15.5%, 16% range. So, yes, I believe this is probably more consistent. We had some interruptions if you will with the Euro 5, Euro 6 transition. And I think this is more indicative of where DAF -- DAF's position in the market.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in your release you actually mentioned you were going to be expanding your Denton facility in the near future to expand the capacity there. I guess, I was kind of wondering -- this past year was a very, very strong year for Class 8 in 2015, and I don't
componenttext: So in your release you actually mentioned you were going to be expanding your Denton facility in the near future to expand the capacity there. I guess, I was kind of wondering -- this past year was a very, very strong year for Class 8 in 2015, and I don't think you had too many problems delivering to customers, so I guess, what's being expanded attention that's so important? And when can we start seeing some of the margin benefits from that expansion?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you'll see the margin benefits, whenever we get finished and we're utilizing the facility. But as you go through the cycles, you identify opportunities to continue to make your facilities and your processes more capable, and this is just sort of the
componenttext: Well, you'll see the margin benefits, whenever we get finished and we're utilizing the facility. But as you go through the cycles, you identify opportunities to continue to make your facilities and your processes more capable, and this is just sort of the continuing effort that we go through and have gone through for 110 years of the company of continuing to invest during all phases of the business cycle to be able to be prepared, one, to get the efficiencies, but also to get that incremental capacity. The penetration of the 2.1-meter products both at Peterbilt and Kenworth has been outstanding and we continue to invest in the robotic capacity in those facilities. And this is just part of that overall process that we go through throughout our history of making good prudent investments that prepare us, not only for today, but also for tomorrow.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's more efficiency gains, and it's not intended to substantially increase the number of parts you can make in a year. You just make them faster or better?
componenttext: So it's more efficiency gains, and it's not intended to substantially increase the number of parts you can make in a year. You just make them faster or better?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both, yes.
componenttext: It's a combination of both, yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one quick model question for you as well, could you give us the diluted share count adjusted if you had not posted a loss for the year -- for the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick model question for you as well, could you give us the diluted share count adjusted if you had not posted a loss for the year -- for the quarter?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would have been 351.9.
componenttext: It would have been 351.9.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Wertheimer with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Wertheimer with Barclays.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you able to talk just a little bit about how you're approaching the 11-liter launch and any numbers you are willing to update on the penetration in Europe and the U.S?
componenttext: Are you able to talk just a little bit about how you're approaching the 11-liter launch and any numbers you are willing to update on the penetration in Europe and the U.S?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has b
componenttext: Yes, so the MX-11, as you know, we've launched that in Europe in the fourth quarter of 2013. It's been very well-received in Europe by both our truck customers as well as we sell several thousand engines each year to bus and coach customers and that has become the engine of choice of those bus and coach customers for their applications. So 2 years of experience in Europe and launched it in January this year in North America, and the launch has gone very well. I was recently on a trip visiting with some of our customers, and there's a lot of interest by a lot of different types of customers, particularly those that are sensitive to weight because it's 400 pounds lighter than our other offering. So it's a very attractive option. And so the launch has gone good. The customers who have put that into their product early days, it's performing as expected. And we will continue to ramp that up as we progress through the course of this year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect. And did you launch it in many models at once or is it just sort of a stage thing where we can expect it to take a couple of years to be fully out there in the fleet?
componenttext: That's perfect. And did you launch it in many models at once or is it just sort of a stage thing where we can expect it to take a couple of years to be fully out there in the fleet?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it will be a staged -- I mean we're purposely ramping up both -- the plant so that they get more comfortable with the assembly process. But early days is very promising.
componenttext: No, it will be a staged -- I mean we're purposely ramping up both -- the plant so that they get more comfortable with the assembly process. But early days is very promising.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and if anyone have any objections, they should disconnect at any time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hasting
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and if anyone have any objections, they should disconnect at any time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President a
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and Controller. 
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results.
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the second quarter of 2016. PACCAR's second quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and second quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $372
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the second quarter of 2016. PACCAR's second quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and second quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $372 million at 8.4% after-tax return on revenues. Adjusted net income excludes a favorable $109 million adjustment to the reserve established in the first quarter this year, reflecting the settlement of the European Commission investigation. 
Including the reserve adjustment, PACCAR reported net income of $481 million in the second quarter. PACCAR achieved excellent truck, parts and other gross margins of 15.2%, driven by Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF's premium products, DAF's strong 16% market share, a robust European truck market and rigorous cost control. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. PACCAR delivered 36,700 trucks during the second quarter, in line with our expectations. Deliveries in Europe were 17% higher than last year's second quarter. 
In the third quarter, PACCAR deliveries will be slightly lower than the second quarter due to the normal summer shutdown at DAF. Third quarter gross margins are projected to remain strong but down slightly from the second quarter margins due to the lower production in Europe. PACCAR's industry-leading operating margins reflect the benefits of DAF, Peterbilt and Kenworth's new truck models, record plant operating efficiency, good truck markets and continued material cost savings. We've raised our forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market to a range of 280,000 to 300,000 units reflecting strong demand and the steady economic outlook. 
The Eurozone's GDP growth expectations for this year are 1.5%. Freight transport activity on German highways in the first half of this year was up 3.4% over the same period last year. Since the vote in the U.K. to exit the European Union, DAF's truck orders, parts and service sales and finance sales continue at strong levels comparable to the period prior to the vote. The economic picture in the U.S. is positive with GDP forecast to grow 1.9% this year. The housing and automotive industries create a large amount of freight. Housing starts are projected to grow 11% this year to 1.2 million and the automotive industry is expected to deliver 17.2 million vehicles similar to last year's record sales. The ISN manufacturing index has been over 50 indicating expansion for the last 4 months. Consumer spending and disposable income are outgrowing the overall economy, which is supported of freight in the truck industry. We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in the range of 220,000 to 240,000 units this year, which is the third best in the last decade. 
Peterbilt and Kenworth's combined retail sales market share of the U.S. and Canadian market was 28% in the second quarter. Our share of net orders so far this year is strong at 34% as customers benefit from Kenworth and Peterbilt's reliable and fuel-efficient trucks and industry-leading resale values. PACCAR Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $756 million, a 5% increase compared to the first quarter. PACCAR Parts quarterly pretax income was $133 million, with a return on revenues of 17.6%. These results were driven by good fleet utilization, the growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation, and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. Second half part sales are expected to improve from first half levels. 
PACCAR Financial Services second quarter pretax income was $77 million. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. During the quarter, PACCAR Financial began providing retail financing in Romania, its 23rd country of operation. PACCAR Financial also acquired land in the Chicago area to construct a new use truck center and expanded sales of Kenworth and Peterbilt premium use trucks. PACCAR's strong balance sheet and cash flows have enabled the company to invest $6 billion in new products and facilities in the last 10 years. PACCAR achieved record net operating cash flow of $1.6 billion in the first half of 2016. 
PACCAR's capital spending of $325 million to $375 million this year is targeted at enhanced aftermarket support, manufacturing facilities and new product development. Research and development expenses are estimated to be in the range of $240 million to $260 million. PACCAR continues to enhance its leadership position in the global truck market by developing the highest-quality products and services in the industry. 
Thank you. And I look forward to your questions.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, just if I could ask you to sort of give us an update on how you see your industry inventory levels in North America and in Europe. And I guess, specifically, I'm trying to think about the potential that you will need to adjust production levels at
componenttext: Maybe, just if I could ask you to sort of give us an update on how you see your industry inventory levels in North America and in Europe. And I guess, specifically, I'm trying to think about the potential that you will need to adjust production levels at in the second half. Or do we think of them as being sort of fairly stable moving forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The dealer inventories are in excellent shape in both of our key markets, North America and Europe, and they have been. We adjusted build rates in the second half of last year. And the balance with demand and we've been at steady inventories and steady bu
componenttext: The dealer inventories are in excellent shape in both of our key markets, North America and Europe, and they have been. We adjusted build rates in the second half of last year. And the balance with demand and we've been at steady inventories and steady build during the first half of this year and projected to see that continue for the second half of this year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And maybe just a quick follow-up. Retail sales have been running obviously, ahead of orders for a while. And I guess, the market maybe is having a little bit of trouble figuring out whether we should be paying more attention to 1 versus the o
componenttext: Okay, great. And maybe just a quick follow-up. Retail sales have been running obviously, ahead of orders for a while. And I guess, the market maybe is having a little bit of trouble figuring out whether we should be paying more attention to 1 versus the other. Is it your view that orders will sort of recover the retail levels once inventories get in shape? Or do you think that once people take deliveries of these trucks, the order rates will continue to be lower and things will sort of take another step down?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there's a lot of trucks still being produced still on some of the backlog. And so I think orders will come back to better reflect what retail sales activity is. The great news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth, because of their approach to buildi
componenttext: No. I think there's a lot of trucks still being produced still on some of the backlog. And so I think orders will come back to better reflect what retail sales activity is. The great news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth, because of their approach to building trucks to customer orders, they've gotten a higher share of the orders during the first half of the year, just under 35%. So they've done a great job of supporting our customers.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, you guys have, I think a pretty high share in the oil and gas markets which obviously, has been pretty weak. Any signs of any kind of life there yet?
componenttext: And then just finally, you guys have, I think a pretty high share in the oil and gas markets which obviously, has been pretty weak. Any signs of any kind of life there yet?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think it's -- I think I'd say it's bottomed out until the opportunity is up from here, I think.

componenttext: The first question is just on -- just to come back to the outlook that you provided. componenttext: Got it. And then just on parts specifically. I think the expectation had been North America up, call it I think 3 in Europe around that range as well. We're starting from a little bit of a hole here in the first half. So any update to that guidance from a revenue standpoint?

componenttext: I think as we look at the second half, I think we see second half part sales probably up 2% to 4% compared to first half levels. Traditionally, the second half parts activity has been a little higher than the first half.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jamie Cook with Credit Suisse.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just a couple of questions. One, well, I know you won't give the official retail sales forecast outlook until next quarter. You've seen some industry experts in the U.S. like ACT. I mean, they've taken down their forecasts for '17, they're now as
componenttext: I guess, just a couple of questions. One, well, I know you won't give the official retail sales forecast outlook until next quarter. You've seen some industry experts in the U.S. like ACT. I mean, they've taken down their forecasts for '17, they're now assuming it down a year. You guys have, within -- and then I guess, in Europe there's some greater concerns on the longer-term expectations of Brexit and how that impacts things. So I guess, my question is, I know you're not going to give a specific number. But do you think the market is too bearish on '17? Or given what you see today, is it fair to assume that '17 would be down in the U.S.? And then given that you raised your forecast for the year but it appears you're not that worried about Brexit but sort of your thoughts there. And then my second question is you said PACCAR inventory -- dealer inventories were good. I don't think you answered or talked about what you're seeing from the competitors. If you could provide any color there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, based on the information we have about dealer inventories, I think we're probably below where some of the competition are with respect to their inventory positions. But we're very comfortable with where we're at in both Europe and North America. Wit
componenttext: Well, based on the information we have about dealer inventories, I think we're probably below where some of the competition are with respect to their inventory positions. But we're very comfortable with where we're at in both Europe and North America. With respect to 2017. I guess, based on as we sit here today, it feels like some of the negative forecast feel a bit bearish at this point. That's about all I can say at this point.

componenttext: This is Joe Vruwink for David. When you look at commodity price movements through the first 6 months of the year, particularly steel. Do you have any sense of prices stay at current levels and you get your resets on your pass-throughs on to next year. May be $1 or margin headwind you would expect to encounter?
