componenttext: I think at this point, we've seen reductions over the last several quarters. I'd say their prices, our costs are firming. But we don't anticipate any significant impact of material cost movements in the near term.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just on the extent of market share gains both in the U.S. and in Europe. Share is typically hard to come by in this industry. And it's tougher to hold onto. So you're 6 months into a pretty big share spike or share improvement. D
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just on the extent of market share gains both in the U.S. and in Europe. Share is typically hard to come by in this industry. And it's tougher to hold onto. So you're 6 months into a pretty big share spike or share improvement. Do you think that can hold? Obviously, a residual value is particularly at Peterbilt, are well above what the industry is doing. So I'd imagine that's a big positive. But are there things with a new product lineup or other intangibles with PACCAR where you think 34%, 35% that doesn't just need to be the first 6 months. It can be a 2016 outcome ultimately?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again that's orders in terms of retail sales in the second quarter, Peterbilt and Kenworth are 28%, and reflecting the great products and services with Parts and Finance that we provide through our dealer network. We have the strongest dealer networ
componenttext: Well, again that's orders in terms of retail sales in the second quarter, Peterbilt and Kenworth are 28%, and reflecting the great products and services with Parts and Finance that we provide through our dealer network. We have the strongest dealer network. So when I started with the company, Peterbilt and Kenworth were 21%, and they've grown to 28% over a period of time and over the 20-year period we've owned DAF, we've gone from less than 10% to 16%. So we have a long-term track record of incrementing that share. And I think that's our focus. And with the product lineup and support activities that we have in place, that will continue to be our focus to achieve those increments.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: May be let me ask it this way. You're at 28%. You're booking at 34%. So in '17, are you may be in the low 30s for retail share?
componenttext: May be let me ask it this way. You're at 28%. You're booking at 34%. So in '17, are you may be in the low 30s for retail share?

componenttextpreview: I think that's -- I'd love to be, but that might be optimistic.
componenttext: I think that's -- I'd love to be, but that might be optimistic.

componenttext: A question on the European orders. A few of your European competitors have kind of talked about modest declines in the EU region truck orders compared to last year. Can you comment on what you saw in terms of order intake during the quarter, compared to Q2 '15?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it was very comparable. It was nice consistent order board throughout the quarter. So I'd say it's very consistent with what we saw in 2015 levels. And if you recall in 2015, we were increasing build rates throughout the year. This year, we starte
componenttext: I'd say it was very comparable. It was nice consistent order board throughout the quarter. So I'd say it's very consistent with what we saw in 2015 levels. And if you recall in 2015, we were increasing build rates throughout the year. This year, we started at a stronger pace and we maintained that and anticipate further build rate enhancements in the second half.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the finance company. I saw a little uptick in provisions for losses on receivables compared to both last year in Q1. Was that driven by a specific region? Or can you help us understand -- I guess, was small. But kind of what was going on th
componenttext: Okay. And then the finance company. I saw a little uptick in provisions for losses on receivables compared to both last year in Q1. Was that driven by a specific region? Or can you help us understand -- I guess, was small. But kind of what was going on there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's small and it was very discreet in terms of particular customers and activity. So it really is the portfolio is performing great. The pass-through are -- have been less than 1% now for many years and it continues to perform well at that level.
componenttext: Yes, it's small and it was very discreet in terms of particular customers and activity. So it really is the portfolio is performing great. The pass-through are -- have been less than 1% now for many years and it continues to perform well at that level.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one last question was kind of how to look at the short-term. I mean, you talked about the production pattern already slightly lower Q3 versus Q2. Should the margin be somewhat similar in Q3 versus Q2, because you had a kind of earlier than
componenttext: Okay. And then one last question was kind of how to look at the short-term. I mean, you talked about the production pattern already slightly lower Q3 versus Q2. Should the margin be somewhat similar in Q3 versus Q2, because you had a kind of earlier than industry production decrease last year in North America that did impact the margin?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as I mentioned, we'll see both production and margins down slightly in the third quarter as a result of the European summer shutdown period.
componenttext: Yes, I think as I mentioned, we'll see both production and margins down slightly in the third quarter as a result of the European summer shutdown period.

componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about what you're hearing from your customers in terms of -- we're getting into that seasonal time frame where large fleets starts contemplating orders for 2017 delivery. What are you hearing from the customer base out there?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about what you're hearing from your customers in terms of -- we're getting into that seasonal time frame where large fleets starts contemplating orders for 2017 delivery. What are you hearing from the customer base out there?

componenttextpreview: I think it's -- looking at the results of our -- some of our customers, those that are reported, you see the results are still good. They're not may be as buoyant as they were a year ago, but still good solid results. And I think a lot of their decisions
componenttext: I think it's -- looking at the results of our -- some of our customers, those that are reported, you see the results are still good. They're not may be as buoyant as they were a year ago, but still good solid results. And I think a lot of their decisions about truck orders will be driven by the economic conditions. We've seen lower orders in the first half and as we talked about it, I think we'll see orders pick up and I think customers will start to place orders to get into their positioning for 2017 builds slots.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And those come in for North America?
componenttext: And those come in for North America?

componenttext: I think both markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on used prices. We've seen softness in used equipment prices. Can you talk about your brands use pricing? And also, does that have any impact on PACCAR leasing? And is there any downside risk on residual values for past leasing?
componenttext: Okay. And then on used prices. We've seen softness in used equipment prices. Can you talk about your brands use pricing? And also, does that have any impact on PACCAR leasing? And is there any downside risk on residual values for past leasing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So used truck prices in Europe are pretty steady. They have been and we've started to see a few Euros 6 trucks into the market and the Euros 6 -- DAF Euros 6 trucks are really earning a nice premium in the used market. In North America, we have seen a red
componenttext: So used truck prices in Europe are pretty steady. They have been and we've started to see a few Euros 6 trucks into the market and the Euros 6 -- DAF Euros 6 trucks are really earning a nice premium in the used market. In North America, we have seen a reduction, several of our competitors have sizable quantities of used truck inventories. That's sort of dampened the entire market. The good news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to enjoy 10% to 15% premium relative to the competition. And that's part of the impact on PACCAR Financial Services last year. We were earning nice gains with a buoyant used truck market this year. Those gains have gone down as a result of just lower average sales prices.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any residual value risks?
componenttext: And any residual value risks?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think we look at that every quarter and adjust our residual values based on the current market at that time. So that's been reflected in our quarterly results.
componenttext: No. I think we look at that every quarter and adjust our residual values based on the current market at that time. So that's been reflected in our quarterly results.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could just talk about the duration of your backlog today? How it's changed over the last few months and the visibility you have for the rest of the year?
componenttext: I wonder if you could just talk about the duration of your backlog today? How it's changed over the last few months and the visibility you have for the rest of the year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, orders have been -- let's talk about Europe first. Orders have been, as I mentioned, very, very good and we have a solid backlog and we're anticipating that we'll probably increase our daily build rates during the course of the second half. And Nort
componenttext: Well, orders have been -- let's talk about Europe first. Orders have been, as I mentioned, very, very good and we have a solid backlog and we're anticipating that we'll probably increase our daily build rates during the course of the second half. And North America, orders have been below production of retail sales. So we continue to produce trucks that were ordered in 2015. So -- but we've got some good solid orders in the backlog and we'll continue to build those trucks as well as the orders that are coming in on an ongoing basis.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then shifting over to the parts side of the business. How do you see the margin opportunity for parts going forward? One of your competitors recorded a pretty notable high number. Can you just refresh us on sort of the rebranding strategies you
componenttext: Okay. And then shifting over to the parts side of the business. How do you see the margin opportunity for parts going forward? One of your competitors recorded a pretty notable high number. Can you just refresh us on sort of the rebranding strategies you have here to augment parts margin? And where do you see these margin going from here?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we develop new products and have developed new products over the years, we always get enhancing our proprietary content of our vehicles. And obviously, with the increasing mix of MX engines in the truck part in North America, that's going to enha
componenttext: Well, as we develop new products and have developed new products over the years, we always get enhancing our proprietary content of our vehicles. And obviously, with the increasing mix of MX engines in the truck part in North America, that's going to enhance our margin opportunity over time with respect to engine parts. But we also are trying to focus a lot on selling parts, our TRP lineup of all makes. And those have a little bit of narrow margin on those. So it's a balance. I would say those margins would be fairly consistent with what we've seen in the recent quarterly performance.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about your key partners as you develop the autonomous vehicle platform whether it's DAF or Peterbilt or Kenworth, whoever's taking the lead on that. If you could just, to the extent you willing to comment, talk about the time
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about your key partners as you develop the autonomous vehicle platform whether it's DAF or Peterbilt or Kenworth, whoever's taking the lead on that. If you could just, to the extent you willing to comment, talk about the time frame and when you expect to have the commercial products. Nice to see the progress and put tuning, I'm wondering if you're willing to flush that out a bit more for us.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, it's very early days with the advanced driver assisted systems. And all of the divisions are actively engaged in discussions with suppliers across divisional lines, technology companies. Really, there's a lot of participants that we think
componenttext: Well, obviously, it's very early days with the advanced driver assisted systems. And all of the divisions are actively engaged in discussions with suppliers across divisional lines, technology companies. Really, there's a lot of participants that we think and help support our entrance into those technology. So we're very active. And it's going to be probably more than 5 years before you see something on the road that is fully autonomous and operating day to day. Don't know how long that will be, but it's something that everybody is focused on. And we're making some sizable investments in the technologies and capabilities in that area.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then from a shorter term standpoint. Can you talk about what was pricing in the quarter for you in U.S. and Europe and the first quarter 10-Q looks like there was a modest headwind in Europe. I'm wondering if it was that just timing phenomenon.
componenttext: Okay. And then from a shorter term standpoint. I'm wondering if it was that just timing phenomenon. Can you talk about pricing turning positive in Europe for the second quarter?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think pricing in Europe is pretty -- is relatively steady and has been for some time. And U.S. pricing is also steady. Obviously, the lower use truck prices can impact large transaction to do with fleets. But that's -- I'd say the pricing in both market
componenttext: I think pricing in Europe is pretty -- is relatively steady and has been for some time. And U.S. pricing is also steady. Obviously, the lower use truck prices can impact large transaction to do with fleets. But that's -- I'd say the pricing in both markets is pretty consistent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, I'm wondering if you're willing to talk about what order inquiry levels have been like in Europe in July, just to calibrate us. What you're hearing from your customers post Brexit, if you're willing to comment directionally?

componenttext: Yes, so post Brexit, I guess, as I said in my comments, the order activity and inquiries continue at good solid rates. We have our range estimates for the European market. And as I mentioned, we're going to be enhancing our build rate in the second half in Europe to reflect that demand.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the medium duty product is the same excellent product that we've had in the market for the last several years. And last year, we achieved a record share of 17.2%. And we're in that same range, it was slightly lower than that year-to-date this year, the
componenttext: So the medium duty product is the same excellent product that we've had in the market for the last several years. And last year, we achieved a record share of 17.2%. And we're in that same range, it was slightly lower than that year-to-date this year, the medium duty market is -- last year was in Class 6 and 7, where we participate was about 80,000 trucks. And we think that market is going to be comparable to that level this year. And the durability and again, the residual value of those trucks is great in the market, well received by our customers.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just help us to understand the incentive for you guys to sell used trucks outside of the dealer network? Building a new facility in Chicago.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we have a -- 2 facilities. One in Salt Lake City, one in Spartanburg. And as there are more larger -- the average order size of transactions increases over time or those involved trade activity. And the participate with our dealers in consummating
componenttext: Yes, so we have a -- 2 facilities. One in Salt Lake City, one in Spartanburg. And as there are more larger -- the average order size of transactions increases over time or those involved trade activity. And the participate with our dealers in consummating those transactions. And so we want to have a very efficient way, effective way of selling those used trucks into the marketplace. And so the system enhances our capability. And I think we'll see some additional investments over the coming years in used truck distribution capabilities.

componenttext: Okay. And that's impressive, and the other number was a little higher than I would have thought 1Q to 2Q, so again I apologize. I might have missed it. What was the strength in the other geography to go from 3,300 units up to 3,900, you're talking deliveries units.

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just big picture question. I mean, I'm just trying to think about units versus gross margins, your units this past quarter, if you look back over the last couple of years may be if you look at third quarter of 2014, and say okay, similar units. In fact, a little bit lower, but the gross margins are nearly 200 basis points higher. Can you just characterize for us, just so we have a better understanding because the parts revenue from them, they're not really much higher as a percent of total revenue. So you can't say it's just parts mix. That 200 bps, how would you characterize A, lower input costs? B, I know you're going to say, the great work of your people, lowering the cost, I understand that. But may be that bucket as well. And another key difference is the European shipments are a higher percent of the total now than a couple of years ago. So may we're not appreciating the profitability of Europe as the mix is going in that direction. Just trying to help understand the framework of similar units at 200 basis points higher gross margins. How would you bucket that improvement?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think your first 2 comments were to pertinent to input costs. We've benefited from lower input costs. In 2014, we were still transitioning to the Euro 6 product into the factories. We were ramping up the 2.1-meter product. And we were gaining a lo
componenttext: Well, I think your first 2 comments were to pertinent to input costs. We've benefited from lower input costs. In 2014, we were still transitioning to the Euro 6 product into the factories. We were ramping up the 2.1-meter product. And we were gaining a lot of ground with the MX engine production over that period. And so the efficiencies that have come with being 2 years after some of those transitions, getting the full benefit of the 2.1 meter their products and our North American factories. All those factors have added and incremented that operating margin. So that -- those are sort of the key elements of it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, the capturing of the Euro 5 pricing, that was harder to get initially would -- just when you look at -- again it's not perfect math. You try to figure out the average price per truck, in Europe by the units and the revenue, it doesn't app
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, the capturing of the Euro 5 pricing, that was harder to get initially would -- just when you look at -- again it's not perfect math. You try to figure out the average price per truck, in Europe by the units and the revenue, it doesn't appear that we don't have the mix exactly within it. The average truck has gone up that much. So big initially, if you recapture the Euro 5 pricing more now than a couple of years ago maybe the...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not so much the pricing as it is, the operating efficiency. The Euro 5 to Euro 6 transition was occurred in a short period of time. And as you get past the launch period, you start achieving the operating efficiencies and performance in the field tha
componenttext: It's not so much the pricing as it is, the operating efficiency. The Euro 5 to Euro 6 transition was occurred in a short period of time. And as you get past the launch period, you start achieving the operating efficiencies and performance in the field that goes with the enhanced products. So I think that's just what we've seen over that couple of year period.

componenttext: A quick question on Financial Services. I saw that margins are down a few points in the first half in the prior year. Is what we saw in the first half similar to what we suspect in the back half of the year? Or if we look at prior years, the margins are actually a little bit higher in second half versus the first half in other years, it could happen again this year. Just kind of your outlook on the financial margins in the back half would be helpful.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the second half would be comparable to the first half. As I mentioned earlier, the first half of this year compared to last year was primarily the effect of lower used truck prices and the resell of used trucks that come off lease in our Fina
componenttext: Yes, I think the second half would be comparable to the first half. As I mentioned earlier, the first half of this year compared to last year was primarily the effect of lower used truck prices and the resell of used trucks that come off lease in our Financial Services operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I also wanted to turn secondly, to Brazil. Obviously, it's still small for you guys. You haven't really mentioned much. But is there any kind of [indiscernible] can say, since last quarter, has it gotten worse in Brazil or in your opinion, be
componenttext: Okay, great. I also wanted to turn secondly, to Brazil. Obviously, it's still small for you guys. You haven't really mentioned much. But is there any kind of [indiscernible] can say, since last quarter, has it gotten worse in Brazil or in your opinion, better or do you think that 2017 could be a better year, if perhaps it's about coming out?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say based on some recent visits to Brazil that there's I guess positive momentum in the country with the transition of leadership. And the feedback that we get from our customers and our dealers, the product is being very, very well received. Dealers
componenttext: I'd say based on some recent visits to Brazil that there's I guess positive momentum in the country with the transition of leadership. And the feedback that we get from our customers and our dealers, the product is being very, very well received. Dealers are enthusiastic about the long-term future as are we. And what we need is just the market. The market is going to be 35,000 trucks or so this year. That's down from a peak of 100,000. We're continuing to increase our deliveries and our share, albeit at lower -- low levels. But the opportunities definitely there. Our team has done a great job of positioning the brand, establishing the parts and service capabilities. So I think there's going to be a nice upside as we progress. And I'm hopeful that 2017 is going to be a stronger year than 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I do a follow-up to that question? Also on the sort of margin in Brazil. Could Brazil eventually be your best margin business or up there, with the other businesses once it's kind of a bit higher on volume rates going forward?
componenttext: Can I do a follow-up to that question? Also on the sort of margin in Brazil. Could Brazil eventually be your best margin business or up there, with the other businesses once it's kind of a bit higher on volume rates going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at the history of Brazil and those are peak markets, they were very strong margins in that market. And so there's no reason that can't happen again. But that's a ways away.
componenttext: If you look at the history of Brazil and those are peak markets, they were very strong margins in that market. And so there's no reason that can't happen again. But that's a ways away.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Baudendistel with Stifel.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you if what your long-term growth outlook is for the parts business. I mean historically, you've done a great job of growing that well ahead of the other markets 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% a year, but I'm just wondering what your expectation in lig
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you if what your long-term growth outlook is for the parts business. I mean historically, you've done a great job of growing that well ahead of the other markets 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% a year, but I'm just wondering what your expectation in light of the investments you made there and in light of the fact that we could be in a period of lower Class A production that we've had in the past 2 years?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at the history of our parts business, the last 10 years has grown at an average annual rate 6%, 7% per year. And I don't see any reason why that can't be a comparable pace as you go forward. We continue to invest. We just -- in J
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at the history of our parts business, the last 10 years has grown at an average annual rate 6%, 7% per year. And I don't see any reason why that can't be a comparable pace as you go forward. We continue to invest. We just -- in June, had the grand opening of our new distribution center in Renton, here in the state of Washington. We're looking at additional distribution center expansions or new locations both in our North America and Europe, and looking at some of the other countries supporting that distribution capability as well. The team continues to invest. And their e-commerce capabilities, their support of dealer programs, making it this easy to do business with PACCAR Parts as possible. The expansion of their TRP brands and PACCAR packaging. So there's no reason that the team couldn't continue to grow that business sort of beyond and get a bigger share of that parts -- after market parts market.

componenttext: On Europe, delivery trends just seeing sequentially the delivery volumes step down a little bit and then just with seasonality and some plant shutdowns expected to step down a little bit more in 3Q and then comparing that versus seeing the guidance step up, I guess it was in the first quarter of last year, deliveries were very strong. And should we be anticipating a similar type of volume in the fourth quarter of this year, just given the strength of Europe and no apparent impact of Brexit?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- a lot of that delivery volume is driven by the number of work days and fourth quarter for DAF typically has the highest number of workdays in their year. So all other things being equal, the fourth quarter is typically one of their stronger quar
componenttext: So the -- a lot of that delivery volume is driven by the number of work days and fourth quarter for DAF typically has the highest number of workdays in their year. So all other things being equal, the fourth quarter is typically one of their stronger quarters.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of when you think you'll have greater confidence in terms of kind of we transition out of the summer low and order activity in North America, will it take -- when does inquiry activity really start to pick up for you? We won't
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of when you think you'll have greater confidence in terms of kind of we transition out of the summer low and order activity in North America, will it take -- when does inquiry activity really start to pick up for you? We won't see it and actual orders I guess, until you get to October and seasonality picks up. But when do you start to feel more confident around the visibility you have to 2017? Just knowing it was the third quarter of last year when you started to take build rates down towards the end of that. We didn't hear anything about that in the second quarter of last year. Just trying to think about when you will have a firmer feel for exactly how to manage to shaping up into '17?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we obviously monitor orders daily. So we're very vigilant. And we base our production on the level of order activity. And so as we progress through the summer, get to the September, October time frame, it's typically when we sort of gauge the level
componenttext: Well, we obviously monitor orders daily. So we're very vigilant. And we base our production on the level of order activity. And so as we progress through the summer, get to the September, October time frame, it's typically when we sort of gauge the level of order activity for the rest of the year, and how things might shape up for the beginning of 2017. So 3 months from now, we'll talk about what are our initial expectations are for early '17 and also at this point.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Two small ones for me. Just a clarification on the steel, and which I think you said was firming up, but not going to be really material near-term. componenttext: Yes, I think again, we have long-term arrangements with our suppliers that sort of feed the cost movements into to the product over time. So I think at this point, it's not just a significant item and we continued to obviously, work on other suppliers to some elements of cost reductions and incorporating new technologies and new materials into our products. And so there's always some ongoing cost-reduction efforts that we have that tend to offset some of the commodity costs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

Maybe I'm reading your press release to closely, but when you mentioned investing for future growth and PACCAR integrated power training components, does that reference the 11-meter and the refuse and the things that you talked about in the release or is that a future as yet unreleased powertrain changes?

componenttextpreview: Well, we just -- we continue to work very closely with our suppliers of transmissions, axles, aftertreatment and get -- be able to achieve the integration of their products -- our products to provide our customers with the most significant powertrains in
componenttext: Well, we just -- we continue to work very closely with our suppliers of transmissions, axles, aftertreatment and get -- be able to achieve the integration of their products -- our products to provide our customers with the most significant powertrains in the industry. As so that's our focus. Is to continue to have calibrations and capabilities that are customized and suited to our powertrain technologies.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we contemplate potential impacts at some point from Brexit, can you just share within Europe, how much of the revenue is in the U.K? And that if there's any difference of how much of the cost structure is kind of U.K. and pound-denominat
componenttext: Okay. And then as we contemplate potential impacts at some point from Brexit, can you just share within Europe, how much of the revenue is in the U.K? And that if there's any difference of how much of the cost structure is kind of U.K. and pound-denominated versus euro-denominated?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have the benefit of having manufacturing operations in the U.K. We're the only OEM to have that. So we have a partial offset to our revenues that we earn out of the U.K. So the impact, as we see it for 2016, is relatively insignificant. And assuming
componenttext: So we have the benefit of having manufacturing operations in the U.K. We're the only OEM to have that. So we have a partial offset to our revenues that we earn out of the U.K. So the impact, as we see it for 2016, is relatively insignificant. And assuming the currency stays at its current level, then the OEMs will make pricing adjustments to achieve a reasonable margin on their businesses in the U.K. over time. So we don't see it as being a major factor in our margins over time.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just could you put some numbers around the size of U.K. for you in broader Europe?

componenttext: So it's about 25% of our revenues for DAF.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to -- a lot of my questions have been asked. But I just want to dig in a little bit deeper on the question that David Raso was asking on costs versus may be benefits from sourcing parts in different locations. So 2 questions. Number one, if I
componenttext: I just want to -- a lot of my questions have been asked. But I just want to dig in a little bit deeper on the question that David Raso was asking on costs versus may be benefits from sourcing parts in different locations. So 2 questions. Number one, if I look at your revenue per unit, it was down about 5%. I wanted to disaggregate what's a mix issue versus a currency issue versus what actual pricing is doing? And then the same thing with cost. If I take a look at may be how currency is affecting cost per unit, raw materials affecting cost per unit versus what's volume related. How do I think about those buckets?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, what you're comparing -- if you're comparing back to 2014 to now, clearly currency has had a sizable impact on the revenue side, but also on the cost side. And the cost side has gone down over that period of time because of the excellent factory
componenttext: So again, what you're comparing -- if you're comparing back to 2014 to now, clearly currency has had a sizable impact on the revenue side, but also on the cost side. And the cost side has gone down over that period of time because of the excellent factory efficiencies that we've gained with our new products, the performance of those products in the field, the material cost savings. The benefits of commodities, and just ongoing, working with our suppliers to incorporate new materials, new technology and the products to achieve better operating efficiency and cost levels. So for us, it's -- the MX engine penetration has been beneficial in that as well. So all those things are the elements that are driving that enhancement over that period of time

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. And if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at any time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Has
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Today's call is being recorded. And if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at any time. 
I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. And joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. And joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and Controller. 
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. 
Certain information presented today will be forward looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions, that may affect expected results.
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the second quarter of 2016. PACCAR's second quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and second quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $372
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and excellent operating income for the second quarter of 2016. PACCAR's second quarter sales and financial services revenues were $4.4 billion and second quarter adjusted net income, a non-GAAP measure, was $372 million and 8.4% after-tax return on revenues. Adjusted net income excludes a favorable $109 million adjustment to the reserve established in the first quarter this year, reflecting the settlement of the European Commission investigation.  Including the reserve adjustment, PACCAR reported net income of $481 million in the second quarter. 
PACCAR achieved excellent Truck, Parts and Other gross margins of 15.2%, driven by Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF's premium products; DAF's strong 16% market share; a robust European truck market and rigorous cost control. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. 
PACCAR delivered 36,700 trucks during the second quarter, in line with our expectations. Deliveries in Europe were 17% higher than last year's second quarter. 
In the third quarter, PACCAR deliveries will be slightly lower than the second quarter due to the normal summer shutdown at DAF. Third quarter gross margins are projected to remain strong but down slightly from the second quarter margins due to the lower production in Europe. PACCAR's industry-leading operating margins reflect the benefits of DAF, Peterbilt and Kenworth's new truck models, record plant operating efficiency, good truck markets and continued material cost savings. 
We've raised our forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market to a range of 280,000 to 300,000 units, reflecting strong demand and the steady economic outlook. 
The Eurozone's GDP growth expectations for this year are 1.5%. Freight transport activity on German highways in the first half of this year was up 3.4% over the same period last year. Since the vote in the U.K. to exit the European Union, DAF's truck orders, parts and service sales and finance business continue at strong levels comparable to the period prior to the vote. 
The economic picture in the U.S. is positive with GDP forecast to grow 1.9% this year. The housing and automotive industries create a large amount of freight. Housing starts are projected to grow 11% this year to 1.2 million, and the automotive industry is expected to deliver 17.2 million vehicles, similar to last year's record sales. 
The ISM Manufacturing Index has been over 50, indicating expansion for the last 4 months. Consumer spending and disposable income are outgrowing the overall economy, which is supportive of freight in the truck industry. 
We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in a range of 220,000 to 240,000 units this year, which is the third best in the last decade. 
Peterbilt and Kenworth's combined retail sales market share of the U.S. and Canadian market was 28% in the second quarter. Our share of net orders, so far this year, is strong at 34% as customers benefit from Kenworth and Peterbilt's reliable, fuel-efficient trucks and industry-leading resale values. 
PACCAR Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $756 million, a 5% increase compared to the first quarter. PACCAR Parts quarterly pretax income was $133 million with a return on revenues of 17.6%. These results were driven by good fleet utilization, the growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. Second half Parts sales are expected to improve from first half levels. 
PACCAR Financial Services second quarter pretax income was $77 million. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. During the quarter, PACCAR Financial began providing retail financing in Romania, its 23rd country of operation. PACCAR Financial also acquired land in the Chicago area to construct a new used truck center and expanded sales of Kenworth and Peterbilt premium used trucks. 
PACCAR's strong balance sheet and cash flows have enabled the company to invest $6 billion in new products and facilities in the last 10 years. 
PACCAR achieved record net operating cash flow of $1.6 billion in the first half of 2016. 
PACCAR's capital spending of $325 million to $375 million this year is targeted at enhanced aftermarket support, manufacturing facilities and new product development. 
Research and development expenses are estimated to be in a range of $240 million to $260 million. 
PACCAR continues to enhance its leadership position in the global truck market by developing the highest quality products and services in the industry. 
Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

componenttext: Maybe just if I could ask you to sort of give us an update on how you see your industry inventory levels in North America and in Europe. componenttext: The dealer inventories are in excellent shape in both of our key markets, North America and Europe, and they have been. We adjusted build rates in the second half of last year and the balance with demand, and we've been -- have steady inventories and steady build during the first half of this year and projected to see that continue for the second half of this year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And maybe just a quick follow-up. Retail sales have been running, obviously, ahead of orders for a while. And I guess the market maybe is having a little bit of trouble figuring out whether we should be paying more attention to one versus the
componenttext: Okay, great. And maybe just a quick follow-up. Retail sales have been running, obviously, ahead of orders for a while. And I guess the market maybe is having a little bit of trouble figuring out whether we should be paying more attention to one versus the other. Is it your view that orders will sort of recover to retail levels once inventories get in shape? Or do you think that once people take deliveries of these trucks, the order rates will continue to be lower and things will sort of take another step down?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there's a lot of trucks still being produced on some of the backlog, and so I think orders will come back to better reflect what retail sales activity is. The great news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth, because of their approach to building tru
componenttext: No. I think there's a lot of trucks still being produced on some of the backlog, and so I think orders will come back to better reflect what retail sales activity is. The great news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth, because of their approach to building trucks to customer orders, they've gotten a higher share of the orders during the first half of the year to just under 35%. So they've done a great job of supporting our customers.

componenttext: I guess just a couple of questions. One, well, I know you won't give the official retail sales forecast outlook until next quarter. You've seen some industry experts in the U.S. like ACT. I mean, they've taken down their forecast for '17. They're now assuming a down year. You guys have within the -- and then I guess with Europe, there are some greater concerns on the longer-term implications of Brexit and how that impacts things. So I guess my question is I know you're not going to give a specific number, but do you think the market is too bearish on '17? Or given what you see today, is it fair to assume that '17 would be down in the U.S.? And then given that you raised your forecast in here, but it appears you're not that worried about Brexit but just sort of your thoughts there. And then my second question is you said PACCAR inventory -- dealer inventories were good. I don't think you answered or talked about what you're seeing from the competitors. If you could provide any color there.

componenttextpreview: Well, based on the information we have about dealer inventories, I think we're probably below where some of the competition are with respect to their inventory positions. But we're very comfortable with where we're at in both Europe and North America. Wit
componenttext: Well, based on the information we have about dealer inventories, I think we're probably below where some of the competition are with respect to their inventory positions. But we're very comfortable with where we're at in both Europe and North America. With respect to 2017, I guess based on as we sit here today, it feels like some of the negative forecast feel a bit bearish at this point. That's about all I can say at this point.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the extent of market share gains, both in the U.S. and in Europe, share is typically hard to come by in this industry, and it's tougher to hold on to. So you're 6 months in to a pretty big share spike or share improvement. Do you think that can hold? Obviously, your residual values, particularly at Peterbilt, are well above what the industry is doing. So I'd imagine that's a big positive. But are there things with the new product lineup or other intangibles with PACCAR where you think 34%, 35% that doesn't just need to be the first 6 months. It could be a 2016 outcome ultimately?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again that's orders in terms of retail sales the second quarter. Peterbilt and Kenworth are 28% and reflecting the great products and services with Parts and Finance that we provide through our dealer network. We have the strongest dealer network. S
componenttext: Well, again that's orders in terms of retail sales the second quarter. Peterbilt and Kenworth are 28% and reflecting the great products and services with Parts and Finance that we provide through our dealer network. We have the strongest dealer network. So when I started with the company, Peterbilt and Kenworth were 21%, and they've grown to 28% over a period of time. And over the 20-year period we've owned DAF, we've gone from less than 10% to 16%. So we have a long-term track record of incrementing that share. And I think that's our focus. And with the product lineup and the support activities that we have in place today, that will continue to be our focus to achieve those increments.

componenttext: I think it's -- looking at the results of our -- some of our customers, those that are reported, you see the results are still good. They're not maybe as buoyant as they were a year ago but still good, solid results. And I think a lot of their decisions about truck orders will be driven by the economic conditions. We've seen lower orders in the first half. And as we talked about it, I think we'll see orders pick up and customers start to place orders to get into their positioning for 2017 build slots.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And those come for North America?
componenttext: And those come for North America?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think both markets.
componenttext: I think both markets.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on used prices, we've seen softness in used equipment prices. Could you talk about your brand's used pricing? And also, does that have any impact on PACCAR leasing? And is there any downside risk on residual values for past leasing?
componenttext: Okay. And then on used prices, we've seen softness in used equipment prices. Could you talk about your brand's used pricing? And also, does that have any impact on PACCAR leasing? And is there any downside risk on residual values for past leasing?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So used truck prices in Europe are pretty steady. They have been, and we've -- we're starting to see a few Euro 6 trucks into the market. And the Euro 6 -- DAF Euro 6 trucks are really earning a nice premium in the used market. In North America, we have s
componenttext: So used truck prices in Europe are pretty steady. They have been, and we've -- we're starting to see a few Euro 6 trucks into the market. And the Euro 6 -- DAF Euro 6 trucks are really earning a nice premium in the used market. In North America, we have seen a reduction. Several of our competitors have sizable quantities of used truck inventories. That sort of dampened the entire market. The good news is that Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to enjoy 10% to 15% premium relative to the competition, and that's part of the impact on PACCAR Financial Services last year. We were earning nice gains with a buoyant used truck market this year. Those gains have gone down as a result of just lower average sales prices.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any residual value risks?
componenttext: And any residual value risks?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. I think we'd look at that every quarter and adjust our residual values based on the current market at that time, and so that's been reflected in our quarterly results.
componenttext: No, no. I think we'd look at that every quarter and adjust our residual values based on the current market at that time, and so that's been reflected in our quarterly results.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher with UBS.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonder if you could just talk about the duration of your backlog today, how it's changed over the last few months and the visibility that you have for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Wonder if you could just talk about the duration of your backlog today, how it's changed over the last few months and the visibility that you have for the rest of the year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, orders have been -- let's talk about Europe first. Orders have been, as I mentioned, very, very good, and we have a solid backlog. And we're anticipating that we'll probably increase our daily build rates during the course of the second half. And No
componenttext: Well, orders have been -- let's talk about Europe first. Orders have been, as I mentioned, very, very good, and we have a solid backlog. And we're anticipating that we'll probably increase our daily build rates during the course of the second half. And North America, orders have been below production of retail sales. So we continue to produce trucks that were ordered in 2015, and so -- but that -- we've got some good solid orders in the backlog, and we'll continue to build those trucks as well as the orders that are coming in on an ongoing basis.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then shifting over to the Parts side of the business, how do you see the margin opportunity for Parts going forward? One of your competitors recorded a pretty notable -- notably high number. Can you just refresh us on sort of the rebranding stra
componenttext: Okay. And then shifting over to the Parts side of the business, how do you see the margin opportunity for Parts going forward? One of your competitors recorded a pretty notable -- notably high number. Can you just refresh us on sort of the rebranding strategies you have here to augment Parts margins and where do you see these margins going from here?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we develop new products and have developed new products over the years, we always get enhancing our proprietary content of our vehicles. And obviously, with the increasing mix of MX engines in the truck park in North America, that's going to enha
componenttext: Well, as we develop new products and have developed new products over the years, we always get enhancing our proprietary content of our vehicles. And obviously, with the increasing mix of MX engines in the truck park in North America, that's going to enhance our margin opportunity over time with respect to engine parts. But we also are trying to focus a lot on selling parts, our TRP lineup of all makes, and those have a little bit narrows margin on those, so it's a balance. And so I'd say margins will be fairly consistent with what we've seen in the recent quarterly performance.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about your key partners as you develop the autonomous vehicle platform, whether it's DAF or Peterbilt or Kenworth or whoever's taking the lead on that. If you could just, to the extent you're willing to comment, talk about th
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about your key partners as you develop the autonomous vehicle platform, whether it's DAF or Peterbilt or Kenworth or whoever's taking the lead on that. If you could just, to the extent you're willing to comment, talk about the time frame of when you expect to have the commercial product. Nice to see the progress in put tuning, I'm wondering if you're willing to flesh that out a bit more for us.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, it's very early days with the advanced driver-assistant systems. And all of the divisions are actively engaged in discussions with suppliers across divisional lines, technology companies. Really, there's a lot of participants that we thin
componenttext: Well, obviously, it's very early days with the advanced driver-assistant systems. And all of the divisions are actively engaged in discussions with suppliers across divisional lines, technology companies. Really, there's a lot of participants that we think can help support our entrance into those technologies, so we're very active. And it's going to be probably more than 5 years before you see something on the road that is fully autonomous and operating day to day. Don't know how long that will be, but it's something that everybody is focused on. And we're making some sizable investments in the technologies and capabilities in that area.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then from a shorter-term standpoint, can you talk about what was pricing in the quarter for you in U.S. and Europe? And the first quarter 10-Q looks like there was a modest headwind in Europe. I'm wondering if it was that just the timing phenome
componenttext: Okay. And then from a shorter-term standpoint, can you talk about what was pricing in the quarter for you in U.S. and Europe? And the first quarter 10-Q looks like there was a modest headwind in Europe. I'm wondering if it was that just the timing phenomenon. Can you talk about if pricing turned positive in Europe in the second quarter?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think pricing in Europe is pretty -- is relatively steady and has been for some time, and U.S. pricing is also steady. Obviously, the lower used truck prices can impact large transaction to do with fleets. But that's -- I'd say the pricing in both marke
componenttext: I think pricing in Europe is pretty -- is relatively steady and has been for some time, and U.S. pricing is also steady. Obviously, the lower used truck prices can impact large transaction to do with fleets. But that's -- I'd say the pricing in both markets is pretty consistent.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, I'm wondering if you're willing to talk about what order inquiry levels have been like in Europe in July just to calibrate us. What you're hearing from your customers post-Brexit, if you're willing to comment directionally?
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, I'm wondering if you're willing to talk about what order inquiry levels have been like in Europe in July just to calibrate us. What you're hearing from your customers post-Brexit, if you're willing to comment directionally?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So post-Brexit, I guess, as I said in my comments, the order activity and inquiries continue at good solid rates. We have our range estimate for the European market. And as I mentioned, we're going to be enhancing our build rate in the second half in
componenttext: Yes. So post-Brexit, I guess, as I said in my comments, the order activity and inquiries continue at good solid rates. We have our range estimate for the European market. And as I mentioned, we're going to be enhancing our build rate in the second half in Europe to reflect that demand.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with BMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with BMO.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On medium duty, can you just talk about where your share is trending? I'm just trying to gauge the success of the new products that you guys rolled out, maybe like a 3-year view of what's happened to your share there.
componenttext: On medium duty, can you just talk about where your share is trending? I'm just trying to gauge the success of the new products that you guys rolled out, maybe like a 3-year view of what's happened to your share there.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the medium-duty product is the same excellent product that we've had in the market for the last several years. And last year, we achieved a record share of 17.2%, and we're in that same range. It was slightly lower than that year-to-date this year. The
componenttext: So the medium-duty product is the same excellent product that we've had in the market for the last several years. And last year, we achieved a record share of 17.2%, and we're in that same range. It was slightly lower than that year-to-date this year. The medium-duty market is -- last year was in Class 6 and 7 where we participate was about 80,000 trucks. And we think that market is going to be comparable to that level this year. And the durability and again the residual value of those trucks is great in the market, well received by our customers.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just help us to understand the incentive for you guys to sell used trucks outside of the dealer network, building a new facility in Chicago?
componenttext: Can you just help us to understand the incentive for you guys to sell used trucks outside of the dealer network, building a new facility in Chicago?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have a -- 2 facilities. One in Salt Lake City. One in Spartanburg. And as there are more larger -- the average order size of transactions increases over time. More of those involve trade activity, and we participate with our dealers in consumma
componenttext: Yes. So we have a -- 2 facilities. One in Salt Lake City. One in Spartanburg. And as there are more larger -- the average order size of transactions increases over time. More of those involve trade activity, and we participate with our dealers in consummating those transactions. And so we want to have a very efficient way and effective way of selling those used trucks into the marketplace, and so the system enhances our capability. And I think we'll see some additional investments over the coming years in used truck distribution capabilities.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with ISI.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Maybe I missed this, I apologize. The second quarter to third quarter progression, you highlighted the DAF shutdown, but did you express North America or let's just say U.S., Canada and other? How do you view them sequentially 2Q, 3Q?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The change from second to third, I think will be down 500 to 1,000 truck. And substantially, all of that is Europe.
componenttext: Yes. The change from second to third, I think will be down 500 to 1,000 truck. And substantially, all of that is Europe.

componenttext: Okay. So U.S., Canada, you expect to be similar to the 19,800 you just posted...

componenttextpreview: Yes. North America numbers will be comparable.
componenttext: Yes. North America numbers will be comparable.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and that's impressive. And the other number was a little higher than I would have thought, 1Q to 2Q. So again, I apologize. I might have missed it. What was the strength in the other geography to go from 3,300 units up to 3,900, talking deliveries u
componenttext: Okay, and that's impressive. And the other number was a little higher than I would have thought, 1Q to 2Q. So again, I apologize. I might have missed it. What was the strength in the other geography to go from 3,300 units up to 3,900, talking deliveries units?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that was primarily some additional units delivered in Mexico.
componenttext: Yes. I think that was primarily some additional units delivered in Mexico.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just big-picture question. I mean, just trying to think about units versus gross margins. Your units this past quarter, if you look back over the last couple of years, maybe if you look at third quarter of 2014, and say, "Okay, s
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just big-picture question. I mean, just trying to think about units versus gross margins. Your units this past quarter, if you look back over the last couple of years, maybe if you look at third quarter of 2014, and say, "Okay, similar units. In fact, a little bit lower," but the gross margins are nearly 200 basis points higher. Can you just characterize for us, just so we have a better understanding, because the Parts revenue from then, they're not really much higher as a percent of total revenue. So you can't say it's just Parts mix. That 200 bps, how much would you characterize, a, lower input costs; b, I know you're going to say the great work of your people lowering the cost. I understand that, but maybe that bucket as well. And another key difference is the European shipments are a higher percent of the total now than a couple of years ago. So maybe we're not appreciating the profitability of Europe as the mix is going in that direction. Just trying to help understand the framework of similar units but 200 basis points higher gross margins. How would you bucket that improvement?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think your first 2 comments were to pertinent to input costs. We've benefited from lower input costs. In 2014, we were still transitioning to the Euro 6 product into the factories. We were ramping up the 2.1-meter product, and we were gaining a lo
componenttext: Well, I think your first 2 comments were to pertinent to input costs. We've benefited from lower input costs. In 2014, we were still transitioning to the Euro 6 product into the factories. We were ramping up the 2.1-meter product, and we were gaining a lot of ground with the MX engine production over that period. And so the efficiencies that have come with being 2 years after some of those transitions, getting the full benefit of the 2.1-meter products and our North American factories, all those factors have added and incremented that operating margin. So that -- those are sort of the key elements of it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, the capturing of the Euro 5 pricing, that was harder to get initially would -- just when you look at -- again, it's not perfect math. You try to figure out the average price per truck in Europe by the units and the revenue. It doesn't app
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, the capturing of the Euro 5 pricing, that was harder to get initially would -- just when you look at -- again, it's not perfect math. You try to figure out the average price per truck in Europe by the units and the revenue. It doesn't appear that we don't have the mix exactly within it that the price of the average truck has gone up that much. So I'm thinking initially if you recapture the Euro 5 pricing more now than a couple of years ago maybe the...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not so much the pricing as it is, the operating efficiency. The Euro 5 to Euro 6 transition was -- occurred in a short period of time. And as you get past the launch period, you start achieving the operating efficiencies and performance in the field
componenttext: It's not so much the pricing as it is, the operating efficiency. The Euro 5 to Euro 6 transition was -- occurred in a short period of time. And as you get past the launch period, you start achieving the operating efficiencies and performance in the field that goes with the enhanced products. And so I think that's just what we've seen over that couple of year period.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's fair. So do you have a warranty number that maybe you can help us with, the warranty provisions? Particularly in Europe from this discussion, how much they've come down in the last couple of years?
componenttext: So that's fair. So do you have a warranty number that maybe you can help us with, the warranty provisions? Particularly in Europe from this discussion, how much they've come down in the last couple of years?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that. But that certainly is something that's been enhancement in our results is the...
componenttext: I don't have that. But that certainly is something that's been enhancement in our results is the...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on Financial Services. I saw that margins are down a few points in the first half from the prior year. Is what we saw in the first half similar to what we suspect in the back half of the year? Or if we look at prior years, the margins are a
componenttext: Quick question on Financial Services. I saw that margins are down a few points in the first half from the prior year. Is what we saw in the first half similar to what we suspect in the back half of the year? Or if we look at prior years, the margins are actually a little bit higher in the second half versus the first half in other years. Could it happen again this year? Just your kind of outlook on the financial margins for the back half would be helpful.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the second half would be comparable to the first half. As I mentioned earlier, this -- the first half of this year compared to last year was the -- was primarily the effect of lower used truck prices and the resell of used trucks that come of
componenttext: Yes. I think the second half would be comparable to the first half. As I mentioned earlier, this -- the first half of this year compared to last year was the -- was primarily the effect of lower used truck prices and the resell of used trucks that come off lease in our Financial Services operations.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I also wanted to turn, secondly, to Brazil. Obviously, it's still small for you guys. You haven't really mentioned much. But is there any kind of outlook you can say, since last quarter, have things gotten worse in Brazil in your opinion or b
componenttext: Okay, great. I also wanted to turn, secondly, to Brazil. Obviously, it's still small for you guys. You haven't really mentioned much. But is there any kind of outlook you can say, since last quarter, have things gotten worse in Brazil in your opinion or better? And do you feel like maybe 2017 could be a better year if it's perhaps bottoming out here?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say based on some recent visits to Brazil that there's, I guess, positive momentum in the country with the transition of leadership. And the feedback that we get from our customers and our dealers, the product is being very well received. Dealers are
componenttext: I'd say based on some recent visits to Brazil that there's, I guess, positive momentum in the country with the transition of leadership. And the feedback that we get from our customers and our dealers, the product is being very well received. Dealers are enthusiastic about the long-term future as are we, and what we need is just the market. The market is going to be 35,000 trucks or so this year. That's down from a peak of 100,000. We're continuing to increase our deliveries and our share, albeit at lower -- low levels. But the opportunity is definitely there. Our team has done a great job of positioning the brand, establishing the parts and service capabilities. So I think there's going to be a nice upside as we progress, and I'm hopeful that 2017 is going to be a stronger year than 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I do a follow-up to that question? Also, on the sort of margin in Brazil. Could Brazil eventually be your best margin business or out there with the other businesses once it's kind of -- at a bit higher volume rates going forward?
componenttext: Can I do a follow-up to that question? Also, on the sort of margin in Brazil. Could Brazil eventually be your best margin business or out there with the other businesses once it's kind of -- at a bit higher volume rates going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at the history of Brazil in those are peak markets, there were very strong margins in that market. And so there's no reason that can't happen again, but that's a ways away.
componenttext: If you look at the history of Brazil in those are peak markets, there were very strong margins in that market. And so there's no reason that can't happen again, but that's a ways away.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Baudendistel with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Baudendistel with Stifel.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you if what your long-term growth outlook is for the Parts business. I mean, historically, you've done a great job of growing that well ahead of the other markets, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% a year. But I'm just wondering what your expectation is i
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you if what your long-term growth outlook is for the Parts business. I mean, historically, you've done a great job of growing that well ahead of the other markets, 5%, 6%, 7%, 8% a year. But I'm just wondering what your expectation is in light of the investments you've made there and in light of the fact that we could be in it for a period of lower Class A production than we've had the past few years.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at the history of our Parts business, the last 10 years has grown at an average annual rate 6%, 7% per year, and I don't see any reason that can't be a comparable pace as we go forward. We continue to invest. We just, in June, ha
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at the history of our Parts business, the last 10 years has grown at an average annual rate 6%, 7% per year, and I don't see any reason that can't be a comparable pace as we go forward. We continue to invest. We just, in June, had the grand opening of our new distribution center in Renton here in the state of Washington. We're looking at additional distribution center expansions or new locations, both in North America and Europe, and looking at some of the other countries supporting that distribution capability as well. The team continues to invest. And their e-commerce capabilities, their support of dealer programs, making it as easy to do business with PACCAR Parts as possible, expansion of their TRP brands and PACCAR branding. So there's no reason that the team can't continue to grow that business sort of beyond and get a bigger share of that parts -- aftermarket parts market.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Frohnapple with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Frohnapple with Longbow Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you guys provided a view on Parts segment sales for the second half. Sorry if I missed this. Did you provide a view on profitability for the second half as well? And would you expect pretax margins to be comparable to second quarter levels or just
componenttext: I know you guys provided a view on Parts segment sales for the second half. Sorry if I missed this. Did you provide a view on profitability for the second half as well? And would you expect pretax margins to be comparable to second quarter levels or just any thoughts there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the pretax relationship to revenues would be consistent to with we've seen historically.
componenttext: Yes. I think the pretax relationship to revenues would be consistent to with we've seen historically.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then with regard to -- can you comment on the MX engine penetration rate in the second quarter in North America, and then just any thoughts on the mix of the MX and your current order board?
