componenttextpreview: Two questions, I guess. One, given that we're sort of at the end of October, can you talk to sort of what you're hearing from the big fleets and sort of how they're thinking about 2017 irregardless of your retail sales forecast or what you're hearing from
componenttext: Two questions, I guess. One, given that we're sort of at the end of October, can you talk to sort of what you're hearing from the big fleets and sort of how they're thinking about 2017 irregardless of your retail sales forecast or what you're hearing from the small and medium-sized fleets? And then, I guess, the second question, on '17, assuming that your retail sales forecast are correct for both the U.S. and Europe, I don't think you talked about this in the prepared remarks, can you talk about where you think gross margins can be, whether they'd be flat, down or up just with some of the market dynamics that are taking place?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our discussions with our customers are really focused on one, the great performance of our products in the market. Discussions have typically centered on, I guess, I would say, a comparable level of investment next year to what they've done this year s
componenttext: So our discussions with our customers are really focused on one, the great performance of our products in the market. Discussions have typically centered on, I guess, I would say, a comparable level of investment next year to what they've done this year sort of small, medium, large, et cetera. I think a lot of that will obviously be dictated by how the economy develops. In terms of gross margins, thinking about next year, obviously, there's a lot of things that will impact that over time. Right now, I would say, our next year margins would be comparable to what we'll see in the fourth quarter this year, plus or minus 0.5% up or down.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, PACCAR was very early at cutting production in late 2015, and you're, sounds like, guiding to a slightly weaker Q4. Are you taking production down another notch in the U.S. right now? And would you suspect that when you do that, you'll be abl
componenttext: Yes, I mean, PACCAR was very early at cutting production in late 2015, and you're, sounds like, guiding to a slightly weaker Q4. Are you taking production down another notch in the U.S. right now? And would you suspect that when you do that, you'll be able to produce in line with retail for 2017, which you're basically guiding flat to down 2% or so?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our approach has always been, for a lot of years, has always been to build based on demand of our customers and our dealers, and our actions with respect to production reflect that. The great news is that in the third quarter, we achieved a record m
componenttext: Well, our approach has always been, for a lot of years, has always been to build based on demand of our customers and our dealers, and our actions with respect to production reflect that. The great news is that in the third quarter, we achieved a record market share for Peterbilt and Kenworth combined in U.S. and Canada of 31%. So great recognition of the great products that they're producing at their factories currently. And we'll continue to build based on what that market demand looks like. So inventories are in great shape. And so I would think that retail would be closely tied to production levels as we move forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just on Parts, with respect to this 18% margin that you've held, I think, for 7 or the last 8 quarters, or somewhere close to that, do you feel like it's sustainable going forward? Because certainly, you've been operating performing at a level
componenttext: Got it. And just on Parts, with respect to this 18% margin that you've held, I think, for 7 or the last 8 quarters, or somewhere close to that, do you feel like it's sustainable going forward? Because certainly, you've been operating performing at a level higher than you were 2 to 3 years ago.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And the team has done a great job with leveraging the operating infrastructure that we have in the Parts business. We've obviously added -- enhanced our Parts distribution capabilities in the northwestern part of the U.S. with the Renton facility. W
componenttext: Sure. And the team has done a great job with leveraging the operating infrastructure that we have in the Parts business. We've obviously added -- enhanced our Parts distribution capabilities in the northwestern part of the U.S. with the Renton facility. We'll be adding some additional facilities in the coming future, all balanced to meet the market demand and ensure that our customers are getting the best support in the industry with keeping their trucks operating on the road. So I think, we'll continue to see that level of performance.

componenttext: Okay. And the if I look at the FIMCO, I'm splitting hairs a little bit, we've seen some really modest increase in the provisions for lots of unreceivables. I mean, it's clearly not close to the levels of call it, 8 years ago or so. But what region is driving that modest increase? Or is it just kind of spread all over the place?

componenttextpreview: It's as you said, it's very modest. The portfolio is performing -- actually that credit loss level is at historically low levels. A few customers in the oil and gas business, but that's what the focus of it.
componenttext: It's as you said, it's very modest. The portfolio is performing -- actually that credit loss level is at historically low levels. A few customers in the oil and gas business, but that's what the focus of it.

componenttext: I didn't really comment on that. But I think the fourth quarter, looking at comparables, revenue levels I think in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just coming back to the U.S. and Canada. Obviously, just given Peterbilt's position based on the market pretty well represented there. It looks as though your overall retail outlook, a little bit more positive in some. But I'm just curious. As we hear fro
componenttext: Just coming back to the U.S. and Canada. Obviously, just given Peterbilt's position based on the market pretty well represented there. It looks as though your overall retail outlook, a little bit more positive in some. But I'm just curious. As we hear from some of the big truck load companies in the past day or 2, it looks like they're pulling back on spending a bit more. So I'm just curious if you could maybe slice your comments on Western Canada more finely between trucks versus tractors for '17? In terms of your expectations for the broader market.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Bob. I think we see a fairly comparable level of buy from both the vocational and over-the-road customers in 2017 from 2016. Both Kenworth and Peterbilt have strong locational presence, I think combined, the company is 35% to 40% market share
componenttext: Tim, this is Bob. I think we see a fairly comparable level of buy from both the vocational and over-the-road customers in 2017 from 2016. Both Kenworth and Peterbilt have strong locational presence, I think combined, the company is 35% to 40% market share in the locational business, which has been very, very good for us over the last couple of years. But increasingly, the new Peterbilts and the new Kenworth are getting even more traction in some of the larger fleets. So we're getting incremental kind of conquest purchases from customers. But on balance, we think that the 2017 is going to look very, very comparable to 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then just coming back to the question earlier on used values. Can you comment on what maybe the MX has been out there long enough, just given normal trade cycles, a little bit more volume to make a call or if you have a little bit more v
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just coming back to the question earlier on used values. Can you comment on what maybe the MX has been out there long enough, just given normal trade cycles, a little bit more volume to make a call or if you have a little bit more visibility on it. Can you just give us some color in terms of how the trucks with the MX earlier had been performing in the secondary markets?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we started get those yields, first trucks are that we built in 2010, '11, are now passing on to the second owner. And I think what we'll see as time goes on is the durability with the CGI steel that we used to build the headed block and just the rigoro
componenttext: So we started get those yields, first trucks are that we built in 2010, '11, are now passing on to the second owner. And I think what we'll see as time goes on is the durability with the CGI steel that we used to build the headed block and just the rigorous testing that we put the engines through that, that will -- should be reflected in the use prices over time as we move forward. So we're very optimistic about how that will progress.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss with BMO.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you keep getting smarter every quarter, by 2019, you'll be able to give us a single point earnings forecast. I wonder in the Parts decline, if you could give us any color in the quarter. If it was more on the volume side or any pricing weakness or mix?
componenttext: If you keep getting smarter every quarter, by 2019, you'll be able to give us a single point earnings forecast. I wonder in the Parts decline, if you could give us any color in the quarter. If it was more on the volume side or any pricing weakness or mix?

componenttextpreview: It's primarily -- it's all volume-related. Not the -- consider the volume of shipments. Yes.
componenttext: It's primarily -- it's all volume-related. Not the -- consider the volume of shipments. Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And since so many of the questions are about sort of doubting your flat forecast for 2017, I just wonder if you could give us a couple of things that we should incorporate into our thinking around levers you can pool to show earnings resiliency in 2017, i
componenttext: And since so many of the questions are about sort of doubting your flat forecast for 2017, I just wonder if you could give us a couple of things that we should incorporate into our thinking around levers you can pool to show earnings resiliency in 2017, if things are a little worse than flat.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we commented on, we continue to make prudent investments in operating efficiency both in our factories, the warehouses. We continue to use more and more technology in our business processes, in our factories and continuing to provide new technolog
componenttext: Yes, as we commented on, we continue to make prudent investments in operating efficiency both in our factories, the warehouses. We continue to use more and more technology in our business processes, in our factories and continuing to provide new technology to our customer. We'll just continue to make those investments. And if you look back at the history, we've got a history of delivering 5% to 7% efficiency and gains over the long-term. And we'll continue to make those kinds of investments as we move into 2017.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a bigger picture question. With the launch of the proprietary axle, should we think about that as the start of -- well, not the start, but kind of the next step in the increase vertical integration? And can you talk about what your ta
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a bigger picture question. With the launch of the proprietary axle, should we think about that as the start of -- well, not the start, but kind of the next step in the increase vertical integration? And can you talk about what your take rate expectations are for that product starting next year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a nice balance of vertical integration with some of our components and great relationships with our suppliers and other areas. And I think we'll continue with that balanced approach for this PACCAR Axel. If you look out probably a year or 2
componenttext: Well, we have a nice balance of vertical integration with some of our components and great relationships with our suppliers and other areas. And I think we'll continue with that balanced approach for this PACCAR Axel. If you look out probably a year or 2 down the road, this axel will probably 30%, 40%, 50% of what we've -- of the axles that we put on our North American vehicles. And of course, the axle we put on our DAF products are 100% PACCAR axels. So we have a combination of vertical and supplier provided. But more and more -- much more of the supplier provided components are proprietary in that they're developed to work in a very efficient manner with the rest of our powertrain component. So you'll continue to see that trend as we move forward going with all of our suppliers.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just from an incumbent initial RAM perspective. Should we think about it as kind of margin neutral in 2017? And it takes a little while to hit critical mass? Or should that be accretive from the get go?
componenttext: And just from an incumbent initial RAM perspective. Should we think about it as kind of margin neutral in 2017? And it takes a little while to hit critical mass? Or should that be accretive from the get go?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it'll be a big factor in terms of market performance.
componenttext: No, I don't think it'll be a big factor in terms of market performance.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up to Andy's question. Within the Financial Services segment. The increase in the interest and other expense in the quarter, what can that be attributed to? It sounds like you struck prices may be not so much. Anything else you can point to
componenttext: A quick follow-up to Andy's question. Within the Financial Services segment. The increase in the interest and other expense in the quarter, what can that be attributed to? It sounds like you struck prices may be not so much. Anything else you can point to there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well it -- the factor is the used truck pricing and reflecting that as adjustments to depreciation expense over time. So as we have trucks return off lease except through that typically runs through the depreciation expense line. So that's one element of
componenttext: Well it -- the factor is the used truck pricing and reflecting that as adjustments to depreciation expense over time. So as we have trucks return off lease except through that typically runs through the depreciation expense line. So that's one element of it, and then the rest of it is just the competitiveness of the market and the spread of interest earned and interest paid. So that's the 2 elements of it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then how are your inventory levels positioned at your used truck centers in North America? Just curious if inventory levels are normal or higher than historical levels?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then how are your inventory levels positioned at your used truck centers in North America? Just curious if inventory levels are normal or higher than historical levels?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say normal. And we're continuing to invest in our ability to support our used truck operations. As time has gone on, we deal with a lot more larger fleets. We're more heavily engaged in taking trade-ins with our customers and working with our
componenttext: Yes, I would say normal. And we're continuing to invest in our ability to support our used truck operations. As time has gone on, we deal with a lot more larger fleets. We're more heavily engaged in taking trade-ins with our customers and working with our dealers. So we'll continue to invest where we're probably going to open by the end of the year, a new facility in the Chicago area and adding some additional capacity in our facility in Salt Lake City. So it's -- I say normal at the higher level just given the higher level of activity we're seeing in trade in's and operating lease activity.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore ISI.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 5% sequential decline 3Q to 4Q. Can you help us with that a little bit sequentially, when it comes to Europe versus other versus U.S. and Canada?
componenttext: The 5% sequential decline 3Q to 4Q. Can you help us with that a little bit sequentially, when it comes to Europe versus other versus U.S. and Canada?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So it's lower operating leverage from a lower production level for the quarter. A slight reduction in price realization in the U.S. and Canada because of the competitive market conditions and small impact from the movement of the pound versus the eu
componenttext: Sure. So it's lower operating leverage from a lower production level for the quarter. A slight reduction in price realization in the U.S. and Canada because of the competitive market conditions and small impact from the movement of the pound versus the euro. The pound is -- while it's down, it certainly within a range that we've seen in the last near-term history. So as time goes on, we'll work through that and prices will adjust to a more normalized margin going forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: And just to be clear, that down 5%, that's a production number? Can I equate that to a unit number as well? I mean, I'm just trying to work off a down 5% sequentially, should be a little over 33,000 units.

componenttext: That's correct.

componenttext: I don't have the specific numbers, Dave. But definitely Europe will be up because of increased workday and we have the summer shutdown. So we have more work days in the fourth quarter plus a slightly higher build rate and that'll be offset by U.S. and Canada.

componenttext: And other usually -- having its usual fourth quarter?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the U.S. Canada outlook for '17, I know it's an industry forecast, not yours. But when I think of the cadence through the year. When we think about retail sales and have been running of late, still down 20%. Orders have been down, up 25%
componenttext: Okay. And then on the U.S. Canada outlook for '17, I know it's an industry forecast, not yours. But when I think of the cadence through the year. When we think about retail sales and have been running of late, still down 20%. Orders have been down, up 25%, 30%. The comps do ease especially for the orders in the spring. Can you take us through your thought process on a down 2 [ph]? Is it an industry order rate starting to turn positive by late spring? And is it sort of a unit sales kind of down, high single digit in the first half, up? High single-digit in the second half, a little bit more than that? Just trying to think how back half loaded is it, but appreciating that the orders at some point, you hope turn positive given the comps get easier or accumulate on that.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, all the OEMs have been building trucks out of the backlog throughout this year. So I think you'll see the conversions of order, levels, retail sales, production et cetera or whatever the run rate will be. And I think our feeling is that as we get pas
componenttext: Yes, all the OEMs have been building trucks out of the backlog throughout this year. So I think you'll see the conversions of order, levels, retail sales, production et cetera or whatever the run rate will be. And I think our feeling is that as we get past the first year, we'll see some progression given the economic assumptions about continued GDP growth, strong housing and automotive and some returned industrial production growth.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I'm not trying to pin you them out, but just start to take that to mean, yes, I mean it's the orders have to turn positive at some point in '17 to turn around the retail sales, but the [indiscernible] slightly for the year?
componenttext: Yeah, I'm not trying to pin you them out, but just start to take that to mean, yes, I mean it's the orders have to turn positive at some point in '17 to turn around the retail sales, but the [indiscernible] slightly for the year?

componenttext: Sure. Absolutely.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. If you look at PACCAR's performance over several years in the medium duty segment, we grow share in North America, 0.5 point per year. And we would continue to expect that, that would be the case in 2017 as well. Yes, if you look at 2017 was a record deal for medium duty for PACCAR, and we're going to be pretty close to that 2015 level for 2016, and so we're optimistic that we got the products and the supporting network to make that growth continue.

componenttext: I just wanted to ask you on your European outlook of being down a little bit. I think some others are saying it's going to be flat, they be up a little bit. I just want to get some additional detail on what exactly is concerning you? Is it Brexit? Or is there certain other things?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think 260,000 to 290,000 trucks, that is an excellent truck market. We've probably taken a little bit of a conservative approach on the heels of 2016 being at 295,000 which is the best truck market since 2008. So we hope that it would continue at
componenttext: Well, I think 260,000 to 290,000 trucks, that is an excellent truck market. We've probably taken a little bit of a conservative approach on the heels of 2016 being at 295,000 which is the best truck market since 2008. So we hope that it would continue at the current pace. What we've been a little bit conservative in terms of our projection for our outlook for next year.

componenttext: Just first question just on market share in U.S. and Canada. You noted the 31% in the quarter. I think earlier in the year, you talked about the larger share capture and order activity. So it seems like over the past few years, market share has been pretty stable. Do you see some momentum building as you're looking into '17? Do you think that, that's a little bit higher?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at the history when I started with the company, we were a 21% player. We sort of went up to a new plateau at 25%. And now we're at 28%, 29%. Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to introduce additional configurations around their 2.1 meter pla
componenttext: Yes, if you look at the history when I started with the company, we were a 21% player. We sort of went up to a new plateau at 25%. And now we're at 28%, 29%. Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to introduce additional configurations around their 2.1 meter platform. Peterbilt just launched their model 5 20 for the low cap forward market. We just introduced enhanced Axel and engine components that will enhance the performance of the vehicle. So we continue to increment the product lineup. And we'll continue to do that as we have done for 20 years. And we think that will lead to continued share growth over the long-term.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relatively steady market share in the history in the last couple of years needs to be placed on the context of an oil and gas business that hasn't been generating any truck sales. And we've typically been very strong in that segment. So we're offsetting t
componenttext: Relatively steady market share in the history in the last couple of years needs to be placed on the context of an oil and gas business that hasn't been generating any truck sales. And we've typically been very strong in that segment. So we're offsetting that loss with some of the new wins that Ron talked about.

componenttext: That's a helpful point. And just a clarification. The proprietary ACCEL I think it sounds like where comments you're talking about some kind of partnerships. componenttext: That's exactly right.

componenttext: And so in terms of the opportunity for you, you talked about it's not really a margin impact. It sounds like it drives more traffic into your dealers. And then there's the obvious benefit of that.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I had a question. With the share gains that you guys are seeing, are you seeing any noticeable shift of large, larger fleets versus some of the operators? Is that something that we should be thinking about that impact on impact on gross margins going f
componenttext: So I had a question. With the share gains that you guys are seeing, are you seeing any noticeable shift of large, larger fleets versus some of the operators? Is that something that we should be thinking about that impact on impact on gross margins going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've been active in all elements of the market for many years and we are conquesting new customers all the time. But our product is very competitive with the fleets and the excellent operating efficiency of our vehicle, the higher residual v
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been active in all elements of the market for many years and we are conquesting new customers all the time. But our product is very competitive with the fleets and the excellent operating efficiency of our vehicle, the higher residual value. There's a lot of elements that make our products very attractive to large fleets, but small- and medium-sized customers as well. So a great product lineup, great performance continue to demand, 10% to 15% difference in terms of residual value versus the competitive product.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But are you seeing a mix shift within your split between the 2?
componenttext: But are you seeing a mix shift within your split between the 2?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've seen that over the last 5, 6, 7 years. More and more of our volume is with medium and larger fleet.
componenttext: Yes, I think we've seen that over the last 5, 6, 7 years. More and more of our volume is with medium and larger fleet.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That gives us the opportunity to get more looks at the parts business than we would, maybe with our own operator customers, it also gives us more looks on the Financial Services business. So that mix shift is a positive thing for us as well.
componenttext: That gives us the opportunity to get more looks at the parts business than we would, maybe with our own operator customers, it also gives us more looks on the Financial Services business. So that mix shift is a positive thing for us as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kwame Webb with Morningstar.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to do a longer-term question, so over the last decade, your market share is up almost 1,000 basis points. You guys have always been known as sort of this premium product with a low total ownership costs. You've made significant inroads into
componenttext: So I just want to do a longer-term question, so over the last decade, your market share is up almost 1,000 basis points. You guys have always been known as sort of this premium product with a low total ownership costs. You've made significant inroads into the fleet market. Do you at any point, think that your competition kind of gets it and they're trying to mimic that business model at some point or that product proposition at some point? And then the second question is, how do you think about competing about maybe that potential change in strategy?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't speak for our competition. I know what our focus is. We used to lay it out pretty well. It's a focus on providing the highest quality products, low operating cost, premium value for our customers, excellent support with aftermarket parts and
componenttext: Well, I can't speak for our competition. I know what our focus is. We used to lay it out pretty well. It's a focus on providing the highest quality products, low operating cost, premium value for our customers, excellent support with aftermarket parts and Financial Services, and that's -- continues to be our focus for the New mid- and long-term and continue to make investments to build on that. And the real compete toe to toe with our competitors with ever their approach might be.

componenttextpreview: And then just the follow-up here. So clearly, your scales increased. You launched MX engine, 4 years ago, Axel's today. I mean, should we start to think about increased vertical integration becoming a much larger part of the story going forward?

componenttext: As I mentioned earlier, it's a balance of vertical integration and supplier provided proprietary components. And so I think that's the approach that we'll continue to apply as we move forward. And you will see more as time goes on, you'll see more branded PACCAR components because they are unique to integrate with our vehicle and our powertrain.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions for us what real quick had you had to put in the price increase to offset the FX headwind? And if so, about how much might that have been? And the second question is kind of following on David Ross those question about waters in 2017 and whe
componenttext: Two questions for us what real quick had you had to put in the price increase to offset the FX headwind? And if so, about how much might that have been? And the second question is kind of following on David Ross those question about waters in 2017 and when they might inflect? Can they start to inflect upwards given where used trucks prices are now? Given that it seems like people are -- or at least a lot of customers are upside down on trades. Or do we need a certain amount of price increase in used to kind of get you to that, that there order results? And so about may be how much would you guys have to come up to kind of put people back in balance?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I mentioned before, the pound moves up and down over time and pricing adjusts to reflect that. All of the OEMs predominantly have their production on the continent. We're very fortunate that we're toward the U.K. truck maker. So we have a bit of a n
componenttext: So as I mentioned before, the pound moves up and down over time and pricing adjusts to reflect that. All of the OEMs predominantly have their production on the continent. We're very fortunate that we're toward the U.K. truck maker. So we have a bit of a natural hedge with respect to U.K. cost and prices. So yes, we'll adjust pricing as the market needs to adjust to earn a fair return of our trucks over time. With respect to used truck pricing. I think as we progress through next year, the customers are keeping their trucks perhaps a little bit longer. At some point though, the value intersects with the current market, and they'll be back in the market at some point to reinvesting new equipment. The new equipment has such attractive operating efficiencies with lower fuel consumption, better operating efficiency, the reliability and durability of the products are outstanding. So they -- you have to upgrade at some point to take advantage of those features that are on the newer products.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PACCAR's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded, and if anyone has any objections, they should disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Mr. Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Hastings, please go ahead.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President
componenttext:
Good morning. We would like to welcome those listening by phone and those on the webcast. My name is Ken Hastings, PACCAR's Director of Investor Relations, and joining me this morning are Ron Armstrong, Chief Executive Officer; Bob Christensen, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Michael Barkley, Senior Vice President and Controller.
As with prior conference calls, if there are members of the media on the line, we ask that they participate in a listen-only mode. 
Certain information presented today will be forward-looking and involve risks and uncertainties, including general economic and competitive conditions that may affect expected results. 
I would now like to introduce Ron Armstrong.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and earnings for the third quarter of 2016. PACCAR's third quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.2 billion, and third quarter net income was $346 million, a strong 8.1% after-tax return on revenu
componenttext:
Good morning. PACCAR reported good revenues and earnings for the third quarter of 2016. PACCAR's third quarter sales and Financial Services revenues were $4.2 billion, and third quarter net income was $346 million, a strong 8.1% after-tax return on revenues. PACCAR achieved excellent Truck, Parts and Other gross margins of 14.7%, driven by Peterbilt, Kenworth and DAF premium products; a robust European truck market; strong part sales and rigorous cost control. 
Kenworth and Peterbilt achieved record quarterly Class 8 market share of 31% in the U.S. and Canada. DAF increased year-to-date heavy-duty market share in Europe to 15.6%. PACCAR's increasing its investments and delivering new products and technologies, as reflected in the recent introduction of the new PACCAR axle, enhancements to PACCAR MX engines and the DAF Connect telematics system. I'm very proud of our 23,000 employees who have delivered industry-leading products and services to our customers worldwide. 
This year marks the 20th anniversary of PACCAR's acquisition of DAF Trucks. Kenworth, Peterbilt and DAF have achieved great synergies together. DAF has grown its market share from 9% to 15.6% in the last 20 years. DAF sells trucks, engines and aftermarket parts in over 100 countries worldwide. DAF's expertise in powertrain development contributed to the production of PACCAR MX  engines in North America, and 47% MX engine penetration in Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks. 
PACCAR delivered 34,900 trucks during the third quarter. Deliveries in Europe were 4% higher than last year's third quarter, with deliveries in the U.S. and Canada reflecting a lower market, partially offset by strong share growth. We've raised our 2016 forecast for Europe's greater than 16-tonne market to a range of 290,000 to 300,000 units, reflecting strong demand in a steady economy. The Eurozone's GDP growth for this year is 1.5%, with 2017 projected at a similar level. 
Freight transport activity on German highways is up 3% year-to-date compared to the same period last year. And we expect the 2017 European heavy truck market to be another excellent year in a range of 260,000 to 290,000 units. The U.S. economy is growing 1.5% this year as well. U.S. housing starts will grow 6% to 1.2 million units and the automotive industry will deliver 17.2 million vehicles comparable to last year's record sales. Our estimate of retail sales for this year's U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck market is a range of 215,000 to 225,000 units. 
For 2017, economists are forecasting higher GDP growth of 2.2%, an increase in housing starts of 8% and strong auto sales of 17.1 million units. Industrial production is expected to grow nearly 2% next year, which should be good news for the truck industry. We estimate U.S. and Canadian Class 8 truck industry retail sales will be in a range of 200,000 to 230,000 units in 2017. PACCAR global truck deliveries in the fourth quarter are estimated to be about 5% lower than the third quarter due to more holidays and slightly lower build rates in North America. This is partially offset by higher build rates and more production days in Europe. 
Truck, Parts and Other gross margins in the fourth quarter are forecast to be 50 to 100 basis points lower than the third quarter. PACCAR Parts business generated quarterly revenues of $765 million. Parts quarterly pretax income was $338 million, with an excellent pretax return on revenue of 18.1%. These results were driven by the growing number of PACCAR trucks and engines in operation and expanding network of TRP stores and the many innovative products and services offered by PACCAR Parts and our dealers. 
PACCAR Financial Services third quarter pretax income was $71 million. Excellent portfolio performance contributed to the good results. During the quarter, PACCAR Financial enhanced its technology leadership with the introduction of a mobile sales and credit system, which allows customers and dealers to complete a loan application, receive an expedited credit decision and electronically sign a contract on a mobile device. 
PACCAR's strong balance sheet and cash flows have enabled the company to invest over $6 billion in new products, technologies and facilities in the last 10 years. PACCAR estimates capital spending of $375 million to $400 million, and R&D expenses of $240 million to $250 million this year. In 2017, we forecast increased capital investments of $375 million to $425 million, and increased R&D expenses of $270 million to $300 million. 
These investments will enhance PACCAR's integrated powertrain, deliver advanced driver assistance and truck connectivity technologies, and add additional capacity and efficiency to the company's manufacturing and parts distribution facilities. 
Thank you. I'd be pleased to answer your questions.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk first about growth in the Parts segment. We've seen some good sequential increase this year over the past 2 quarters, still comping down in year-over-year terms though. So I was just wondering, I know that, historically,
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk first about growth in the Parts segment. We've seen some good sequential increase this year over the past 2 quarters, still comping down in year-over-year terms though. So I was just wondering, I know that, historically, you'd spoken about dealer inventory issues in past quarters, maybe some other moving pieces there, I was just wondering if you could give an update on what exactly is going on there and whether you're changing your forward-looking expectation so that segment can sustain, call it, low to mid-single digit growth?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, as we look forward, comparing the second half of this year to the first half of this year, we think that we'll see 2% to 4% growth during that period. And as we think about next year with the increasing number of PACCAR engines that are in the fi
componenttext: I think, as we look forward, comparing the second half of this year to the first half of this year, we think that we'll see 2% to 4% growth during that period. And as we think about next year with the increasing number of PACCAR engines that are in the field with our customers, we've sold over 100,000 MX engines so far. I think, we're -- we feel that next year's parts revenue growth will continue to see somewhere in the 2% to 4% revenue growth range.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. And then, I had another question on raw material price fluctuations. Obviously, that's been a topic that folks have focused on quite a bit recently as well as the potential impact on gross margins. So I was just wondering if you could pro
componenttext: Okay. Very good. And then, I had another question on raw material price fluctuations. Obviously, that's been a topic that folks have focused on quite a bit recently as well as the potential impact on gross margins. So I was just wondering if you could provide an update maybe or a reminder exactly how PACCAR deals with that contractually with suppliers, long-term supply agreements and any impact you think that raw material fluctuations could have on margins, maybe in the most recent quarter and then in the coming quarters as well?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 75% to 80% of our purchasers are under long-term agreements with our suppliers. Many of those have adjustment clauses that spread the effects of material cost movements over time. And I would say that the effect today has been pretty nominal
componenttext: Well, we have 75% to 80% of our purchasers are under long-term agreements with our suppliers. Many of those have adjustment clauses that spread the effects of material cost movements over time. And I would say that the effect today has been pretty nominal.

componenttext: This year, we think, hopefully, will be the bottom of this cycle and we expect to see some positive movement. But more importantly, we're very optimistic about the DAF product, its position in the market, the DAF dealers who represent DAF and our ability to grow our share as we move forward. So somewhere 40,000 trucks probably plus or minus compared to 30,000 to 32,000 this year.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And then, just shifting to U.S. and Canada dealer inventory. I know last quarter, you said that you are pretty comfortable with your inventories in the channel. Is that still the case? And then, what's your view on industry in just inventory levels?

componenttextpreview: I'm very comfortable with our situation. We have less than 60 days worth of inventory in North America. We're in great shape in Europe. So inventories in great shape. I think, the numbers I see, the industry inventory have moved down and so that should be
componenttext: I'm very comfortable with our situation. We have less than 60 days worth of inventory in North America. We're in great shape in Europe. So inventories in great shape. I think, the numbers I see, the industry inventory have moved down and so that should be good for future orders.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ann Duignan with JPMorgan.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we take a look at your forecast for 2017 for U.S. and Canada? It's a bit more optimistic than ours or some of the industry pundits. And last year this time, you were a lot more optimistic about U.S. and Canada for '16. Can you just talk a little bit a
componenttext: Can we take a look at your forecast for 2017 for U.S. and Canada? It's a bit more optimistic than ours or some of the industry pundits. And last year this time, you were a lot more optimistic about U.S. and Canada for '16. Can you just talk a little bit about where your forecast might've been wrong for 2016? And where do you think the risks might be for 2017. I mean, they could be upside or downside, frankly, but what you're seeing out there and what gives you confidence in '17 forecast?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you recall, we get smarter every quarter. And as we've progressed, we adjusted our U.S. and Canada markets downward and Europe upwards. So things happen in the economy around the world in the air. So it's -- sometimes you're on the right side, so
componenttext: Well, if you recall, we get smarter every quarter. And as we've progressed, we adjusted our U.S. and Canada markets downward and Europe upwards. So things happen in the economy around the world in the air. So it's -- sometimes you're on the right side, sometimes you're on the other side. For next year, based on economic growth expectations of 2% or so plus some industrial production improvement, continued strength in housing and automotive, we feel comfortable with the range of 200,000 to 230,000 for next year, and we'll see how that progresses. And we'll be smarter every quarter.

componenttext: Boy, yes, that's -- so the U.K. is typically 10,000 to 11,000 trucks per year, which is a really good market for DAF. And post Brexit, the demand for trucks and parts is still present. Obviously, the pound movement has had some slight impact on margins. But the pound goes up and down, and the prices adjust over time. So whatever impact there is temporary.

componenttext: I'm trying to think a little bit about your MX engine penetration. I think, when we first started on this path, it was like a 50% penetration goal. And I guess, we've achieved that. And I assume it's going to go higher going forward. I'm wondering if you have just a view of what 2017 might look like? But more than that, I'm trying to think about the utilization that, that plant in the U.S., and I'm wondering -- I'm assuming that as we get more penetration and more units of MX engines, that should be a margin tailwind for the company, but I'm curious if you just might flesh that out for me.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we do with all of our factories, we invest for the expected capacity in the midterm, I guess, you could say. And as we look long-term, we'll continue to make investments to support our expectations. And so yes, we expect the penetration of that t
componenttext: Well, as we do with all of our factories, we invest for the expected capacity in the midterm, I guess, you could say. And as we look long-term, we'll continue to make investments to support our expectations. And so yes, we expect the penetration of that to continue to climb gradually over time as more and more customers get the MX in their fleet and transition to more and more MX mix. So I think we're well-positioned supporting the current market and we'll continue to invest with new machinery to support the ongoing needs of our, really, our global needs around the world.

componenttext: Two questions, I guess. One, given that we're sort of at the end of October, can you talk to sort of what you're hearing from the big fleets and sort of how they're thinking about 2017 irregardless of your retail sales forecast or what you're hearing from the small and medium-sized fleets? And then, I guess, the second question, on '17, assuming that your retail sales forecast are correct for both the U.S. and Europe, I don't think you talked about this in the prepared remarks, can you talk about where you think gross margins can be, whether they'd be flat, down or up just with some of the market dynamics that are taking place?

componenttext: So our discussions with our customers are really focused on one, the great performance of our products in the market. Discussions have typically centered on, I guess, I would say, a comparable level of investment next year to what they've done this year sort of small, medium, large, et cetera. I think a lot of that will obviously be dictated by how the economy develops. In terms of gross margins, thinking about next year, obviously, there's a lot of things that will impact that over time. Right now, I would say, our next year margins would be comparable to what we'll see in the fourth quarter this year, plus or minus 0.5% up or down.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Gilardi with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, PACCAR was very early at cutting production in late 2015, and you're, sounds like, guiding to a slightly weaker Q4. Are you taking production down another notch in the U.S. right now? And would you suspect that when you do that, you'll be abl
componenttext: Yes, I mean, PACCAR was very early at cutting production in late 2015, and you're, sounds like, guiding to a slightly weaker Q4. Are you taking production down another notch in the U.S. right now? And would you suspect that when you do that, you'll be able to produce in line with retail for 2017, which you're basically guiding flat to down 2% or so?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our approach has always been, for a lot of years, has always been to build based on demand of our customers and our dealers, and our actions with respect to production reflect that. The great news is that in the third quarter, we achieved a record m
componenttext: Well, our approach has always been, for a lot of years, has always been to build based on demand of our customers and our dealers, and our actions with respect to production reflect that. The great news is that in the third quarter, we achieved a record market share for Peterbilt and Kenworth combined in U.S. and Canada of 31%. So great recognition of the great products that they're producing at their factories currently. And we'll continue to build based on what that market demand looks like. So inventories are in great shape. And so I would think that retail would be closely tied to production levels as we move forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just on Parts, with respect to this 18% margin that you've held, I think, for 7 or the last 8 quarters, or somewhere close to that, do you feel like it's sustainable going forward? Because certainly, you've been operating performing at a level
componenttext: Got it. And just on Parts, with respect to this 18% margin that you've held, I think, for 7 or the last 8 quarters, or somewhere close to that, do you feel like it's sustainable going forward? Because certainly, you've been operating performing at a level higher than you were 2 to 3 years ago.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And the team has done a great job with leveraging the operating infrastructure that we have in the Parts business. We've obviously added -- enhanced our Parts distribution capabilities in the northwestern part of the U.S. with the Renton facility. W
componenttext: Sure. And the team has done a great job with leveraging the operating infrastructure that we have in the Parts business. We've obviously added -- enhanced our Parts distribution capabilities in the northwestern part of the U.S. with the Renton facility. We'll be adding some additional facilities in the coming future, all balanced to meet the market demand and ensure that our customers are getting the best support in the industry with keeping their trucks operating on the road. So I think, we'll continue to see that level of performance.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I think, slightly. Yes, slightly negative. Yes. We're -- typically, the average sales price of a truck in Europe is a little lower than the average sales price in North America. So mix has some impact on that.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And the if I look at the FinCo [ph], I'm splitting hairs a little bit, we've seen some really modest increases in the provisions for losses on receivables. componenttext: It's as you said, it's very modest. The portfolio is performing -- actually that credit loss level is at historically low levels. A few customers in the oil and gas business, but that's the focus of it.

componenttext: I didn't really comment on that, but I think, the fourth quarter, we're looking at comparables revenue levels, I think, in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Timothy Thein with Citi.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just coming back to the U.S. and Canada. Obviously, just given Peterbilt's position in the vocational the market, pretty well-represented there. It looks as though your overall retail outlook, a little bit more positive than some. But I'm just curious, as
componenttext: Just coming back to the U.S. and Canada. Obviously, just given Peterbilt's position in the vocational the market, pretty well-represented there. It looks as though your overall retail outlook, a little bit more positive than some. But I'm just curious, as we hear from some of the big truckload companies here in the past day or 2, it looks like they're pulling back on spending a bit more. So I'm just curious if you could maybe slice your comments on U.S. and Canada more finely between trucks versus tractors for '17 in terms of your expectations for the broader market.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Bob. I think, we see a fairly comparable level of buy from both the vocational and the over-the-road customers in 2017 from 2016. Both Kenworth and Peterbilt have strong vocational presence. I think, combined, the company is 35% to 40% market
componenttext: Tim, this is Bob. I think, we see a fairly comparable level of buy from both the vocational and the over-the-road customers in 2017 from 2016. Both Kenworth and Peterbilt have strong vocational presence. I think, combined, the company is 35% to 40% market share in the vocational business, which has been very, very good for us over the last couple of years. But increasingly, the new Peterbilts and the new Kenworths are getting even more traction in some of the larger fleets. And so we're getting incremental kind of conquest purchases from customers. But on balance, we think that the 2017 is going to look very, very comparable to 2016.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then, just coming back to the question earlier on used values. Can you comment on what -- I mean, the MX has been out there long enough and just given normal trade cycles, I presume you've got a little bit more volume to make a call or h
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, just coming back to the question earlier on used values. Can you comment on what -- I mean, the MX has been out there long enough and just given normal trade cycles, I presume you've got a little bit more volume to make a call or have a little bit more visibility on it. Can you just give us some color in terms of how the trucks with the MX have been performing in the secondary markets?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we started to get those deals -- first trucks are -- that we built in 2010, '11 are now passing on to the second owner. And I think what we'll see as time goes on is the durability with the CGI steel that we used to build, the head and block, and just
componenttext: So we started to get those deals -- first trucks are -- that we built in 2010, '11 are now passing on to the second owner. And I think what we'll see as time goes on is the durability with the CGI steel that we used to build, the head and block, and just the rigorous testing that we put the engines through, that, that will be reflected in the used prices over time as we move forward. So we're very optimistic about how that will progress.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: If you keep getting smarter every quarter, by 2019, you'll be able to give us a single point earnings forecast. I wonder, in the Parts decline, if you can give us any color in the quarter. If it was more on the volume side or any pricing weakness or mix?

componenttextpreview: It's primarily -- it's all volume-related, sort of the volume of shipments. Yes.
componenttext: It's primarily -- it's all volume-related, sort of the volume of shipments. Yes.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, since so many questions are about sort of doubting your flat forecast for 2017, I just wonder if you can give us a couple of things that we should incorporate into our thinking around levers you can pull to show earnings resiliency in 2017 if things are a little worse than flat?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we commented on, we continue to make prudent investments in operating efficiency, both in our factories, the warehouses. We continue to use more and more technology in our business processes, in our factories and continuing to provide new technolo
componenttext: Yes, as we commented on, we continue to make prudent investments in operating efficiency, both in our factories, the warehouses. We continue to use more and more technology in our business processes, in our factories and continuing to provide new technology to our customers. So we'll just continue to make those investments. And if you look back at the history, we've got a history of delivering 5% to 7% efficiency and gains over the long-term. And we'll continue to make those kinds of investments as we move into 2017.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weber with RBC.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a bigger picture question. With the launch of the proprietary axle, should we think about that as the start of -- well, not the start, but kind of the next step in the increased vertical integration? And can you talk about what your t
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a bigger picture question. With the launch of the proprietary axle, should we think about that as the start of -- well, not the start, but kind of the next step in the increased vertical integration? And can you talk about what your take rate expectations are for that product starting next year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a nice balance of vertical integration with some of our components and great relationships with our suppliers in other areas. And I think, we'll continue with that balanced approach for this particular axle. If you look out probably a year o
componenttext: Well, we have a nice balance of vertical integration with some of our components and great relationships with our suppliers in other areas. And I think, we'll continue with that balanced approach for this particular axle. If you look out probably a year or 2 down the road, this axle will probably be 30%, 40%, 50% of what we -- of the axles that we put on our North American vehicles. And of course, the axles we put on DAF products are 100% PACCAR axles. So we have a combination of vertical and supplier-provided. But more and more -- much more of the supplier-provided components are proprietary in that they're developed to work in a very efficient manner with the rest of our powertrain component. So you'll continue to see that trend as we move forward going with all of our suppliers.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just from a kind of an initial ramp perspective, should we think about it as kind of margin-neutral in 2017, and it takes a little while to hit critical mass? Or should that be accretive from the get go?
componenttext: And just from a kind of an initial ramp perspective, should we think about it as kind of margin-neutral in 2017, and it takes a little while to hit critical mass? Or should that be accretive from the get go?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it'll be a big factor in terms of  margin performance.
componenttext: No, I don't think it'll be a big factor in terms of  margin performance.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neil Frohnapple with Longbow Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up to Andy's question. Within the Financial Services segment, the increase in the interest and other expense in the quarter, what can that be attributed to? It sounds like you struck prices maybe not so much. Anything else you can point to
componenttext: A quick follow-up to Andy's question. Within the Financial Services segment, the increase in the interest and other expense in the quarter, what can that be attributed to? It sounds like you struck prices maybe not so much. Anything else you can point to there?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it -- the factor is the used truck pricing and reflecting that as adjustments to depreciation expense over time. So as we have trucks return off lease, et cetera, that typically runs through the depreciation expense line. So that's one element of it
componenttext: Well, it -- the factor is the used truck pricing and reflecting that as adjustments to depreciation expense over time. So as we have trucks return off lease, et cetera, that typically runs through the depreciation expense line. So that's one element of it. And then, the rest of it is just the competitiveness of the market and the spread of interest earned and interest paid. So that's the 2 elements of it.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, how are your inventory levels positioned at your used truck centers in North America? Just curious if inventory levels are normal or higher than historical levels?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, how are your inventory levels positioned at your used truck centers in North America? Just curious if inventory levels are normal or higher than historical levels?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say normal. And we're continuing to invest in our ability to support our used truck operations. As time has gone on, we deal with a lot more larger fleets. We're more heavily engaged in taking trade-ins with our customers and working with our deal
componenttext: I would say normal. And we're continuing to invest in our ability to support our used truck operations. As time has gone on, we deal with a lot more larger fleets. We're more heavily engaged in taking trade-ins with our customers and working with our dealers. And so we'll continue to invest. We're probably going to open by the end of the year a new facility in the Chicago area and adding some additional capacity at our facility in Salt Lake City. So it's, I'd say, normal at a higher level just given the level of activity that we're seeing with trade-ins and operating lease activity.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Raso with Evercore ISI.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 5% sequential decline 3Q to 4Q, can you help us with that a little bit sequentially when it comes to Europe versus other versus U.S., Canada?
componenttext: The 5% sequential decline 3Q to 4Q, can you help us with that a little bit sequentially when it comes to Europe versus other versus U.S., Canada?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So it's lower operating leverage from a lower production level for the quarter. Slight reduction in price realization in U.S. and Canada because of the competitive market conditions, and a small impact from the movement of the pound versus the euro.
componenttext: Sure. So it's lower operating leverage from a lower production level for the quarter. Slight reduction in price realization in U.S. and Canada because of the competitive market conditions, and a small impact from the movement of the pound versus the euro. The pound is -- while it's down, it's certainly within a range that we've seen in the last near-term history. And so as time goes on, we'll work through that and prices will adjust to a more normalized margin level going forward.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just so I'm clear, though, that down 5%, that's a production number? Can I equate that to a unit number as well? I mean, I'm just trying to work off of a down 5% sequentially should be a little over 33,000 units from what you...
componenttext: And just so I'm clear, though, that down 5%, that's a production number? Can I equate that to a unit number as well? I mean, I'm just trying to work off of a down 5% sequentially should be a little over 33,000 units from what you...

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But within that, is that sort of a Europe up 10%, North America -- U.S., Canada down high-teens, with other doing their sequential normal uptick?
componenttext: But within that, is that sort of a Europe up 10%, North America -- U.S., Canada down high-teens, with other doing their sequential normal uptick?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I don't have the specific numbers, Dave. But definitely, Europe will be up because of increased work day and we have the summer shutdown, so we have more work days in the fourth quarter plus a slightly higher build rate and that'll be offset by U.S. and Canada.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And other usually -- having its usual fourth quarter...
componenttext: And other usually -- having its usual fourth quarter...

componenttextpreview: Yes, it'll be -- I think, it'll be pretty comparable to the third quarter levels.
componenttext: Yes, it'll be -- I think, it'll be pretty comparable to the third quarter levels.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, on the U.S., Canada outlook for '17, I know it's an industry forecast, not yours, but when I think of the cadence through the year, when we think about retail sales have been running of late, still down 20%, orders have been down, up 25%,
componenttext: Okay. And then, on the U.S., Canada outlook for '17, I know it's an industry forecast, not yours, but when I think of the cadence through the year, when we think about retail sales have been running of late, still down 20%, orders have been down, up 25%, 30%. The comps do ease especially for the orders in the spring. Can you take us through your thought process on the down 2%. Is it an industry order rate starting to turn positive by late spring? And it's sort of a unit sales kind of down, whatever, high single digit in the first half, up? High single-digit in the second half, a little bit more than that? Just trying to think how back half-loaded is it, but appreciating that the orders, at some point, you hope, turn positive given the comps get easier call it April, May?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, all the OEMs have been building trucks out of the backlog throughout this year. And so, I think, you'll see the conversions of order levels, retail sales, production, et cetera, at whatever the run rate will be. And I think, our feeling is t
componenttext: Yes, I think, all the OEMs have been building trucks out of the backlog throughout this year. And so, I think, you'll see the conversions of order levels, retail sales, production, et cetera, at whatever the run rate will be. And I think, our feeling is that as we get past the first year, we'll see some progression given the economic assumptions about continued GDP growth, strong housing and automotive and some return to industrial production growth.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yeah, and not trying to pin you to a mug, but just try to take that to mean, yes, I mean, just mathematically, the orders have to turn positive at some point in '17 to turn around the retail sales to be up for the -- have to be down slightly for the year?
componenttext: Yeah, and not trying to pin you to a mug, but just try to take that to mean, yes, I mean, just mathematically, the orders have to turn positive at some point in '17 to turn around the retail sales to be up for the -- have to be down slightly for the year?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Absolutely.
componenttext: Sure. Absolutely.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Shlisky with Seaport Global.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: So I was wondering if you can give us your outlook for the Class 5 to 7 market for 2017. I know it's small for you, but would love to hear your color on how that's going and how it might turn out next year?

componenttext: Well, it will be a comparable level to this year. Probably somewhere in the 80,000 unit range.

componenttext: Okay. Great. If you could also give us kind of your thoughts on how share is going in that region in that size range both this year and do you have goals to grow that share next year in Class 5 through 7?

componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. If you look at PACCAR's performance over several years in the medium duty segment, we grow share in North America 0.5% per year. And we would continue to expect that would be the case in 2017 as well.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. If you look at PACCAR's performance over several years in the medium duty segment, we grow share in North America 0.5% per year. And we would continue to expect that would be the case in 2017 as well.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at 2015 was a record deal for medium duty truck deliveries for PACCAR, and we're going to be pretty close to that 2015 level for 2016, and so we're optimistic that we've got the products and the supporting network to make that growth cont
componenttext: Yes, if you look at 2015 was a record deal for medium duty truck deliveries for PACCAR, and we're going to be pretty close to that 2015 level for 2016, and so we're optimistic that we've got the products and the supporting network to make that growth continue.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to ask you on your European outlook of being down a little bit. I think, some others are saying it's going to be flat, maybe up a little bit. And I just wanted to get some additional detail on what exactly is concerning you? Is it the Brexit? Or certain other things?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, 260,000 to 290,000 trucks, that is an excellent truck market. We've probably taken a little bit of a conservative approach on the heels of 2016 being at 295,000, which is the best truck market since 2008. So we hope that it would continue at the cur
componenttext: Well, 260,000 to 290,000 trucks, that is an excellent truck market. We've probably taken a little bit of a conservative approach on the heels of 2016 being at 295,000, which is the best truck market since 2008. So we hope that it would continue at the current pace, but we've been a bit conservative in terms of our projection for our outlook for next year.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea with Vertical Research.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question just on market share in U.S. and Canada. You noted the 31% in the quarter. I think, earlier in the year, you talked a little bit about larger share capture in order activity. So it seems like over the past few years, market share has been p
componenttext: First question just on market share in U.S. and Canada. You noted the 31% in the quarter. I think, earlier in the year, you talked a little bit about larger share capture in order activity. So it seems like over the past few years, market share has been pretty stable. Do you see some momentum building as you're looking into '17? Do you think that, that's a little bit higher?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at the history when I started with the company, we were a 21% player and we sort of went up to a new plateau at 25%. And now, we're at 28%, 29%. Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to introduce additional configurations around their 2.1 meter
componenttext: Yes, if you look at the history when I started with the company, we were a 21% player and we sort of went up to a new plateau at 25%. And now, we're at 28%, 29%. Peterbilt and Kenworth continue to introduce additional configurations around their 2.1 meter platform. Peterbilt just launched their Model 520 for the low cap forward market. We just introduced enhanced axle and engine components that will enhance the performance of the vehicle. So we continue to increment the product lineup. And we'll continue to do that as we have done for 20 years. And we think that will lead to continued share growth over the long-term.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: A relatively steady market share history over the last couple of years needs to be placed in the context of an oil and gas business that hasn't been generating any truck sales. And we've typically been fairly strong in that segment. So we're offsetting th
componenttext: A relatively steady market share history over the last couple of years needs to be placed in the context of an oil and gas business that hasn't been generating any truck sales. And we've typically been fairly strong in that segment. So we're offsetting that loss with some of the new wins that Ron talked about.

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a helpful point. And then, just a clarification, the proprietary axle. I think, Ron, it sounds like from your comments, you're talking about some kind of supplier partnerships. And it sounds like this is that case. This isn't taking something from
componenttext: That's a helpful point. And then, just a clarification, the proprietary axle. I think, Ron, it sounds like from your comments, you're talking about some kind of supplier partnerships. And it sounds like this is that case. This isn't taking something from DAF and bringing it over. This is something that was codeveloped and will be manufacturing in North America and then supplied  to you. Is that how this thing works?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: That's exactly right.

componenttext: Okay. And so in terms of the opportunity for you, you talked about it's not really a margin impact, it sounds like it drives more traffic into your dealers. And then, there's the obvious benefit of that.

componenttext: Yes, there's definitely a competitive advantage that comes with this proprietary axle and the integration of it with the rest of the elements of the powertrain.

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: So I had a question. With the share gains that you guys are seeing, are you seeing any noticeable shift of larger fleets versus owner-operators? And is that something that we should be thinking about that has an impact on gross margins going forward?

headline: PACCAR Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, we've been active in all elements of the market for many years and we are conquesting new customers all the time. But our product is very competitive with the fleets and the excellent operating efficiency of our vehicle, the higher residual
componenttext: Yes, I think, we've been active in all elements of the market for many years and we are conquesting new customers all the time. But our product is very competitive with the fleets and the excellent operating efficiency of our vehicle, the higher residual value, there's a lot of elements that make our products very attractive not only to large fleets, but small and medium-sized customers as well. So a great product lineup, great performance continue to demand a 10% to 15% difference in terms of residual value versus the competitive product.
